address: No. 1 Kampung Orang Asli, Telok Jawa, Masai 28990 Masai, Johor Malaysia
comment: Delicious food reasonable price we finish 5 dishes of our food just waiting our chili crab for 1 hour its so disappointed.

address: No. 1 Kampung Orang Asli, Telok Jawa, Masai 28990 Masai, Johor Malaysia
comment: Been here for more than 3 times now for seafood. Quality seafood at reasonable prices. They have a wide variety of fish, crabs and other sea produce for selection. I personally like their chili crab which is all time favorite. The place is not very accessible meaning you will have to take a cab or drive here. It can get crowded on weekends and dinner hours so preferably get a reservation in advance.

Located just beside the Ubin FIrst Stop Restaurant, it is not as famous as its neighbour. Although it's not one of the more well-known eating places on Pulau Ubin, once you step in, you'll feel the spirit of Ubin overwhelm you. Across all the walls are beautiful old photographs of Pulau Ubin, from nature shots to historical photos from decades long gone. It's the de facto community art gallery of Ubin.Affectionately known as the "two sisters" coffee shop by regulars, the place is run by two sisters who were born and bred on the offshore island. An evidence of how well loved it is can be seen by the photographs that were all donated to the sisters by regulars that include many a professional photographers, and old timer islanders who have known the sisters since they were little. It doesn't get as authentic as this.Food wise, they serve up the usual "chze char" fare. The food is nothing to brag about but it's all in the service and homeliness of the coffeeshop that brings regulars back again and again. It is especially comforting when the island is overrun by tourists in seafood restaurants, you would have some luck finding a good spot at Sin Lam Huat. But watch out on a hot day, seats inside could get pretty stuffy. Alfresco is the way to go if you're lucky.

address: 129 Pasir Ris Road, Pasir Ris Park Carpark E #01-02 Singapore 519150 Singapore
comment: Located inside Pasir Ris park, this small restaurant could be easily missed. It opens after 6pm on a sunday evening that I visited them. It has a small cosy ambience inside and the food is good! I miss the carbonara there when I had it with my family. They also serve beers, martinis, pizzas, buffalo wings and thus is a nice place to chill out with a few friends. Furthermore it is situated close to the beach, and couples love to take a walk after a meal there. Food prices are reasonable and I like that they don't charge you GST nor service charge, but they do charge you 40 cents per cup of ice water.Good for small group birthday celebrations, mid-size family gatherings, beach goers and couples.

address: 2 Jln Lokam #01-51/52 Kensington Square Singapore 537846 Singapore
comment: It was located under an apartment block. From outside, one would think this place as another drinking place in the neighbourhood with dark tinted glass. Inside besides the bar, there was wifi available, dart machines, pool table and telecasted soccer match on the screen. But the bigger surprise turned out to be the menu, which had quite a wide variety of dishes from western to chinese zi char dishes. For every order of main course during lunch, one will get a choice of soup and a choice of drink (soft drink/ coffee/ tea) with a $5 topup.For CarlsBerg Beer, it was having a promotion currently at $60.00/ tower, and $25.00/ jug.Crispy Prawn Twister 腐皮炸大虾 ($12.80)Served with celery and carrot sticks with tartar sauceThis was one of our table's hot favourite with chunky prawns encased inside the thin crispy filo pastry crust.Fish & Fries 炸鱼薯条 ($15.80)Golden fried fish fillet served with classic tartar sauce, coleslaw and crispy friesThis was one of the most popular dishes in the bistro. Nice golden brown crust, but the fish inside was a bit too mushy for me. Maybe we had taken a bit too long before starting on this dish.Aglio Olio with 3 types of mushroom 三菇意大利面 ($16.80)Garlic aplenty cooked in white wine and extra virgin olive oil together with fresh button mushrooms, shimeji mushrooms and shiitake mushroomsIt was cooked with chilli padi which I felt had overwhelmed the dish. The white wine taste was distinct but not for the garlic. Lamb Rack 羊肉架 ($23.80)3 bone premium lamb rack cooked together with garlic and lemongrass presented with green salad and stirred-fried potato; complemented with red wine brown sauceThe lamb was tender and one was able to chew it easily. Some may felt that it tasted a bit gamey.Crispy Egg Seafood Noodles 生面 ($10.80)The noodles was nicely crisp, topped with lots of liao on top.Sweet and Sour Pork with Sunny Side up and Fragrant Rice 古老肉饭 ($8.00)Another zi char dish which was quite popular with the customers. The meat was juicy sweet and tender.German Pork Knuckle 德国猪蹄 ($55.80)Pre-order only"Chef Specialty" presented with garden green salad, homemade mash potato and thai chilli sauceThe skin was nicely crisp without too hard and the meat went quite well with the dip. One would wish that the mash was not hidden under the pile of meat.Roast Beef 烤牛肉 ($88.00)Pre-order only600gms Roast beef cooked to order. Presented with garden green salad and oven baked potato complemented with black pepper brown sauce Ribeye was used here and cooked to nice pink in colour. Although the meat was tender, certain parts needed the jaws to work a bit more. The green salad which was served with a creamy dressing was quite nice and the fish roes in it gave a burst in texture.

address: 2 Jln Lokam #01-51/52 Kensington Square Singapore 537846 Singapore
comment: Cozy Bistro & Lounge was started just 4 months ago by Kevin Koo who ran a previous entertainment business for 10 years. Cozy Bistro & Lounge is equipped with, Pool Table x 01, Darts machines x 02 and Telecast soccer match on TV. Nestled in the Jalan Lokam residential neighbourhood, it is within reach of Bartley or Serangoon MRT stations.1. Crispy Prawn Twister 12.80- Served with celery and carrot sticks with tartar sauce. Probably one of my favourite snacks to munch on while darting. Definitely a fun way to eat your favourite fried prawns! Crispy and tasty!2. Lamb Rack $23.80 *Highly Recommended*- 3 bone premium lamb rack cooked together with garlic and lemongrass presented with green salad and stirred-fried potato; complemented with red wine brown sauce. This is probably why I would come back! The lamb rack was so juicy and tender. One bite and you'll be sold. A good mix of meat and fats, with some light seasoning, makes this so irresistible.  It was melt in your mouth delicious.4. Roast Beef (Pre-order only) $88.00The roast beef was very thickly sliced and cooked to a perfect medium; it was salty, meaty goodness. Sides were also good: salad with dressing was good and oven baked potato. - 600gms Roast beef cooked to order. Presented with garden green salad and oven baked potato complemented with black pepper brown sauce.6. German Pork Knuckle (Pre-order only) $55.80- "Chef Specialty" presented with garden green salad, homemade mash potato and thai chilli sauce. Crispy on the outside pork knuckle skin and juicy and meaty on the inside. This is great for a party of 4 or more! It's huge! The homemade mash potato was a nice discovery, it was flavourful and savoury. I would definitely consider ordering this for a cool boys night out!Other dishes such as the Mushroom Aglio Olio was a tad spicy for me and tasted slightly bland for my taste. But again here, Cozy Bistroy & Lounge is extremely generous with the amount of mushrooms served!There is a current promo for CarlsBerg Beer $60.00 for a Tower or $25.00 for a Jug.Overall : Do stop by Cozy Bistro & Lounge for a fun night out without hurting your wallet! Prices are nett and you have gotta try the Lamb Rack $23.80,   German Pork Knuckle (Pre-order only) $55.80 and Crispy Egg Seafood Noodles $10.80.

Did sum-body say dim sum? On my way! So good that I came here 2 days in a row!A Michelin Star dim sum restaurant with multiple locations in different countries around the world. I really wished there was one in California.Some of my favorites dishes include: - Pork and shrimp dumpling (Sui Mai) -- A classic. So delicious. - Shrimp dumpling (har gow) -- shrimply yummy!- Pork dumplings in hot & spicy sauce -- a nice spice kick to my dumplings. Great flavor and very tasty! - BBQ pork rice noodle roll & Shrimp rice noodle roll -- so silky and smooth. Good filling. And of course, can't leave without getting yourself an order of (HK) Egg tarts. So eggy and soft! I love it soo much! DELICIOUS. I would recommend everyone try Tim Ho Wan!!!

Really enjoyed my dim sum brunch!I had high expectations based on the Michelin star and it more or less met expectations.  Good execution, great flavors, good service.I got the BBQ pork buns, pork & shrimp siew mai, shrimp rice rolls, spicy pork dumplings.The BBQ pork buns were the best I've had.  Really good bun and well marinated, high quality pork filling.  Spicy pork dumplings were also well executed.  Great sauce.

What's good about this place is it's open until 3 o'clock in the morning, a good place to go to grab some dimsums if you're craving it during unconventional time. I have been to Tim Ho Wan in Hong Kong (North Point branch) and their menu is more extensive than this branch in Singapore and I honestly believe their food is better compared to this place. Be sure to get their baked char siew pork buns though, they are to die for!
This is a fast food dim sum place. I preferred a real Cha Lo. Limited dim sum selection. Nothing outstanding.

In the mall right next to the office building, the dimsums were ok. We were hungry, so ate it all up but nothing spectacular for all the hype about it.The funny: The waitress was stern - we were joking that we better get our order right or else she was going to ask us to report to detention!

Came for lunch on a Sunday and the restaurant was the only one doing brisk business in this place. No surprise as its mainly a office building so parking was a breeze. There was a queue at THW but moved rather quickly. We ordered a whole bunch of their dim sum including their promotion specials - fried dry Hor Fun with chicken and prawns. What we had and verdict - Glutinous rice in lotus leaf - very good Har gow - $6 for 4 is quite expensive and on par with Chinese restaurants in hotels. That said, it was competently done with thin skin and crunchy shrimp filling. Siew Mai - same feedback as the Har Gow. Malay cake - fluffy soft and not too sweet. Wu Kok with Chili crab filling - interesting. Not badSpinach and shrimp dumpling - loved this with its chewy transparent skinShrimp Cheong fun - decentCheong fun with sesame sauce - won't order this again as its quite boring and the sesame sauce was on the stingyHot tea is chargeable but refillable.

Frankly speaking, I don't see what's all the hype about this place. The food is extremely normal, nothing that screams WOW!!!! As you can see, there's not much photo of food as THERE'S NOTHING NICE that deserve a space in my photo. I will say it's just an overpriced hype food that will be going out of fashion soon.I have given this place, different branches, a few chances. I will say, it's really nothing fantastic. Save the calories for other more deserving food.I will give this place zero star for the food. The saving grace is the service. The serving staff comes with additional bowls and soup without us asking for it. So this 1 star is for the excellent service staffs that they have.

Overhyped. Overpriced. UnderwhelmedDISCLAIMER: we got there at 2am so the supper menu was available (which is not as extensive as their regular menu) but it made such an impact, this is the first and last time ill ever visit a tim ho wan.Also, they asked us for our last order at 230am, so not quite sure if they 24 hrs everyday. Pl call ahead to check. We had the fish porridge, beef brisket noodles, har gow, chicken feet, veggie of the day (poached lettuce) and shrimp/pork wrapped in beancurd skinOf all the dishes, we liked the veggies the best!!!Har kow prawns were big/fresh but skin was chewy.Beancurd skin was also chewy. The beef brisket was very tender but tasteless, as was its Soup. The porridge was average and the chicken feet is braised, so if youre expecting the usual chicken feet dim sum dish (which we were), youll be disappointedAll in all, it cost us close to $50.You are better off heading to swee choon for your late night dim sum fix. We only ended up at tim ho wan cause it was a tues and swee choon was closed

For all the awards they received we had expected better and were disappointed. We had the porridge, chicken feet, chive dumping , shrimp roll, baked char siew pau, dessert -chrysanthemum jello . The items were either too sweet or too salty. Majority of the items were in the $6 per dish. Don't mind paying if food was good.
I thought the food was very average considering how much people talk about them. Service is, ehrm, Singaporean.  Definitely not your culinary experience to talk about. Wouldn't recommend.

If you're willing to wait 30 min or more for a brunch/dim sum on Sunday and I recommend this place.  Braised bun Bbq pork , chicken feet, are good, quite filling for Sunday morning.  Not too pricey( $50 sing) for two with 7 different type of food.  I forgot what I ate due to food coma...

In the mall right next to the office building, the dimsums were ok. We were hungry, so ate it all up but nothing spectacular for all the hype about it.The funny: The waitress was stern - we were joking that we better get our order right or else she was going to ask us to report to detention!

If this is HK fare then I think the Brits must have done the dimsum pre 1997.I have never tried this famous place in HK but I have given this place 2 or 3 chances to blow me away. Its a popular spot indeed with q's building up. This branch is 24H and seems to be filled most hours of the night. I tried it once at 9 pm and another time at 1 am. My experience was similar.Tasteless beef noodle ( where I had to pour my entire portion of sauce and chilli) to get a modicum of taste.  Limp cheong fan.  Hey giving up my ketofgenic diet for a limp cheong fan is a big deal to me. Soya sauce for the CCF was also rather thin.A very forgettable ordeal. Charsiu pau which was warm and toasty helped assuage a bit of the hunger.
Wait too long for quality of food.Michelin starred? are you kidding me?Not any better than other regular dimsum places.Feels more like cafeteria dimsum.just not up to par to justify all the hype....
I thought the food was very average considering how much people talk about them. Service is, ehrm, Singaporean.  Definitely not your culinary experience to talk about. Wouldn't recommend.
Char siew Char Siew. But not worth the queue. Service is prompt. Porridge is a tiny bowl. Just mostly the Char Siew. My Fav!
This is a fast food dim sum place. I preferred a real Cha Lo. Limited dim sum selection. Nothing outstanding.

For all the awards they received we had expected better and were disappointed. We had the porridge, chicken feet, chive dumping , shrimp roll, baked char siew pau, dessert -chrysanthemum jello . The items were either too sweet or too salty. Majority of the items were in the $6 per dish. Don't mind paying if food was good.

I was passing by around here and searched for other things to try while in Hougang ang came across a review about this place and wanted to try it for my self. I'm kind of scared trying out noodles with a dark color sauce but the reviews were good. They say that there is usualy a long line on weekends.. Long lines on food stalls usually mean good/cheap food.Anyway, I ordered the Lor Mee by showing uncle the pic of the dish. He asked me if it was my first time trying that dish and I said, yes. He is quite friendly and offered to pick the sauces to be mixed and I gladly accepted. I don't know how to describe the dish but it has a lot of ingredients. I enjoyed eating it even though I do not know how to feel about the taste. Hehe. It was yummy and I was very full after finishing my meal. I stood up and gave uncle a 2 thumbs up before leaving the table. :)  worth the try :)

There's often a patient line at this stall and while I'm not the biggest fan of lor mee, my curiosity was piqued and the stars aligned when there was nary a line one afternoon. I'm glad I tried it. The gravy is not too gooey or gummy and it's packed with ingredients for $2.50. But the star is the combination of garlic and chilli they put on the spoon. When mixed with the viscous gravy and the noodles, it gives it a real kick. While not necessarily a lor mee convert, I'll be open to another bowl at Lor Ah Soo Lor Mee sometime soon.

The Lor Mee uncle knows me because I'm one of the few who like my noodles uber vinegary and I always request for less noodles and more protein in the form of fish cakes! The soy based gravy is delicious and aromatic and for $4.50 a serving, Lor Mee remains one of my favorite street eats in Singapore!
Pretty underrated lor mee. Good selection of ingredients, you can really feel the love

This stall has easily the best lor mee in Hougang as it is easy to find a lor mee stall but difficult to find one that is really good and cheap and with alot of ingredients. One bowl can easily have 6-7 ingredients and they all taste so tasty and delicious.The sauce is not too starchy also yet has the right consistency. I love that it has my favourite ingredients such as egg, fish cake, wanton, ngo hiang, the 3 layered meat, and even fried fish. I love to have my lor mee with the thick bee hoon and lots of chilli, vinegar and garlic.The aunty has a pleasant personality and even though i requested for a lot of things she didn't seem to be angry at all, some stall folks would get angry as it is different from the usual order. Would love to go back soon.

My mum used to do her marketing at this market when we lived around that area and I used to head to the food centre above the market to have breakfast on Saturdays and Sundays. There is a great variety of food at the food centre, many of which are pretty good. The fried white carrot cake stall there serves up a delightful, crispy and tasty dish. There is a particular Nasi Lemak stall called Yi Liu Xiang that is an old time favourite of mine. They have such awesome chili and ikan bilis that I can just eat the rice with those two ingredients alone.Parking is pretty readily available in the adjoining multi-storey carpark. The food stalls tend to close pretty early (around 2-3pm) so there isn't a point heading there for dinner.

Located just 100m away from tai seng mrt exit A is grasso coffee. It takes up two units at Irving Place. They have a wide variety of grab and go breakfast offerings, catered to the work community in this heavily industrailized area.Muffins, Swiss rolls and even tiramisu! There's something for everyone!I got myself a chicken mayo sandwich, at just $2 it was pretty delicious. Wholemeal bread, fresh veggies, the tomato was somewhat sweet and there were generous, huge chicken chunks.They sell kopi, Teh at $1 like your typical kopitiam but they also sell cotton candy and even caramel popcorn frappes at $6.Grasso Coffee is here to target both the young, hipster crowd as well as the traditional audience! They open at 8am on weekdays :)

A nice cafe tucked away in Tai Seng industrial area! Not too far away from the MRT (exit A) with ample seats and comfortable food. Customers can enjoy set meals which are value for money with food ranging from baked goods (muffins, tiramisu (no alcohol), cakes) to mains like baked rice. Something special to note is that it sells your regular nanyang coffee ($1.70 and up) as well as gourmet coffee-both which taste above average. Had the berry coffee ($6.50) on my first try and it was not too sweet. They also sell sandwiches for $2 which are conveniently packed for takeaway! Would recommend the garlic shrooms croissant/sandwich :)

Grasso Coffee's concept is a take away kiosk that offers freshly made coffee, which menu covers both traditional and gourmet flavours. They offer Nanyang styles of kopi, kopi-o, kopi-c to Western choices of espresso, latte, ice-blended frappe, etc. To complement the drinks, the cafe also serves food items such as focaccia bread, egg tarts and muffins. They are made and baked in the shop to be served freshly everyday in limited quantities.

rest_name: Tian Wai Tian Fish Head Steamboat
comment: This is my go-to place for fish head steamboat whenever I am in the mood for it. I first tried it at the main restaurant along Serangoon Road and that place was pretty rustic and limited parking.So this is great for me since this is in my 'hood. Parking is plentiful (depends on timing though) and an easy walk from Kovan mrt and bus station. I love the soup which is very tasty, and full of vegetables. The small is sufficient for 2 persons. I find the cheaper fish (garoupa?) has more bones than the pomfret, but it is more flavorful. It also has slices of yam in the soup. The prawn paste chicken wings is a must order. Just so yummy. Sambal sweet potato leaves are equally good.

rest_name: Tian Wai Tian Fish Head Steamboat
comment: Located in a coffee shop in Hougang, literally across the bus interchange, near the xin wang cafe is Tian Wai Tian Fish Head Steamboat. I normally frequent the tian wai tian at ang mo kio, but since I was going bowling at jForte my friends decided to grab dinner here on a rainy sunday night.At around 730pm, the place was packed. there was a queue to place zichar orders. All the tables were occupied and you would've to wait quite a while for an empty table. Even when we got a table, it took another 10-20 minutes before the table got cleared and cleaned. My recommendation is make a reservation, so that you have a clean table and the reserved tables are on the other side of the coffee shop which is more airy and windy. I say at the side facing the bus interchange, there wasn't much air crossflow.1. Fish head steamboatWe ordered a medium and my friends complained that they coudln't find much fish in the steamboat. There were 5 of us and yes some pieces were miniscule and some were half the size of an iphone 6S. The fish was decent, it wasn't MSG ladden as I didn't feel too thirsty after the meal. The soup was served with vegetables and seaweed. I loved the seasweed. The soup was refillable, but it is self-service.2. Prawn Paste ChickenTheir prawn paste chicken never fail to meet my expectations. I love them! They are so crispy on the exterior and juicy and tender on the inside. They aren't too oily but they sure are sinful! The chicken wings are also pretty plump. 3. Egg FuyongThe egg was pretty oily but they were generous with the ingredients, lots of prawns, carrots and some meat in the egg. The aroma of the egg was pleasant and even though we ordered a small portion, it was more than enough for the 5 of us. 4. Salted egg porkThis was the only disappointing dish we ordered. The pork was dry and I could barely taste the salted egg. The salted egg was also barely visible on the pork. Skip this dish5. Sambal Kang KongThis was drenched in oil! I ended up washing the kang kong in a bowl of fish soup before eating it as there was just too much sambal oil on the vegetables.For 5 of us, we paid $79, at $16 per pax, our tummies are filled with zi char food and we were all satisfied. But I'll definitely go for sweet and sour pork rather than salted egg pork the next time round.Overall : don't expect any service, since you're not pay any service charge or GST, make a reservation before heading down, and do give the fish head steamboat a try.

Protip: - Highly recommend the Ribs and Roasted Cauliflower. - With the Burpple app, you can get a BOGO main entree. - Each physical location of Meatsmith has a unique flavor.I originally heard about Meatsmith from a close friend who fanatically loves Meatsmith, particularly the Little India location.  So after the 3rd annoying time he brought it up, I decided to finally give it a try. NOW, I'm fanatically tell you about it now.. hahaha.. Typically, when trying out a new restaurant, I ask the waiter what's the most popular and order those. They recommended the Ribs and Roasted Cauliflower. Oh man, it definitely hit the spot.  For the ribs, they were literally tender fall off the bone, the way real ribs are intended.  For Roasted Cauliflower, never was really a fan before, but after trying this for the first time it opened my world and now i'm try to figure out how can i make this at home. Once you try it, you'll know why. The ambience is more of an informal bar type setting. It's great for casual eating with friends but not so much a date spot. The only spot available for us was the bar stools overlooking the street.  While Meatsmith does have multiple restaurants, each location has a unique focus on the local flavor.

Meh, I have had better sums it up.Meat was done well.$30 plus for 3 small lamb chops.  Good if you are here for beer and tapas, not good if you are looking to eat.  The platter for one was tasty but underwhelming.
Great food and super flavorful!! fun ambience too theres an upstairs seating area with a bar

Fantastic eatery with unique flavors; spicy and different probably the best experience we had from Singapore. Well prepared with top-motivated kitchen and staff. Experimental kitchen; so innovative and exciting, that we had to visit the restaurant three times. We had Coconut Chutney Pork Ribs, Date Glazzed Beef Rib, Bambay Butter Naan, Gren Mango Slaw and Gun Powder Potatoes also do not mis the nice and cosy bar on the upper floor.

Unpretentious kopi tiam location but definitely a crowd favourite from its long lines every day. It has an extensive menu and unlike most western stalls in food courts and hawker centres, this is really good and is reminiscent of the olden day coffee houses like The Silver Spoon, Red House etc. If only there's air conditioning to make dining in more pleasant

address: 18 Toa Payoh Lor 7 1913 Coffeeshop Singapore 310018 Singapore
comment: My friend told me to try this place and said it was even better than the one at Come Daily at Lorong 1 Toa Payoh. Come Daily hokkien mee has always been my favorite though I have noticed the standards have been slipping ever since the father retired and the son took over the stall. I came with another friend to try the Hokkien Mee here. It took a while (at least 10 mins) for it to be ready and we ordered right when it opened (we got there before 10 am, and waited for it to open). So I do not know how long it will take if you order during peak period. The noodle was tasty. It was not too wet or dry. My friend said she could smell the prawn stock wafting from the plate. I liked it but I was not overly wowed. Maybe no lard (or not enough lard) -- I could not remember if it was there. It lacked the umami or rich taste of a nicely fried Hokkien Mee with plenty of wok hei flavor. Still, it is a good place to try. Note:It is only opened from 10 am to 230 pm everyday except for Monday.

rest_name: Hup Chong Hakka Yong Dou Foo
address: Blk 124, Toa Payoh Lorong 1 #01-459 Singapore 310124 Singapore
comment: according to their facebook page this is their main shop.wide array of fried and non fried items to choose from.but their specialty is their homemade deep fried stuff.ngo hiang, meatballs, crispy wanton and stuffed bean curd.you cannot go wrong if you pick any of their deep fried items!it is the well seasoned minced meat that makes everything yummy.after picking your poison you need to tell them where you are sitting.no payment required until they bring your food to you.service was friendly and fast.soup is clear and tasty.chilli and sweet sauce are standard fare.

rest_name: Hup Chong Hakka Yong Dou Foo
address: Blk 124, Toa Payoh Lorong 1 #01-459 Singapore 310124 Singapore
comment: This Yong Dou Foo stall is very near to where I stay. They have just moved from Toa Payoh Blk 116 to the current location. According to my parents, there is actually another stall that is open by their relative at another part of Toa Payoh and they are selling the same Yong Dou Foo.What I like about this particular Yong Dou Foo stall is their fresh tofu item and eggplant. The tofu either fried or steam topped with meat are both very nice. They are also popular for their fried meatball. My father will usually Da Bao a pack of 10 piece of meatball for my brother for snack. They are really tasty despite being on the oily side.What I don't like about the stall is that the noodles portion are really little, and most of the time I won't be full after eating. If you ordered yours with chillies, be careful as they can be quite generous with the chillies and it can turn out too spicy.

I don't remember when it became acceptable for cafes - not restaurants mind you - to charge $6.50 for a cup of coffee or have an average brunch dish cost $17. (Brunch dishes - they're just eggs y'all!) I suppose when youngsters (and older, aka me) started turning up at cafes in droves with their laptops and staying for hours.At least with Regroup, I didn't feel too bad parting with $17 for my squid ink linguine (4 stars). For starters, it had soft shell crab in it. While the crab wasn't as delicately crispy as others I've had, the garlicky, spicy sauce was right up my alley. Typically, I feel like I order squid ink pasta more for its unique colour (I'm a sucker for green tea and pistachio flavoured items because of their gorgeous colours. Heck, I swear it was the wildly unnatural, beautiful lilac skins of yam baos [taro buns] that conned me into consuming far more of them than is probably advisable). But this time, the linguine itself seemed to be that much more flavourful. Warning: Don't eat this before an important presentation or risk looking like a toothless pirate.Tried some of my friend's truffle mushroom soup (4 stars) - it didn't taste creamy and wasn't salty. She found it a bit bland though. Also had some of her goldrush waffle (4 stars). The waffle was somewhere nicely between being soft and crispy, the dark chocolate ice cream was solid, and the honeycomb crumbs were a nice touch. The salted egg sauce was good, but it's not my thing to begin with. I had a single scoop of ice cream and the girl at the counter very nicely agreed to do 2 generous half scoops for me, making it $4 well-spent. Their pistachio (4 stars) is definitely one of the better ones I've had. The stout butterbeer (3.5 stars) had a good flavour but melted too quickly.Besides the food, I love the decor of the place (5 stars). It's spacious, brightly lit, and minimalist. They also have 3 fans going in addition to the air-conditioning - I'm guessing because the large windows make it fairly warm in the day. It was pretty empty on a weekday afternoon, and I got some studying done. Note that there's no wifi available. I see their pistachio latte, smoked salmon salad, and a good book making a perfect afternoon in my near future.

The coffee here is ok to nice. They do latte art. Flavour wise, it's on the safe side and even slightly on the bland side. But the nearest decent coffee at a walk is Wheeler's Yard but that place you'll probably have a much longer wait albeit tastier cup. 3.5 for the coffee.Waffles take quite a prominent spot on the menu but we were in the mood for some salt so we ordered the truffle fries. I have to say the fries were not very good. Firstly they are thick cut but more importantly the oil seemed a little over-used and the insides weren't fluffy..like the fries were a little old. Simple dish that a lot of places sell and make good margins on, so it was an unpleasant surprise that it was subpar.I do like the atmosphere of the place. It's laidback. Kudos for the cool stylish tap for getting your own water. Other than that, it doesn't stand out that much. It doesn't have the charm of the Duxton flagship I would say.I was there on a Sunday morning before 11am and the place was nearly empty.They don't have parking so maybe it appeals more to residents. I have a friend who stays round the corner and I actually drive by weekly but the fact is, I've only been in once..so that is saying something. If I need a coffee and can be fussed to park at my friend's condo and walk. But if I were gonna drive to drink and I'm not crunched for time, I would head over to Old Hen for a bit more life and vibe and taste.Icecream here is rich and sweet. Some almost too sweet for my taste but it's quite creamy and should please be a crowd pleaser. I'll try the waffles when I come back next time and see if it warrants an update!

Happy to find this cafe and ice cream bar just around the corner from the office. They have a small but quite good food menu as well. Some pasta dishes, salads and sandwiches to choose from. Coffee was not the best I have had, but still okay. Will come back!

Affordable Japanese Cuisine. Tasty and yummy. For the price you pay, the food portions are big. $37 for a table of 3 takes the pain away from your wallet. Nice ambience with indoor air conditioning and Al fresco lay out

Love this Thai resto out in "far flung" Changi Village!They have a photo of the King hanging on the wall, and apparently a real Thai chef at the helm. Legit enough for me.I enjoyed their Thai iced tea and the spicy basil pork with rice + fried egg. The portions were a bit off, as I had way more meat than rice, but that's just me being picky. They also say they don't use MSG, and I believe them as I didn't notice any weird side effects after! Prices for the mains were mostly under $10, very affordable. It's a small space that is slightly air-conditioned, as there's no door and it's open air. This is a great spot to stop by after you've come back from Pulau Ubin!

The basil minced meat chicken is actually nice, but the rice portion is rather small to fill a guy's stomach. Although the set meal at $8.90 is value for money with a drink and dessert. The sticky mango rice is yummy!
Love the place, tuck away from the crowd. Love their pork cake and pork basil with rice..

address: 3 Punggol Point Rd #02-07/08, Punggol Settlement Singapore 828694 Singapore
comment: Just the place ... just the place with nice view. Just the place for a good breakfast or just about anything.  Just the place with good service.Was just so unfortunate for me and my friends because when we went there, it was rented out for an event. Although they were kind enough to still accomodate us, we didn't have much time to explore their menu. We only managed to order "just platter" and their "just veges pizza".  Both tasted good. As for the price, reasonable enough.Will i come back? Definitely!

address: 3 Punggol Point Rd #02-07/08, Punggol Settlement Singapore 828694 Singapore
comment: Having breakfast by the sea front - priceless for me. I'm enjoying a morning breeze on a idyllic Sunday morning with my loved ones.I ordered a Farmer's Platter and a ice cold Mocha for myself and a traditional Egg Benedict for my wife. The Farmer's Platter had a good mixture of meat (bacon, European Sausages and beef patty) and a good albeit small toast plus a nice serving of mushroom ragout! Overall, the food was good but the beef patty could have been a little overdone. Maybe next time I would ask for the beef patty to be not overdone. The mushroom ragout was good! Slightly creamy and mushroom was just nice and soft. The Traditional Egg Benedict has a nice poached egg on top of the English Muffin. When sliced, the egg yolk was flowing down on to the muffin and it made it looked even yummier. I would recommend this place due to the sea front setting and especially when there is a cool breeze blowing towards you. Ask for the outside seats, you will not regret!

address: 3 Punggol Point Rd #02-07/08, Punggol Settlement Singapore 828694 Singapore
comment: We had dinner elsewhere and wanted to continue our conversation over desserts, so we took the stairs up and settled at Just The Place. They ran out of the cheesecake so we only had tiramisu, which was nicely presented. The lady's fingers (sponge biscuits) were over-soaked in some watery alcohol but otherwise the cream was quite good. Service was friendly. We sat outdoors and the view of the Strait of Johor was lovely at night!

i loved the original at Chnagi Office park and this is about the same but with less air conditioning.  everything that i have had is awesome!  i always get a wrap, some hummus and then another random item.  do yourself a favor and check this place out and keep going.  we are worried that they might not get as much foot traffic as they used to, and we want this place around for a long time!

Delicious home baked breads, flavourful dips and succulent meats all served with a smile. Damak will not leave you wanting. I've come here at least five times and nothing I've ordered had left me dissatisfied. Whether you are a meat lover or vegetarian, this place will leave you spoilt for choice. I highly recommended. The musaka, pide, kebabs and Turkish coffee.

I always love this place, right on the roof top of Changi Village Hotel, the food is still good but HOWEVER the service SUCKS ! That's why it get 4/5.Food are Italian, their appetitizers are the best, fresh juicy tomatoes with cheese and hams is to die for.  I dont know why they stopped serving the Bread Stick, such a shame..,  as for Mains, my fave is Ravioli, actually you can ask the kitchen to cook any style you like as long as they are not too busy.The view from the al fresco dining area is fantastic, overlooking Pulau Ubin and Pulau Tekong, with a glimpse of Johor, Malaysia in the distance.Recommend that you come at the moment they are open for dinner, ask for the al fresco area, have a drink and enjoy the view till night fall takes over, then its time to eat.Bon Appetit !!!

I'm sorry, but the service is really terrible. Half an hour after one cocktail comes in, the waitstaff will tell you that there isn't the other drink you've requested for. Iced water arrives about an hour after you're seated and should you have an extra friend come in mid way, then it's too bad. You're going to have an extra serving plate and cutlery 15 minutes before you finish your meal. But not before you request for the same items four times and then resignedly nick it off another table. Food is just ok. Sure, the crabmeat linguine is good. But Italian isn't really that complicated to execute. The Buffala pizza came drowned in cheese, so much so that the cheese pooled bathtub-like at the base, leaving the edges dry painted with tomato. The mushroom fettucine was reported to be unfresh, and the sauce gritty because the fungi hadn't been washed properly. On the upside, the ambience is nice. And especially romantic if you're looking out to the sea. Although.. While I was there, there was fighting at the nearby construction site. Which kind of adds to an ambience of a different kind. Gritty romance anyone?

I love this place! When I first stayed at this hotel in 2009, I threw a party up on the roof - a small gathering, with food, wine, drinks, etc., and I bought (or should I say catered) food from La Cantina - and it was great. I mainly ordered finger food - wings, fries, garlic bread. And they were all great.Service was stellar! One particular staff remembered me every other time I came that I felt so special - and this is after 2 years. They are polite, very professional, and very nice.I had dinner there in 2010 - and I tried their pasta - it was amazing. View was great - looking out to the sea and it was very nice. Romantic, quiet, and great place to have a  date.

address: Blk 2, Changi Village Road #01-51 Singapore 500002 Singapore
comment: Loved their goreng pisang (fried banana) compared to their neighbor Million Star Fried Banana. We bought a couple from each stall and compared them. This stall's crust was firmer and held the soft banana better without crumbling to pieces. Banana was sweeter. Must eat while piping hot.

address: 6 Tebing Lane #01-03 Punggol East Singapore 560233 Singapore
comment: My family decided to go to Uncle Leong Seafood to have dinner after cycling along punggol. It is located at the end of punggol near the new golf course and there are other restaurants there like popeyes, japanese and italian restaurant. We tried the XO crab bee hoon which had some soup in it. It was alright but the quality of the crab was no good and also it cost almost $50 for that dish! Totally not worth the price. Would like to comment on their service as well. They definitely do not know how to handle customer. Even when we requested a change in crab, their response was the rest of the crabs are all the same. We do not wish to waste our effort and time arguing with them and decided to leave shortly.Definitely will not be going there again.

address: 6 Tebing Lane #01-03 Punggol East Singapore 560233 Singapore
comment: Quite disappointing after having heard the hype. The crab beehoon has been called a signature dish but despite costing $58, was quite bland. The creamy buttered prawn at $20 was better but not much. The salted egg brinjal (egg plant) sounded interesting but wasn't. On the whole, not worth the cost.

address: 6 Tebing Lane #01-03 Punggol East Singapore 560233 Singapore
comment: Cannot make it la. Waste time q . Not worth it. Bad quality food. I think the servants were very arrogant

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close #01-32/33 Downtown East Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: This is one of my favorite place for a family gathering in the east.The tables are round & the huge kind to sit more than 10 & well equipped with baby high chairs. Ordered our food and they served us in like 5 to 8 minutes? This speed is pretty consistent throughout my many visits.The portion comes in small, medium and large sizes. You can ask for recommendation on which size is ideal depending on the number of people you have. We had mostly small dishes so we can have more varieties. We love the fish curry, fish maw soup & fried prawn rolls. Find the prawn paste chicken abit too tough to bite on. But this dish is quite welcomed by the children. Ntuc members get a 10% discount as they are located in downtown east. This promotion have been going on for years, remember to present your membership before your final payment.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close #01-32/33 Downtown East Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: I've always been a fan of Different Taste and my favourite dish of all has got to be their penang kway teow. its got the right amount of chilli and the kway teow noodles are fried perfectly. The fish head curry is also another killer dish. the fish meat is tender and its soaked up all that beautiful curry flavour. Pair that with a plate of white rice and you're all set. The ha chiong kai is also very good. as is the foo yong omelette. One fo the best zi char restaurants around.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close #01-32/33 Downtown East Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: A great place to take the family for dinner - its relaxed, the food comes out fast, and everything is tasty (as its name suggests :P).  Their dishes are all pretty good - but their hor fan, shrimp paste chicken and fish head curry are a must have for every trip that I make there.  Don't expect too much and you won't be disappointed - its really your local zhi char place in a restaurant setting, but without the service charge and gst! Plus points for that :)  Also, their sambal chilli is really really yummy too - so make sure you ask for some.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close #01-32/33 Downtown East Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: Different Taste at Downtown East has been around for the longest time, when it used to be at the Bowling Alley while the place was still called NTUC Resort. But the quality of food and even the staff has not changed much.One of the best dishes is their Prawn Omelette that has this unique fragrance to it and a crispy edge, it is definitely the best tzi char prawn omelette I have eaten. Tasty, crispy and many prawns. The hotplate tofu with Minced Meat is also fantastic with a tasty gooey sort of sauce on the hotplate combined with the oodles of minced meat some assorted vegetables and smooth tofu. The dish is definitely one to try.Their single person dishes are also great. The penang fried kway teoe has that fragrant "wok taste" while the beef kway teow has a nice sauce and is not diluted and tasteless like most places.The pricing is also extremely affordable at a tzi char price in a restaurant without Service Charge or GST. With a 10% discount for NTUC Members as well.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central Street 3 #01-22/26 White Sands Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: Pepper lunch is just good ol rice on a hot plate with meat. Simple yet tastes so good everytime I ding into a serving of it. My usual order - chicken pepper rice. Probably the most basic but to me, one of the best because its simple and it tastes good.Pour over a few spoonfuls of brown sauce and you're good to do!

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central Street 3 #01-22/26 White Sands Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: I can't remember how many times i've eaten here. Beef pepper lunch is so delicious that i order it every-time, who would have thought that rice and corn taste good together? Their soup taste good too.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central Street 3 #01-22/26 White Sands Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: Preferred to the other outlets, I don't like the energy at this pepper lunch. Probably because of the interior décor, the whole outlet seems a lot darker and less energetic and vibrant. The food tastes pretty much the same though. But of course compared to the express outlets at food courts, Pepper Lunch restaurants fare better. One thing that I still don't like is the stir-fried smell that sticks to the clothes. It gets a little stinkier when that smell is mixed with sweat. Eeeks, the thought of it!

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central Street 3 #01-22/26 White Sands Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: Pepper Lunch, one of Singapore's answer to Japanese fast food. Basically all meals are served on a hotplate which is visually appealing and most of all your food stays warm for a longer period. I usually go for the solid steak with rice which cost a little more but there are constant on-going promotions so be on the look out for deal coupons. I would say the meals here are generally very complete with a solid portion of meat, rice and vegetables. The flavor is great and additional seasoning is available on your table so you can make the necessary adjustments to suit your taste. A place that never fails to disappoint!

I absolutely love the maggie mee goreng here which has been consistent from the first day I had it. Also highly recommended is the roti prata which is fluffy and slightly crispy. I would not recommend the naan though because the flour is too thick and not that great tasting. For drinks, the consistency is sometimes lacking, especially when it is crowded.Overall, I would highly recommend this place.
Slow service and rude female staff who expresses her unhappiness loud and clearly for everyone to see and hear. Clearly not able to work under stress. Never coming back!
Great place for morning prata (1.70 SGD) and a cofffee. Covered patio seating with fans but no AC. Lots of fresh juice options. Cash only.

Excellent fare. Open 24 hrs. Try their Nasi campur and their curries are very well done. The flavours are well rounded and try their Roti John, Cheese prata, Channa, Cholley and Tom Yuk fried rice. If you are a regular here, they may oblige you by serving their food nextdoors as you visit the bar next door to it for some booze. Love the homely vibe and clueless waiters here!

From South Indian dishes to North Indian, from Malay Muslim Food to Thai Muslim Food - "We Speak Taste!"Savour the array of pure halal along the coast.Great location, great ambiance, great taste ... as they say it - "We Speak Taste"

address: 3 Punggol Point Rd 02-11, The Punggol Settlement Singapore 828694 Singapore
comment: Awesome place to relax and chill like the name suggests. Food 3/5: the truffle fries were nice and crispy but lacking in truffle. Pizza was well topped but the crust was frozen. Half and half option though at no additional cost which is niceIce cream 5/5Service 5/5

address: 83 Punggol Central, #B1-22, Waterway Point East Wing Singapore Singapore
comment: We came early on Good Friday to avoid the crowd as we are a big group of 11. The staff was quick to accommodate our request inclusive of wheelchair access.They have wide range of soup and cantonese food available. The soup tasted as you would expected from Lao Huo Tang. We had the beancurd, egg with tomato, sliced fish, fried rice, sweet and sour pork.The pricing is reasonable. We will definitely visit again. Come early to avoid the crowd.

Once upon a time, in a faraway land in the northeast of Singapore, there is Punggol 21. It used to be farmlands and housed the most wonderful seafood restaurants at the edge of the jetty. Now it has transformed into a land of highrise residential buildings, with waterways and jogging tracks.But the princess of Punggol 21 loves her food. She used to be spoilt for choice when living in the more mature neighborhoods and she feels that she is......... starving........ in... this... estate. And that would be a horrible ending to this fairy tale.So there is Cheng to the rescue. While he is not the most yummy prince around, he whips up decent dishes. Pig trotters bee hoon, steamed fish, bittergourd soup, prawn paste chicken. Now the princess can be happy when she needs a decent place to eat nearby. In a faraway land like Punggol 21, this is ok.....until the real Prince Charming appears.The end.

It's a kinda empty shop because it's at a corner of Waterway Point. However we were very satisfied with this branch's offerings. Ordered a fish n chips, the chicken pasta and crabmeat pasta. Each of the dishes were so good and we were very happy. Portions were big and price is rather reasonable. I wil definitely come back again! Many good deals around too!Great place for friends to chill out or a weekend meal with family.

Wait staff is young, but friendly. No problems there, but the restaurant was out of bread at 7pm on a Sunday. Yes, a "French" restaurant out of baguette. The waitress took our order and came back 5-minutes later to let us know the lamb shank was 86'ed. We ordered the unagi and foi gras appetizer and quickly discovered that the pairing did not work well. The entree we did manage to get was the duck confit and, although judged premade (due to the speed in which it was served), the taste was fine. Your experience may vary, but I know there is better and more authentic French food available in Singapore, just maybe not in Punggol.

Bad experience. Went for dinner with friend here a few days ago, thinking that it will be a good experience like the north point outlet which I visited before but it wasn't. We reached there around 730pm, ordered and waited until 815pm but we still don't see our food being served to us. After asking the staffs about it, they asked us to wait another 5mins more for the long table customers which came later. We left without having any dinner except a garlic toast that we ordered. The toast itself came late too. Very disappointed.

rest_name: Dim Sum Inc by Crystal Jade
comment: The latest outlet under the well known Crystal Jade chain. Easy to reach as it was located next to the LRT station. Compared to other outlets, it was considered the lower end of the chain.It offered all-day dining quick-service concept, with a compact menu ranging from Signature Hong Kong Rice Bowl, home-style specialities and popular Dim Sum to roast meats, rice and noodles. Menu was limited comparing to other outlets.Combo Set D (S$9.80++)The set consisted of Shrimp Wanton Noodle (dry/ soup) (Usual Price S$7.80++) + a choice of Drink which I selected Honey Lemon (Usual Price S$2.80++). The drink was bottle version, available off the shelf.Ordered the dry version of the noodle and it was pretty disappointing. The noodles was lumpy and had quite strong alkaline taste from the lye water. Pretty washing the noodles in the small broth that served with the noodle, but only slight improvement. The wantons were slightly more salty than preferred. Overall it was a terrible dish which was pretty different from the usual dish which was served in other outlets.Deep-Fried Mango Prawn Roll (S$3.20++/ 2pices)Although this dim sum could be found in other outlets but the version was very different from other outlets. The version here was full of mayonnaise but barely able to taste the mango in it. I would prefer the version from Crystal Jade Dining In which was full of chucky mango.Assorted Trio Har Kau (S$4.80++/ 3 pieces)The dim sum looked pretty colourful in red, orange and yellow and tasted not bad with the skin not too thick.Overall it was a disappointing meal. Different price different standard.

address: Sengkang Square #03-19/20, Compass Point Singapore 545078 Singapore
comment: Nice food in general.Must try the bbq pork buns and the roast pork belly with honey sauce.Housefly flying around, enjoying the food as well.

address: Sengkang Square #03-19/20, Compass Point Singapore 545078 Singapore
comment: The $1 soya chicken promotion is a disaster as the picture does not tally with what was served. The normal soya chicken on the menu is about $11.95 or $12.95 and as it was a promotion at $1 for minimum spend of $30 I would expect a decent plate. So please don't get scammed by them.Service by staff was excellent though and staff was embarrassed when we asked how come chicken so small when it was suppose to be a promotion for card members.

address: Sengkang Square #03-19/20, Compass Point Singapore 545078 Singapore
comment: We had roasted duck, tofu with mushrooms, beef with kailan, french beans with olive & minced pork, and double boiled chicken soup. Everything was good, perhaps the beef was a little overdone and the minced pork was a tad too fatty. Service was prompt and efficient, as always. It's a pity that the mall is closing for renovation. Hope they will reopen here!

address: 168 Punggol Field, Punggol Plz #b1-05 Singapore 820168 Singapore
comment: This sushi place is conveniently located in the neighborhood area of punggol. Once you step in the place looks nice and comfy with an open concept where you can see what the chef is preparing for you.There is also a conveyor belt with many different type of sushi and handrolls and other food available. The best thing is that the price is very affordable. If you are not too particular about having authentic japanese cuisine, this place would suit you well.The dishes i would recommend are the spider handroll, age toufu, chawamushi, ebiko sushi, salmon sushi. Their tempura soba is also not bad. I tried their ramen before but it was quite tasteless so maybe not an option to try for that. Overall, a cheap and nice place to dine in if you are looking for average sushi.

OMG, so good.Seriously, probably some of the best airport food I've had.Selator is a tiny airport,  and Mr. Teh Tarik isn't big either,  but the food portions are huge.I ordered a murtabak and roti / paratha thinking it would be small, but it was a ton of food, and it was also very tasty.See pictures....Keep in mind there's no food or drinks once you go through security, so basically you have to eat at Mr. Teh Tarik if you want something before your flight.

address: 168 Punggol Field #B1-05  Punggol Plaza Singapore 820168 Singapore
comment: This establishment has a few outlets sprouting across the island since 2002. If you are not already  familiar with them, they have 3 different dining experience, the so-called Nihon Mura Izakaya, Mihon Mura Bento Sushi and the one here, fits the Kaiten Sushi notion - conveyer belt sushi. I rarely visit any of the outlets but last week, I decided to give it a try, after all, I need to find a place for my dinner and trying to skip ALL Chinese/French foods!!  So, this one here, seems to fit the bill - a quieter dining room plus its a Japanese fare!I guess the draw is - the affordable price tag plus that promotion currently rolling out. The colour plates are going for $1 each if you ordered 3s. But strangely, they don't seem to fill up the conveyer belt, nothing has been replenished and the moving platform looks empty and cold. Weaned me from wanting to eat more, I should be happy for the reduced appetite, but at the very least, please refill the belt to make the dining room looks more "normal" when you called it "Kaiten Sushi" eatery. It appeared so pathetic and everyone will have to take the hassle to order from the menu, manually. Defeat the idea totally.If you asked, let's do a quick honest review.. before I lost that inspiration again (btw, I have always been truthful lol).The usual pick, Inari sushi - nice and soft cooked vinegar rice  plump up the fried Tofu pouch like a coin-filled money sac. These tofu skin has a subtle sweetness in them, not overly candied and it was moist and cushy. I always opt for plain ones, to get a real taste of the basics. I hardly give chance to one that are stuffed with fanciful kani or  Salmon roe.. a simple good Inari sushi is one that will make my day. And these, yes, they did somehow ... plus its a dollar for 2!? A steal.. if you are not fussy over anything.The Chawanmushi is passable though I find the taste in the custard a little too harsh in the seasoning. I like the egg custard to arrive on my table, having a balanced flavour. The mirin was found domineering the poor soy sauce fella, I didn't quite understand the sweet egg dish in the tea cup though the chicken chunks were juicy and tender. I won't need a sweet dessert in between my mains..  The chilled soba was the worst I ever tasted. The one here, served in a bamboo tray was far from meh = Meh meh meh!! AVOID!!  It looks weirdly painted in some sort of a alien green, I hope I am not loading myself with chemical paints but the critical part is, the noodle was hard, I can't match it up with the proper "al dente" term, it wasn't any close. However, I am glad that  I have less to complain on the tsuyu dipping sauce.To make it up, the Ebi and Yasai Tempura was some fresh vegetables, mostly root plants with 3 shrimps. The lotus root tempura was the most chewy and stoned, while the rest was causing less exhaustion on my jaw-muscles. They were fresh but less crisp on the fried batter. $6.90 for that stack was reasonable, given the "teaspoon-length" shrimps. Then I went on to order a plate of Sakura Ebi Age Maki, again this fall under the $1 promotion. Never mind about the  micro-tag, it won't influence my review anyhow =) I wished this fried maki has been perfect, the light batter turn out having a loud greasiness in each bite. The honeyed Sakura Ebi wasn't entirely inferior in taste, the way it looked. The maki has a mixture of  some Kani, Tamagoyaki morsels, seaweeds - very flavourful except the less favourable greasy exterior. Maybe they should properly drained them or use a blotting tissue to fight the stubborn diesel?!!? I will have a hard time considering if the plate was to cost me $3.48 at its usual. $1 for that, I will have to try to digest with a faint smile then...It's probably a good place for a weekend family session, if you are not particularly coming for the authentic flavours. The tags are smaller than most Japanese sushi outlet but think twice for those who can't accept misfired items.

address: 168 Punggol Field #B1-05  Punggol Plaza Singapore 820168 Singapore
comment: I've eaten here a bunch of times over the years and can safely say the quality has plummeted as compared to when I first opened. You can start with the strange smell when one first enters, smelt like something out of a sanitation room to me. Then you would be lead through, what I would describe as, a narrow walkway which isn't helped by the amount of stuff they pile around. The food is subpar at most and the ambience is non-existent. Moreover the open kitchen for the sushi is messy and badly organised. Never going back again that's for sure.

address: 168 Punggol Field #B1-05  Punggol Plaza Singapore 820168 Singapore
comment: This restaurant really need to do something about its dining space.  It is lacking of moving space. If patron have infant or young children, they are unable to cater for such space. As for their food and service have been getting worst. I will give a 3/10 rating.

The pork broth is pepper-based, but tastes wildly different between the one served in our order (pork rib soup & pork tenderloin slices soup) and the free refill.The one that was served was barely warm, mildly sweet and had a light hint of pepper. The pork tenderloin slices were slightly tough and chewy (overcooked or not much tenderiser used?). The refilled broth was near boiling hot, which probably enhanced the peppery taste, as it tastes a lot more spicy than the previous bowl of soup. I wish for a better consistency between the two servings.They took quite a while to serve although the restaurant was not entirely full on a Saturday lunch time.

This is the place to go to for a bowl of peppery bak kut teh in Punggol. While there isn't any ambiance at the restaurant (it's "open design"), the food served is top-notch. The soup served  is yummy and is refillable, which makes it a good deal for those who appreciate it. The meat I had was tender and juicy, and slipped off-the-bone easily. Don't be put off by the queue (to be expected when the shopping mall is new) as it moves fairly quickly.

address: 600 Ponggol Seventeenth Ave Marina Country Club Singapore 829734 Singapore
comment: Haven't had chilli crab for a long time (about 1+ years), and their chilli crab didn't disappoint! Gotten my hands dirty and cleaned all the two crabs down my stomach. Of course I shared with 2 others... Ha!The promotion tonight for the crabs was only $55. Worth the money I think!The Nai Bai was yummy, the soy sauce prawn was pretty good too. The atmosphere at the marina is lovely and cooling at night. The only thing is that Marina Country Club is a little run down and not so happening... Fri night and not many customers in the area. Anyway, overall experience is good.

address: 600 Ponggol Seventeenth Ave Marina Country Club Singapore 829734 Singapore
comment: This restaurant is situated at punggol marina towards the end of punggol and it is at the corner of the marina country club. One thing that caught my eye and made me want to dine there is the fact that i can sit at the outside of the restaurant and look at the boats and water out there.I had ordered some of the dishes and i thought their standard was not bad indeed. Their fried bee hoon was not too dry and it was full of flavour, sambal sotong had a nice spicy taste to it and the sotong was of good texture too not too rubbery of tough. Service though was nothing to comment about, the staff were pretty average in the way they handles customers and i think probably because it wasn't some fancy restaurant so they didn't bother to train their staff well. I would not drive so far in just to dine there again as i think customer service is important.

This chicken rice stall initially was low priced at $2.20 per packet and gradually increased its price to $2.50 but still is one of the most well-valued and tasty chicken rice in the neighborhood aka Pasir Ris west area. When you add rice, the meat also seems more which is a good trick for hungry people. Other than chicken rice, they do sell roasted pork which is crispy and slightly saltish. The Char Siew rice is also a good alternative or good-to-combine with other meats. It has a good bite-feel as well. Basically this stall is nothing extraordinary but it has earned high stars from me because it did so little wrong with its price, combinations and by doing the basics right.
Quiet and cosy. Service is one of the best of all KFC outlet. I love their fries as they are the one uses straight cut fries compare to all who uses shoes lace cut and taste horrible.

Ate there once and that was it. The place is disgustingly filthy and filled with bugs (flies) I was eating my fries and when I was nearing the end where I had to pour my fries out there was a FRIED FLY it was absolutely gross! I went back to the counter to complain and they gave me another pack of fries... Seriously?!?! Also I've ordered home delivery and everytime I ordered they would forget something... Most Bochup branch ever I quit KFC and just go with Popeyes...

Good variety but always very crowded. Can consider using the koufu DBS POSB app. The app allows you to cut queue by Pte ordering while searching for a table. You can pick up food when ready saving a lot of time. Most important you get 10% discount off the rates! Great innovation by koufu

A wonderful place to find food. The vibe is good. The environment is kept to its best despite the daily crowd. Being a young town, Punggol sees a lot of young families from all walks of life. Being the only plaza here, Punggol Plaza becomes the congregation point.The food here are good with a few that I would highly recommend, namely the Vegetarian stall, the Duck stall, the Fishball Noodle stall, Ban Mian stall, Hungry Jack and the Claypot stall. Please don't be mistaken that the rest of the stalls are no good. Just that cravings are different for all. I would revisit and drop a few more tips soon. If you live around the area and visit this place, I would love to hear from you too. Please do share your tips here!

address: 600 Ponggol 17 Ave #1D, Ponggol Marina Country Club Singapore 829734 Singapore
comment: Good music, but server's attitude is appalling. None attended to me. Even if it's closing in 45 minutes, I'm pretty sure it's still valid to make an order

address: 600 Ponggol 17th Avenue Marina Country Club Singapore 829734 Singapore
comment: This casual restaurant is located right at the end of punggol, at a place called punggol marina and it used to be open air before it was renovated years ago. I remember coming here to dine often as my parents loved the food here and i guess it was cheaper back then too.I visited the place again recently and ordered the usual dishes like mee goreng, kang kong, baby squid and the chilli crab which was a must have. To my disappointment, the standard had dropped drastically from last time as i remembered it. The mee goreng was rather dry and not as tasty and flavourful as before. The chilli crab also tasted average nothing fantastic but the service was a little slow though and i noticed most of the staff were either from China or Malaysia maybe that's why.The other dishes were still not too bad and i liked the baby squid, crispy and full of flavour and texture. Overall i think i would not go back as the main dishes like mee goreng were such a disappointment.

This place is a challenge to get to if you don't drive, hidden off tracks near an industrial area, flanked by many Chinese temples along the round.No rules for parking, as long as you don't block others. That's the beauty of it, you can eat in peace without worrying about parking attendant coming to book you.Food is wonderful, it's mainly "zhi char", love the flavours. Not overly done, humble service staff with smiles gives it a friendly kampong feel.Don't expect Michelin star food, but heart-warming dishes.

Beng Poh is just beside Good Year Seafood Village yet it seemed many people do not notice this zi char eatery. They serve delicious dishes and one of my favourites is their steamed shark's head with crispy chye poh in light soy sauce. They also do a better job with their garlic pork than Good Year. I feel both eateries are neck to neck with hits and misses. This place do not have aircon.

address: 83 Punggol Central #02-23, Waterway Point Singapore 828761 Singapore
comment: Great conveyor belt sushi and they just taste good! Love their chirashi don, and their 3 flavoured shrimp, salmon and scallop plate. The long lines is evidence of their value. Prepare for a minimum 30min queue during lunch and dinner hours!

address: 205 Hougang Street 21, Ground Level Heartland Kovan Mall, Singap Singapore 530205 Singapore
comment: Located at the ground flour of heartland mall. Hidden in this mall lies a small gem called the double spout café. Been here twice because it had good food. Both times I had the beef lasagne and the mixed fruit tea in a jug. The beef lasagne was quite small but it had a generous serving of cheese, tomato sauce and ground beef to make your mouth crave for more. The lasagne had potato wedges and a small serving of garden salad with it. The potato wedges is pretty average but the garden salad is very fresh!The mixed fruit tea is delightfully sweet and has loads of fresh fruits like lychee, apples, oranges and strawberries in it!!!Beef lasagne- 8/10Mixed fruit tea- 9/10

address: 205 Hougang Street 21, Ground Level Heartland Kovan Mall, Singap Singapore 530205 Singapore
comment: A nice western food option in the Kovan neighborhood. surprisingly this outlet was more crowded and had a line of people in waiting compared to the New York New York restaurant right above it. it's not the best but sufficient for a quick bite. Their lady server (who has a stud embedded in her arm) was really nice and she was very efficient in her service. She made my first experience at the cafe very pleasant.

address: 205 Hougang Street 21, Ground Level Heartland Kovan Mall, Singap Singapore 530205 Singapore
comment: This cafe is located at the ground floor of heartland mall in Kovan just outside the cold storage. It is of open concept like those modern cafes and kiosks in malls. The menu has a number of food to choose from and i think the cuisine they serve there has a mix of Chinese, western and malay.I think their food are valued for money and really quite tasty, and also they give pretty big portions of each dish. My friend had ordered the fish and chips and the fish was huge, it came along with chunky fries too, nicely fried. I had one of their aglio olio and the side dishes that came along with it were plentiful i was surprised for the price i was paying.The boss and staff there were very friendly and they really did their best to provide good service to customers. I would definitely recommend people to dine here as it is a really casual cafe and good service plus food, must try.

address: Blk 277C, Compassvale Link #01-13 (2C), Buangkok Singapore 543277 Singapore
comment: The second outlet of Wing Zone in Singapore with its grand opening on this Saturday, 30 April! The outlet is located just outside exit B out of Buangkok MRT station. A small outlet with just 3 tables inside. But there is also 2 rows of tables outside the restaurant. For me, I preferred to dine outdoor in the non aircon area with the strong fan blowing at me. Could barely feel the aircon inside. Smokin Q Flavour Fuzed 6-piece wings set ($10.95)Served with wedges and soft drink.The wings were quite dried and tough to eat.Cinnamon Maple 4-piece Tender set ($10.95)The crispy chicken tenders were served with cinnamon maple sauce separated. The set also came with wedge and soft drink.I also had a bit problem with the rest of the order.I had ordered Chicken Caesar Salad ($8.50) but was served without the chicken pieces. The serving looked much smaller when compared that the version which I had ordered before at the bugis outlet.I also ordered Brownie Bites ($4.95/ 12 pieces), but was served 6 pieces. It was served piping hot but not as moist as what I had before.Overall food was not as great as what I had at Bugis outlet before. Not sure why. Maybe the staffs here were still new and could not handle the orders. To be fair the outlet was much more busy compared to the Bugis outlet.

Walking past the outlet and saw the promotion $15 selected set meals (Japanese Wild Caught Salmon Set, Air-Flown Sirloin Steak Set, Duck Leg Confit Set, The Works Set. (Souperholic E-card users only)Decided to order the Salmon Set, but the cashier was unaware of the promotion, and asked another staff. In the end, the manager had to come and show about the entering the promotion code into the cashiering machine. Japanese Wild Caught Salmon Set ($15++)Came with choice of 2 sides which I selected Cauliflower Rice with Quinoa & Edamame and Sunny Side Up Egg. The rice was crunchy with a slight sweet taste.The salmon was dry and overcooked with the white protein visible. The set came with a choice of soup which I selected Velvety Mushroom Stroganoff which was disappointing starchy, and lacking of the mushroom earthy flavour.The set also came with a choice of drink which I selected Ice Lemon Tea which was refreshing and not too sweet.

Another soup spoon Union with 3 concepts in one. Sharing space with Joe and Dough the space is small and cosy. Food wise it's what you expect from soup spoon.  Service was ok as we went at a non peak timing. First time trying the food at salad fork though. $9.50 gets you a decent serving of salad but compared to the lawn it's a little more expensive. But the ingredients were fresh and tasty! Especially the pesto mushrooms and cauliflower rice. Even the herbed chicken breast had some interesting marinate that was garlicky and pretty addictive.
Very nice Teh and eggs are extra large so it's very worth it. But always long queue. If you can't finish the teh can also take away.

The outlet located at the shopping centre had both indoor and outdoor dine in area. Only cash payments by self service machine and NETS payments are accepted here. Wanted to order Tori Teryaki (S$5.99), but the staff keyed in Tori Toji ($6.50). One was given a pager to collect the food when it lighted up.Tori Toji ($6.50)Chicken omelette hot plate Comes with rice but where's the miso soup which online menu showed got. The heavy marinated chicken was a tab too salty but the egg was just nice, still soft.Currently there was a promotion for free maki or drink when one liked its NDP video in facebook.

address: 100 Yio Chu Kang Rd Singapore 545576 Singapore
comment: Out of 3 dishes ordered and tasted, the pepper crab dish is the best. For the customer service level, when I asked to check the weight of the crab, the waiter responded that he has given the crab to the chef. In fact my request was made within 5 minutes after the order. The waiter simply replied that "you didn't tell me earlier". I felt as if I am a customer at fault. Do not expect the finger washing water bowl will be provided, you have to ask for it as well as the chili sauce.

address: 100 Yio Chu Kang Rd Singapore 545576 Singapore
comment: Location is not closed!  The restaurant takes reservations (through Chope). Highly recommend the Butter Cream Crab and Chili Crab. Both sauces for the crabs are delicious with either steamed or fried buns. Also recommend the fried shrimp appetizer and Baby Gailan. Indoor air conditioned and outdoor seating available.

address: 100 Yio Chu Kang Rd Singapore 545576 Singapore
comment: We tried a variety of dishes and only the crab dish is ok. The rest are just...meh.Salted egg chicken - it just doesn't quite go with chicken. Better with seafood. Plus they deep fried small pieces of chicken and they come crispy and hard. Weird combination.Teochew Mee sua - when done right, this dish is one of my favorites. But this place missed it. No wok - hei taste, no seafood sweetness.Steamed scallops with garlic - done in the style of the typical steamed bamboo clams. Ok except that it is still better with bamboo clams.Kai Lan done two ways - a fashionable way to serve kai lan these days. It is better at New Ubin Seafood. Crab - $50 per kg, cheaper than Jumbo. We tried the chilli version which is decent enough and the medium Sri Lanka crab was big and meaty.Except for the crab, we didn't like any of the other dishes. Guess this is hard to warrant a second visit.

address: 100 Yio Chu Kang Rd Singapore 545576 Singapore
comment: Crab Party specializes in crab dishes. Came here because a friend had a crab craving. The price is not that cheap actually $48/kg. This is close to No Signboard's $50/kg price.  The cool thing about this place is that they have more than 30 types of cooking style for the crabs. These include Butter Cream, Black Pepper, Cold Crab, Java Indonesia Curry, Mozzarella Cheese, Taiwan Garlic White Pepper, Teochew Steamed, Vermicelli With Crab In Soup, and Salted Egg Crab.I love the salted egg and pepper one the best. The salted egg gravy isn't too dry or overly creamy. It has a nice salty sweet tinge to it and goes perfectly with the fried man tou ($1each). Way better than the chili crab. The pepper really packs a punch and is very savory. Haven't had such a great pepper crab in ages. The other dishes were so-so. I say stick to the crabs.

Located off Jalan Kayu, Savoury is a casual restaurant offering soups, salads, pastas, entrees & desserts.The interior of the restaurant is warm & cosy. Service was excellent. To top it off, NO GST! You could however leave a tip at the counter after your meal.The desserts are amazing! The waffles are one of the best I've ever had. You are spoiled for choice with a huge spread of Gelato to choose from.It was a great experience, will definitely be back here again.

address: 33 Sengkang West Ave #03-10, The Seletar Mall Singapore 797653 Singapore
comment: Usual Paradise Inn standard and this is a compliment. The food quality and taste is above many I have tried and staff is polite and helpful. Ate Sambal fried rice with fermented beans and the richness of Sambal taste seeps into every grain of rice. Not overpower and definitely for Sambal lovers.  The lettuce with fermented beans was equally nice too. It blend in very nicely with the thin sliced chilli and ginger. Awesome!  Last for tonight's meal was the tofu with seafood and pork floss. Somehow it mixes very well with the other orders providing a smooth and soft texture lingering in my mouth.

address: 3 Punggol Point Road #02-06, The Punggol Settlement Singapore 828694 Singapore
comment: Worst Thai food ever. Phad Thai was so tasteless we had to send it back. Basil pork with no basil. Extremely small serving sizes made for an unpleasant experience, only one redeeming feature, they have a semi air conditioned portion of seating, but all the establishments here have the same. For the price and considering the long drive to get here, really not worth your time or money

address: #01-64, Kovan 209 Market & Food Centre Hougang Street 21 Singapore 530209 Singapore
comment: Increased by 1 star.  The noodle is no longer soggy as previously. Char siew is still the normal type you get from normal wonton stalls but sweeter than others. With 3 wonton in the small slightly starchy soup. The amount of noodle is still the same given the price is now $3.50 at a hawker center. You can get a average wonton noodle at a shop for less than that or order in from food panda.

address: #01-64, Kovan 209 Market & Food Centre Hougang Street 21 Singapore 530209 Singapore
comment: Excellent egg noodles, very impressed with the cheap prices compared to Australia. Good cheap Chinese breakfast noodles with flavours being very vivid. Definitely recommend. Although not the best they are very good value!

address: #01-64, Kovan 209 Market & Food Centre Hougang Street 21 Singapore 530209 Singapore
comment: 1 of the best wanton noodle we ever eaten in the hawker centre. Lets not compare this with those exquisitely designed noodles in the restaurants ya.My fav line... Its only $3!
