This place is awesome.   We made reservations a few days ahead of time,and when we arrived we were shown three crappy two seater tables right next to the front door.  I was very bothered and we almost left.   however, we were dressed up and my wife was in heels so there was no way we were going to wander around looking for a replacement option at 830 at night....so we stayed and we were glad we did.The food was the best we had eaten in Singapore and the music was  equally as wonderful.   We tried the ribeye, the lobster Mac and the asparagus.   All equally wonderful and perfect. service was exceptional and if I closed my eyes, I would swear I was in NYC or San Francisco....this place is an ex-pats delight....The seafood served at the other tables all looked wonderful and we can't wait to return for another experience.This place is amazing...except for those stupid two tops next to the door!
Food was great, good place for a date, not for 3 dudes to hang out. I would go back in the future. Service was good and the seafood was fresh.

Very decent steaks and oysters. All in all, worth returning to and very enjoyable experience.   Expensive. I didnt see the bill, but with wine, oysters steak, you'll be paying upwards of 150+ per person.

Oysters are great - nice selection and served correctly.  Wine list is expansive.  Meat is high quality and prepared and served well.  Great special event place to spend with best friends and a bottle of wine!  Superb.

Luke's was good, with a rating of 3 stars for average in it's price range. To be fair, I had a cheeseburger at a place that bills itself as an "oyster bar and chop house," so I was probably not hitting their signature dish. But I'd been dying for a good cheeseburger and I was cautiously optimistic that this might finally be the place in Singapore that could deliver. With all the add ons (house-cured bacon, egg, and cheese) the price crept up to $42++, so I was hoping to be blown away. It was pretty good. My wife has more refined tastes, so I got to try the lobster pot pie and the lobster corn soup, with kale salad and creamed potatoes on the side. These dishes were all more well-suited for their wheelhouse. They were generous with the lobster, so they earned the price point. ($115 for the pie.) I'd say the winning dish was the kale. Fresh, crispy, well-tossed, and nicely seasoned. And they had some conservative but respectable draft beer (Hitachino lager).
Perfect oysters, crab cakes, tartars and very friendly personnel. Even child was happy.

Excellent oyster, fresh and crisp. Also try the tuna tartar and lobster slider. Clam chowder is also good and the naked rib eye charred on the outside is amazing. I highly recommended this place. Place is kinda small, so better make reservation.

excellent oysters indeed. good clam chowder soup as well.lobster sliders were so-so.bone-in tenderloin was waaay too peppery.this place is not kid friendly.i walked in with my kid in tow. the chef, mr travis himself, was sitting on the bar. he looked at us. and he looked away. no smile. no greetings. no 'welcome to luke's. good evening'.pffth.they gave the kids no utensils. until the very end. they should put a big sign on their website and on their door. no kids.people have told me this place has really good lobster rolls. and the lobsters are really fresh...but i dont think i'll come back.
Excellent food, but pricey stuff.  Oysters the best I've had in Singapore.  Other stuff is also very good, but again, perhaps the price to quality ratio can be better.

Chance upon this restaurant which trying to find somewhere for dinner in the cbd area over the weekend. Criteria: 1. It has to be opened (it's in the cbd & it's the weekend after all)2. Somewhere we haven't tried before3. Mid range price (approx $20/pax)Miss G's fulfilled all the above thus in we go! We ordered an Iberico Char siew rice with onsen egg and chilled Kang kong (pls note it's usually served in white rice but was changed to brown rice cos white rice is out), a chilled truffle somen with hotate and a lemon ginger whiskey highball.The portion of each main is ok but for a gentlemen with large appetite, it might not be sufficient. (Perhaps to entice one to order their yakitori or appetizers to go with?) The portion of the somen for a small eater like me was perfect.Overall taste of the food is good! The chili for the iberico char siew rice deserves a mention as it truly complements the dish by adding the extra punch and increases the appetizing quotient to the dish. The char siu can be more flavorful but it's still tender and definitely not dry. The kang kong is a tad too crunchy but still decent.The truffle somen is quite the real deal. Unlike many places where the truffle is just for a welcoming sniff and then disappears when you eat, the truffle is consistent throughout the somen, thoroughly soaked and "well-oiled". The hotate is also quite fresh but slices are rather thin.The whiskey highball does have the whiskey punch so don't play play. Overall a great discovery for us. :)

address: 25 Church St #01-03 Capital Square 3 Singapore 049482 Singapore
comment: The best restaurant in Singapore!!! Great Mediterranean food, all the dishes was perfect , the service was amazing and lovely and good vibes :-)Great for lunch , dinner or just for snacks and good wine ! (Or combination everything like us lol) Tnx for amazing night!

address: 25 Church St #01-03 Capital Square 3 Singapore 049482 Singapore
comment: Excellent Lebanese food in the heart of CBD. We had the cold mezze, lamb ouzi and mixed kefta kebabs and the muhmariyan dessert. We went here couple of months after our middle East trip and the food was very good especially by Singapore standards.

address: 25 Church St #01-03 Capital Square 3 Singapore 049482 Singapore
comment: This is short, a wonderful and relatively inexpensive place for lunch ($20). But I've been here for dinner too. Basically the best chicken kabab anywhere. Seasoned and cooked to perfection. The other thing that's perfection is the hummus but only the dinner version as the lunch version is pre made and the olive oil is on the side instead of on top. Inside temp is cool even though it's completely open to outside air. Outside obviously hot.

address: 25 Church St #01-03 Capital Square 3 Singapore 049482 Singapore
comment: Good Mediterranean food in Singapore is as rare as a Graff diamond, so it surprised me when one of my work friends recommended Kazbar for food. I've been to Kazbar many times for drinks as it's on the bar stretch and they offer the usual cheap drinking specials on the row. On two recent occasions I had dinner there and was pleasantly surprised. First, if you venture into the restaurant itself (yes beer-ed up CBD folks, the bar has a restaurant), you'll find a souq filled with day beds, tables and a mosaic-tiled bar. There's loud Middle Eastern music to fill the air and I heard there used to be belly dancers. Food wise, I had hummus, tabbouleh, kebabs, chicken wings, lamb chops, the excellent shish taouk and some ground lamb thing stuffed in some flat bread or tortillas to look like quesadillas. Every dish was quite authentic and I particularly liked the hummus and chops. I would add that portions are pretty good for the price. In all, a great find and it shows in the restaurant's longevity.

address: 25 Church St #01-03 Capital Square 3 Singapore 049482 Singapore
comment: Growing up in a Lebanese household and eating Lebanese food daily, I'll gladly rate this place 10/10. Best Lebanese food outside and probably in Lebanon. Everything ordered was exquisite and I'll defiantly come back again.

address: 25 Church St #01-03 Capital Square 3 Singapore 049482 Singapore
comment: Love Kazbar. Great business lunch and also casual dinner spot. The large fattoush salad (S$15) and mixed grill (complete with 3-lamb chops S$42) is a worthy meal for 3-diners. The last Friday evening of every month features belly dancers. Highly recommended.

This place is an insane madhouse during peak weekday lunch hours. Good luck finding a table. Best bet is to get there before 1150am or after 130pm.The fried rice stall is delish. There's plenty of outdoor seating along the road but a nice plus is they have indoor seating with AC!

This is in the same building as the better known Golden Shoe food center which is on the 2nd level. At the corner is May Hua Food Court which is 24 apparently opened 24 hours. I never dropped by so late or in the wee hours to find out. During the peak lunch period, it is crowded as is anywhere else in the CBD area. In the evening, it starts to get packed after 6+pm. Besides catering to the office workers, you also see laborers tucking into bowls piled high with rice (probably extra portion).There are a few stalls which seemed really popular - Roast meat stall in a corner facing Republic Plaza, pork soup (all kinds of pork parts - intestine, liver, meat ball, meat), ban mian, yong tau foo and Ah Heng Curry Chicken Bee Hoon Mee (main branch in Hong Lim Park).The curry chicken bee hoon mee tastes the same as the one in Hong Lim Park, with the same smokey chili sauce which is really the highlight for me. The wanton noodles is really nice with a generous serving of char siew which is caramelized at the edges. It is flavorful and not dry at all. The wanton can be better as the skin feels too thick and sticky and the filling is quite normal. The soup is definitely the wanton soup which is peppery and tasty. I see many people order the roast duck noodles too. The roast chicken is not as good and the roast pork is decent. I think the noodles is better than the rice. Another favorite is the "xiao guo mian" - mini pot noodles, which is at another corner of the food court, facing the main road. It sells prawn noodles soup (not fantastic, can skip this) and bak chor mee (minced pork noodles). I like the mini pot noodles which is actually a pretty big portion with prawns, minced meat, sliced meat, fish ball, meat ball, fish cake (so good it sells it on its own). I find that the uncle cooking it is better than the auntie.For something light, the fish soup is pretty good. The yong tau foo stall has a large variety of choices. The "cai fan" (economy rice) stall has the usual stuff which is ok but not something I particularly like unless I want rice with more veggies. The beef stew from either the Thai or is it the Vietnamese stall at the back is terrible. I think the better food is found in the main area of the food court. It is a good place for local food if you are in the area at night and you want something fast and simple. Many places (especially hawker food) in the CBD area still mainly cater to the lunch crowd.

address: 9 Raffles Place Republic Plaza #B1-06 Singapore 048619 Singapore
comment: I stumbled onto this place when I was checking out the basement food area of Republic Plaza. Being 2 pm, the office crowd has left and there were only a few stragglers left. I was told the bestsellers were the dry mee siam with assam chicken, assam laksa and ayam buah keluak set. I decided to get the dry mee siam with assam chicken though my inclination was for the ayam pongteh set. I guessed I liked to go with the recommended dishes when dining at a new place, especially when I was not sure what to order. I did not expect much as most dry mee siam I had was pretty lackluster. So I was surprised with their version. The dry mee siam packed a punch. The spices were subtly infused with the rice vermicelli and the sauce/gravy drizzled over it was full of the mee siam flavor - tangy from tamarind, lime and tau cheo (fermented beans). The only thing missing was the dried tau pok (dried bean curd) or tofu cubes. There was a small piece of shrimp and some slivers of fish cake, otherwise it was a plain dish. The assam chicken was equally good. There was a hint of smokiness in the chicken (still did not know why it would be smokey but it was all good) which was very tender and fell away from the bone easily with the fork. The gravy was not that assam-y (sour), instead it had lemongrass note to it. I think it would go better with rice than with the noodles. I would want to go back to try the other dishes. I find it rare to find places where you could actually taste the individual spices which made the dishes more aromatic and tasty. The last time I experienced that was actually in a nonya cafe in KL, Malaysia. The name of the cafe is a bit of a misnomer as the dishes are not solely peranakan. Some dishes are Penang style and the name Jonker is commonly known for Jonker Street in Malacca. Googling more, I found out the the owner's grandmothers hailed from Malacca and Penang, hence the type of food served.

*Review is for the views and heritage history only (not the restaurant)*Clifford Pier has historical significance as one of the sites of Mahatma Ghandi's ashes. On 27 March 1948 the ashes that were taken to Singapore were immersed in the sea near Clifford Pier.In addition to this rich heritage, the views from here are stunning. The walkways provide interesting flower arrangements, with expertly manicured bougainvillea and frangipani taking centre stage. The area is also dotted with water features, which make for an uplifting stroll as you soak in the sun and surrounds.After visiting the Merlion, it is recommended to keep walking towards the city centre, along the waterfront, to continue the visual experience!

We had a very nice afternoon tea here today. I did not get a chance to eat anything beforehand, and we toured Gardens by the Bay all morning into early afternoon. We arrived for the afternoon tea session, which is 3:00-5:00 PM on Saturdays. I had made a reservation about a month ago for this.The cost is 60 SGD per adult. Tea selections can be changed as pots are finished. I stuck with sencha the entire time, and my mom enjoyed the jasmine. Eric R. started with Alexandria and switched to sencha. What was highly unusual about this afternoon tea experience compared to any other I have had in London, Osaka, or the U.S. is that besides our three-tiered server with sweets and scones, there was a buffet! The buffet included many savory dishes, plus four additional stations on the sides.The server kindly gave us a tour of the entire buffet and pointed out which items had pork so my mom and I could avoid them. The center of the buffet had salads, gravlax, smoked salmon, and toppings like capers. The hot entrees included fried buns with "chili crab sauce," "black carrot cake" which is a stir-fried radish and egg dish, fried rice with vegetables, clam vermicelli noodles, Thai fried chicken wings, spring rolls, "cronuts" with masala potato, turkey rendang puffs, and Canadian salmon tarts. Another side of the buffet had soy milk and a local rose-like beverage.The stations included:1) curry chicken with paratha (roti)2) popiah (fresh vegetable wrap), kueh pie tee (fried cup with seafood stuffing), and rojak (fruit and tofu salad that one mixes together in a bowl)3) turkey roulade, stuffing, and pumpkin veloute with chestnuts4) dessert station with tiramasu, lychee yule log/roll cake, pannettone, pecan tarts, bread puddingOur three-tiered server included plain and blueberry scones with butter, clotted cream, kaya (coconut jam), and mango passion fruit jam. The middle tier had macarons, fruitcake, brown sugar coconut cakes (ondeh ondeh lamington), cassis chestnut tarts, stolen cookies, and cinnamon star cookies.We were stuffed but I joked this was my intermittent fasting triumph because I ate all of my food for the day between 3:00 and 4:30 PM! "Last call" for tea was supposed to be at 4:30 according to the menu, but we were asked at 4:50 PM if we wanted anything else, which was nice. We lounged leisurely until 5:00 PM before heading back to our hotel. Because of the wide range of dishes that represented so many cuisines, I would suggest this is a great place to "taste the world" in an afternoon tea, which is atypical (especially the buffet experience).

Came here for the afternoon tea, which begins at 3:30PM.While I appreciated the architecture and beauty of the space, the afternoon tea was barely okay. The service was lacking, as it was unattentive and they were often slow to refill tea or other items. We noticed one of the food runners consistently dropped items at incorrect tables and didn't know the seat numbers, so he had to keep asking the customers what they ordered. We noticed him walking around aimlessly and would never clear an empty teapot after dropping off a fresh pot, leaving the table very cluttered. One of the teas my husband ordered came only somewhat hot and overbrewed, as if it sat waiting for a while. The savory set was tasty but was overall pretty heavy, all pastry-based and with a spiced or curried filling. I really enjoyed the masala cruffin. Their hot sauce was definitely one of our favorite things on the table. The holiday dessert set was very heavy as well, and most were too sweet. Their Ondeh ondeh lamington was the best thing from the dessert selection, after you remove the unnecessary ball of cream from the top.Also, anything left on the table you cannot take home, unlike other afternoon tea services I've found in London and the States. Ultimately, at $55SG/person, it's a pretty steep price for just a lackluster experience.It's a good place for those with deep pockets satisfied by a bougie room with no regard for food or service.

Best Bak Chor Mee? Oh yes!I know...... dinner at Clifford Pier and you had Bak Chor Mee?!?!?!But I couldn't help it. I absolutely love Bak Chor Mee and the fact they declared it "Best" made me just want to try it more and I had absolutely no regrets.Best Bak Chor Mee ($27.00) The minute the bowl came, I knew there was something different. The Mee Pok (flat yellow noodles) looked a lot thinner. Took a bit and I was completely drawn in. The noodle was springy (QQ) and had a nice snap to it and the seasoning was mind blowing  good. The vinegar they used was so fragrant. It was slightly sweet, slightly salty and slightly pungent, without any of it over taking each other. With each bite, it felt like multiple flavours filled the inside of the mouth, building up the anticipation for the next bite. It was complex, more complex than any Bak Chor Mee I've had before yet it all very balanced. They were very generous with the ingredients as well, with a mixture of minced pork, lean pork, pork ball and pork liver. The addition of lard was always a welcome and the inclusion of small pieces of crispy flat fish just added to the umami and gave a different texture to each bite. The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the wanton. Wanton felt doughy despite looking fat and stuffed with ingredients and there was this taste of almost raw dough that lingered in mouth after eating. Apart from that hiccup, everything else was amazing. Nasi Goreng ($27.00) Nasi Goreng unfortunately was a bit of a let down. Not that it was bad, it was just very normal and well...... "hotel" standard. The rice was fluffy with a bit of spice, but it wasn't very fragrant and was more Chinese fried rice than Nasi Goreng and the fried chicken looked and  tasted a lot like it came out of a CP bag. The achar (pickled vegetables) it came with was pretty good. Not too sour and not too sweet. The star of the show had to be the satays. In all honesty, it looked like nothing much but it was good! The chicken satays were tender and you could taste the fragrant lemongrass in the marinade. The peanut sauce it came with was good too. It's a lot smoother than what you get outside yet having this almost peanut butter flavour to it. In fact, it was so good, we ended up ordering a plate of satay ($21.00 for 8 pieces. We had a mix of chicken and beef). Dining at Clifford Pier was truest and experience. The food had some hits and misses but I was overall still really good. The only thing was..... while the singer was good..... she didn't quite fit the setting. Still. And overall wonderful experience
Empty tables ... but refuse to let customers sit even though no show from people who have reserved Need to rethink customer orientation!
I have never had key lime before. I have order it before, but never truly had it until Clifford pier. Worth every penny.

Ambience - classy and cosyFood - can be betterService - goodThe restaurant is overlooking Marina Bay Sands and is situated right on the spot of the old Clifford Pier where people board the boats to go to nearby islands. Although the place has been given a new wardrobe, the stuctures still remain and feels very nostalgic!

We went here on our transit stop in Singapore and enjoyed a lovely buffet full of delicious yumminess, before our flight to Frankfurt. The hotel has a giant dining area, as well as a lounging area right beside it. Both are equally large with very high ceilings and an exquisite atmosphere. From what I have heard, the full-on buffet is not a regular happening, but on this day, there was a celebration in town (we went at the end of May), which was the partial reason for the buffet. From antipasti, to seafood, to salads, skewers, traditional rice- and noodle dishes, glazed pork belly and more; they had EVERYTHING on the menu. We were very happy with our choices.The staff was equally helpful with allergy questions and very attentive, which is also a great bonus. Can only recommend.

There are two restaurants within Fullerton Bay Hotel, so make sure you go to the correct one. The other one is called Clifford Restaurant so look out!This place is a beautiful dining hall overlooking the MBS side, with nice chandeliers, big big vases of white orchids, and soft background music playing by a live band (for dinner). It is a very, very pleasant experience to dine here. Service here is impeccable, and waitstaff are attentive and prompt.Let's come to the important bit. The food.Cuisine here is Singaporean hawker food, served with an upmarket touch. The prices here are a steep mark-up from the usual hawker fare, so be prepared to shell out some heavy dough. I came here with a companion and we started with two popiah rolls (thin crepes stuffed with turnip, prawns, egg) ($12). I had the laksa with lobster ($36), which I enjoyed, apart from it not having cockles... My grouse was that my laksa was not Instagram-worthy, with bits of chopped lobster scattered in the laksa. Come on guys, for 36 bucks++ the laksa better look good.My companion had fried snapper with brinjal/eggplant. He rated it 6/10. You have to order rice separately, which is $5 extra, but you have a choice between white and brown rice, which is freeflow. Pretty sweet. I like the brown rice option. Plus point for having healthier choices!We ended the meal with a key lime pie for him, and an ice kacang for me.The key lime pie was good, and had a good digestive crust. They were very accommodating when I mentioned I didn't want peanuts and red beans inside my ice kacang. The ice kacang differs from the hawker one - the ice is very finely blended/ground, so that it is soft and is melt-in-the-mouth, unlike the crunchy feel from the hawker ice kacang. Our bill for two came up to 200 because we had two beers and a glass of champagne (they sell Perrier Jouet by the glass ehre ($30)). If you don't drink, I think this meal is still affordable - comparable to a normal restaurant meal.Would I come back? Maybe. Definitely not getting alcohol next time!

This is an upscale "coffee Shop" in Fullerton Bay Hotel. Food is an eclectic mixof local and western. Dishes are generously portioned but average. Flavors are somewhat authentic but skewed to western tastes. We had the key lime pie and rum baba for dessert. Avoid like the plague. It was terrible. It is somewhat better than your average coffee shop in ambiance and service. But with 3 star prices, it's a place to chill out for brunch or lunch in the weekend but ultimately not a value.

You come here for the big hotel lobby ambience and the view of the Marina Bay Sands and all that. Food - not so much.We came for Sunday brunch, which featured mostly Sing/Malay stuff. They also have dim sum of sorts including some steamed stuff that is wheeled around in carts. It was all tasty enough, but really nothing special at all. And at S$48 per adult, it's expensive fare for what it is.

I brought a friend to Clifford Pier for their Sunday brunch buffet. It was SGD52 per person and offered a wide variety of local foods. It was a great way for my friend to taste a mix of all the local foods in a beautiful historical setting. There was Chicken Rice, Satay, Kway Teow, dim sum, congee, sushi, rojak, laksa, chilli crab and other delicacies. Each dish is clearly labeled (especially with ingredients so if you have any food allergies you can avoid them). They also served local desserts and ice cream. Of course you could find better quality food at specific hawker locations or restaurants, but if you dont have time to hit various locations, this was a central location allowing my friend to have small samples and go in for repeats. The buffet also doesnt have a time limit, so we were there from 11:30am till 2:30pm (when they close). I am not sure how the a la carte menu is priced, but I would go for their buffet selection based on price and quality. Worth the visit and surely a place I will bring future guests who are on a short stop and never had any of the local flavors!

I always have the impression that a restaurant located in fullerton bay hotel will probably cost a bomb and was gonna wait for a special occasion to check out the restaurant. Thanks to last year's restaurant week, I got a chance to try out this restaurant at an affordable price. The restaurant dishes out mainly french food. They do have seasonal menus and sometimes they serve fusion food at times.  I love their french onion soup, duck confit and truffle fries.  The service is really good here from the minute you sit down until you leave the restaurant. Looking for a place with good food and great view to spend your evening with your loved one, this is a place to be.
French restaurant , good taste and better service. Recommend best food even in Chinese

Had a colleague in town, and this was a nice respite after walking all the way along the Singapore River from Clarke quay MRT station. Definitely a nice place to bring visitors from out of town, as the place looks impressive, and you can show them google photos of that the Pier / area used to look like. Service is ok. Quality of food not too bad, but definitely on the pricey side. 12 sticks of satay for more than $20, and the meat on the skewers were strangely flat. The kong bak paus were pretty nice.
Only the fruit is tasty, all the food are terrible. Save your $ for something better.

Came to the Clifford Restaurant in the Fullerton Bay Hotel for a business lunch and was pleasantly surprised at how good the food was.  Smoked salmon, which I frequently find to be banal, was outstanding.  Roasted cod with wine sauce, also usually a blah menu choice, was delicious.  The lemon tart was good, but the crust was a bit thick, and the lemon custard was a bit sweet.
My favorite lunch spot in Singapore!! I still miss it (I live in the states now :'(Great happy hour deals too!

I found my favorite rolls to order:- salmon avocado for the typical sushi- spicy soy chicken for the incredible slightly spicy and a tad sweet sauce. The chicken could be more tender but the sauce helps to make any hard bits palatable. Rolls which I want to try but have not- seaweed salad- garlic king prawns- calamariI like how this place runs like clockwork. The line may be long but it moves very quickly, so don't be put off by that. I usually get it to go as the place is too small for dining in, plus the tables are usually taken.While waiting in line, stare at the big poster board on the wall to think of what to order. Once you get to the display cases, you will need to tell them what you want. A bit hard to try looking at the actual rolls at the two display cases and then tell them as you do not want to hold up the lunch crowd line. Tell them how many rolls you are getting first so they can get the correct size box for you. And say yes when asked if you want them cut (sliced) unless you like to hold it in your fist and eat it like a wrap.

Sushi by the roll. The menu consists out of more than 20 different sushi roll combinations, mixes of vegi, meat or fish. Prices range between 2,6 till 3S$ and each roll is cut into 4 pieces. The sushi is really fresh and in the evening after 6pm it is happy hour: buy 2, get 1 free. It is a great place for fresh and tasty sushi, but you only find the classic maki, no other types are served here.

I'm pretty divided on Aussie Roll. The concept is great in theory, but it fell short on the quality-to-value scale. Aussie Roll basically caters to the average, rushed office employee who needs a quick lunch that's fuss free, inexpensive and portable. For those who don't like raw food, would like more protein and dislike vegetables, the cooked meat rolls *look* delicious and helpings are generous compared to say SSB, your average supermarket sushi roll or the mass market restaurant chains. It's relatively cheap too. So basically these are tummy fillers for the rushed.What I didn't like about the food was  that there wasn't much effort put into the flavors and it felt like I was eating a soulless, mass produced roll. If you've had some of the fast fusion food coming out the food truck scene in the U.S (mind you, I dislike making cross country comparisons but this felt especially relevant) for example, a bulgogi sub or taco cone can still taste excellent if you had each of the ingredients on it's own. That wasn't the case here with the rolls as a whole or with the ingredients pieced apart, which is what I ended up doing when I realized it was going to be a chore to finish my lunch.I had the beef bulgogi, teriyaki chicken, spicy prawn and salmon avocado. First thing that hit me was the rice was pretty bland, coarse and slap dashed together. Even for a supermarket sushi type chain, this seemed like a big flaw to me because 50% of sushi is the rice and you're serving it to Asians. The meats weren't great either - the beef bulgogi was tough and crumbly, that and the teriyaki chicken was too salty. The seaweed, was you guessed it, soft and rather tasteless.To save the day though, the aunties manning the counter were really funny when I asked them for recommendations. I can't reproduce our politically incorrect conversation but they were hilarious. Bottom line, Aussie Roll probably works for some and will last awhile because it serves the perfect market in Raffles Place.

Craving quick takeaway sushi you can eat at your desk? Bored of staring at sushi conveyor belts? Get a quick fix at Aussie Roll,  right in the heart of CBD. This review is going to be simple.  Aussie Roll has a great appeal. The queue is long during lunch peak hours but it moves really quickly.  The 3 or 4 service personnel there have a good system going. There's a huge variety of sushi to choose from. Its listed on a wall inside which you can stare at while waiting in line -  another great idea! A few of my select favourite include the king prawn variations and calamari sushi! All really tasty. Choosing a particular 'roll'  of sushi gets you 4 pieces each and my normal meal consists of 2 to 3 rolls on average. By all means have more if you can. Soy sauce and wasabi takeaway sachets are also available just right after you are done paying. Almost production line like,  but if it works it works! Did I mention how affordable it is? At $2.60 to $3.20 for each roll,  you would hardly ever spend more than $12 here. Which is great for that much sushi. They are not stingy either in terms of how packed each roll is. Apparently the rolls go at 2 for 1 after 6pm, so hey,  pop over for dinner too if you are in the area. A much recommended fuss free joint if you want some no frills sushi and if you aren't too particular about sushi in general. This gets my stamp of approval.

I think this place has a great concept, but compared to Maki-San at Dhoby Ghaut, Aussie Roll falls short.The Good:- Each roll is around $2.40-$2.80 so relatively cheap. Plus, after 6:00 PM they do a buy 2 get one free deal. Perfect for those after workout quick fix.- The rolls can be cut into four slices or eaten like a handroll.- Unlimited supply of wasabi, soy sauce, and utensils. There's also a sink for you to wash your hands! Ginger and mayo do cost extra though.The Bad:- There's no alternative healthy options, ie brown rice. If you're a health nut, then I think you'll be limited to very few options.- The queue can be relatively long during lunch hours.A great, cost-effective option for fake sushi lovers like myself!

Aussie Roll is absolutely fantastic! They have cheap sushi rolls of a huge variety of flavours - beats the other big sushi chains around the area hands down! They have fillings such as teriyaki chicken, bulgolgi beef, soft shell crab, and also the traditional tuna, salmon and vegetarian options.  As everything is prepared already, the line although quite long at lunch time moves very quickly, and you can either eat the entire roll as it is, or have the servers cut it up into smaller pieces for you. Also love how they leave the packets of soy sauce and wasabi outside for you to help yourself, so you don't have to keep going back to the counter to ask for more, and also give you a packet of tissues with your purchase. Very classy. I always forget to bring a packet of tissues with me when I'm out for lunch so it comes in very handy indeed!Also, they have a buy 2 get 1 free promotion every day after 6.30 or 7pm (can't remember exactly) - but it's a great deal so if you are still around raffles place at that time, drop by to pick them up!

I'm kind of in between and 3 and 4 on this - I wish they put more veggies together with the meat, the balance isn't quite there. Also, the sushi rice is really just mashed together rice "paste" almost, kind of what you'd expect from machines/not very good rice. That being said, it's pretty cheap, so I guess I shouldn't complain so much.Good "happy hour" deals! M-F 6pm onwards, buy 2 rolls get 1 free! Woohoo :) Each roll is around $2.60-$2.80, and they cut it into 4 for you if you say yes to cutting.I had:1. Spicy soy chicken - ratio of meat to flavour was not quite there - a bit lacking in flavour given how chunky the meat was! Eaten with the sushi rice, it became a bit bland overall. Good meat though.2. Korean BBQ beef - pretty good! The second piece started tasting a little salty though.. Which made me actually eat the rice to balance it out. Nice that there was a bit of lettuce and some cucumber to add crunch3. Korean spicy pork - I think this was my favourite! At first I liked the beef, then on my second piece (I ate 2 pcs of each roll) that started getting a bit too salty. So this one had the best balance of flavours. Wasn't that spicy to me, but I have pretty high tolerance for spice.They also have your more normal rolls like cream cheese salmon, salmon avocado, seaweed salad (for vegetarians), deep-fried sweet potato, lobster salad (pity there weren't any left!) and all types of breaded seafood (I was trying to steer clear of deep fried stuff).
Delicious cheap sushi. Trust me you have nothing to lose! The chicken avocado roll and spicy soy chicken roll were phenomenal!
Good sushi, quick service, always busy, inexpensive.  Been numerous times.  The pepper chicken is pretty yum!!!

address: 50 Market Street #01-14A Golden Shoe Carpark Singapore 048940 Singapore
comment: With so many salad or "healthy" food places to choose in the CBD area, it can get a bit confusing and daunting to the uninitiated. They look similar and taste about the same, so how do you differentiate them?After trying a few places, I realize I very much prefer Platypus Gourmet2Go in Golden Shoe mall area. It is near another salad place "the Salad Corner" which has a queue as it has very good pricing there. I like Platypus for its simple way of ordering which is pretty straight forward. There are 3 types of lunch boxes here- Balanced: 1 protein + 1 veg + 1 carb + 1 topping + dressing- High protein: 2 protein + 1 veg + 1 topping + dressing- High carb: Errr I think that is max carb + veg + topping + dressingYou can also add extra protein or carb or anything to any of the box or create your own. Add soup (changes daily and can be sold out before 1pm if it is popular) and drink to complete your meal. There are at least 6 types of proteins (fish, pork, chicken cooked in different styles) to choose from and 3 types of carbs (potato, pasta or rice). Toppings are the different type of nuts (walnuts, almonds) or dried fruits (raisins, cranberries). You can also choose to have corn or beans in your salad. I find these do change frequently, so it depend on what is available that day. The food is fresh and I love the poached salmon which is done to perfection. It is not hard or dry at all. The cheesy chicken is also wonderful, especially if you like cheese. It is filling and the price is $7.50 to $8.50 for a box, making it quite economical compared to other salad places with similar quality. Actually I think this fills me up better than the other places which seemed to be all vegs and less protein and carb.

address: 17 Philip St #01-01/02, Grand Building Singapore 048695 Singapore
comment: All the dishes are delicate and subtle flavor. It balances out other Singaporean food.Crabs and fish both are very fresh. As you may know, if seafood is fresh, Chinese always steam it. Braised Goose is one of signature dishes in Chao Zhao cuisine. It very good. Must order!Stir-Fried Yucca is very tasty. Stir-Fried Flat rice noodles is very good, they added minced dried daikon, that reminds me of Hakka food. Only one thing is not too good in here, they have very good business, lots of people here and it's very noisy.

address: 17 Philip St #01-01/02, Grand Building Singapore 048695 Singapore
comment: The only place bustling in an otherwise empty Raffles Place. We had the Chinese New Year Menu and to my wonderful surprise, the food standard didn't drop; every dish was good! We had Teochew yusheng first, that was rather different. Like a salad really, with abalone and a sweet sour plum sauce. Very appetising. Second dish was fish maw soup with crab. Filled with maw and crab, barely any starchy soup, it was warming and comforting with some black vinegar and cilantro. Third dish was whole roasted suckling piglet. The skin was wonderfully crispy and there was very little fat. If I can best describe, you don't feel guilty to eat this at all. Fourth dish was steamed pomfret. The big fish was just so succulent and steamed just done. This is an achievement because steamed fish is hard to get it right, much less a big fish. The soup was flavourful with a sourish tang. Fifth dish was steamed prawn. This was the only let down. Prawns are super fresh but probably a few minutes overdone so the meat was a little tough. Sixth dish is my absolute favourite. Yellow chives stir fried with scallops. There's a wonderful smokey flavour that was the result of using copious amounts of fried ti po (I believe it's dried pollack fish fillet). I liked the vegetables more than the scallops. Last savoury dish is fried mee Sua. I hoped for their signature kway teow but luckily this didn't let us down as well. Good carbo filler.  Dessert was orh nee with a twist - a whole steamed mandarin orange that was mashed into the yam paste. They were a little stingy with the portion though. We could get at best a couple of tablespoons per person. But it was tasty good. Maybe it was a good thing not to have too much of this sinful thing.

address: 17 Philip St #01-01/02, Grand Building Singapore 048695 Singapore
comment: They just moved here from Beach Road where they had been located for years.Good Teochew (one of the Chinese dialects) food.Cold dish - prawn roll (good), liver roll (good) and jellyfish (better than most and even better than some of them served at good class restaurants)Suckling pig - has always been good until today; was tasteless although texture is good; missing something but I can't figure out what it isMustard vegetables with soup base - goodYellow chives with prawns - very fresh prawns, goodOyster pancake - oysters are yummy, texture is good but I just don't like the starch although there is very littleRadish (vegetable) flat rice noodles - not bad but not as good as before and a little oilyWater chestnut pancake - not bad but not my favourite (a bit like muah chee but not as nice)Yam Paste - good, smooth, not too sweetThey have icing coated Yam and crispy noodles (with vinegar or glucose powder) - didn't have this today but I prefer these to the water chestnut pancake

address: 9 Raffles Place #B1-03A, Republic Plaza Singapore 048619 Singapore
comment: Stop over artisan pasta, on the basement Floor of republic plaza is a small take out pasta bar where you eat fresh western pasta. The menu is limited to 6 sauces which you may take with either fusilli or tagliatelle. I took a regular chicken ragu, which tasted nice. You can taste that is freshly made, with chicken and a lot of vegetables. The portion regular is not that big, but I am a small eater, so it was more than enough.

Prices are not cheap, felt that only the meat were probably a little bit special, the sides such as veg and rice etc were normal. Got this because of the hype queue during every lunch hour. Wouldn't go back actually.

Ordered the chicken bowl ($16)When i arrived at dinner time on Sunday, the store was pretty empty and almost all the food had ran out. So i had to go with food i didn't really want as they had ran out of the ones i wanted. Portion was quite small and for $16 i think they would serve more protein and sides. I was still hungry after my meal. Also, the staff was pretty unresponsive and unhealthily for a first timer. Food tasted pretty good and home cooked and healthy.
Soba + tuna + beets & carrots + bean sprouts & cucumbers + snap peas ($16) - 2.5 starsI like the idea but it is pretty pricey and everything was too salty unfortunately! Not terribly impressed.

They started the hype and it's probably here to stay. Still one of my favourite go to spots for a healthier lunch option offering a good selection of restaurant level selections for you to mix and match. With the likes of Daily Cut right around the corner though, I would only wish they could lower their price just a bit to contend with the almost negligible difference in quality.

Grain Traders makes for a clean and healthy lunch, but the price prevents it from being an everyday go-to meal like Chipotle can be. The system is pretty simple and it's very well explained. You can choose a ready-made bowl or customize your own with a grain, a protein, one hot veggie and one hot or two cold veggies, toppings, and a dressing/sauce. The gains were very healthy options such as quinoa, brown rice, soba noodles, etc. The proteins all looked very appetizing with options such as sous vide salmon, seared tuna, slow-roasted pork, roasted chicken and a medium-grilled steak. The combo I chose was bulgur wheat, sous vide salmon, grilled beets and carrots, charred veggies, topped with furikake and a miso caramel sauce. Delish! Too bad the portion of protein was quite small though, and I was hungry around 3-4 hours later.You can't really go wrong with what you order, but S$16nett a pop makes it difficult to eat here everyday. However, it's definitely a healthier yet tasty option and could also work for dinner.

This is the "chipotle" of bowls.  Lots of choices for people seeking low carb, high protein and veggie dining option. My review will focus on these options. $16 gets you quinoa or salad as a base. Several low fat protein including salmon, tuna, and lentil.  About a dozen cold and hot veggie options.Perfect for after a workout.

My newfound love! Healthy slow-cooked meal made fast in the form of westernized mixed rice with price fixed at $16 nett for each bowl. Add-ons are available with prices from $1.5-$3.Choose your grains, meats, veggies, sauce and toppings! My fave combo is brown rice, salmon, mushroom, beans, pumpkins and cucumbers with miso caramel sauce and furikake as toppings. Really delicious meal for lunch & dinner. Generous portion and extremely filling!!!! The place is so spacious as well. You can have your coffee too supplied by Papa Palheta what a nice collab!This branch operates on weekend too!I've been back 3 times in 2 days. :D

As a Singapore first timer, it was in Important for me to track down and devour some world famous Chili Crab. I did some research and had a few places on my list, but being a first timer and wanting the best possible experience I chose Palm Beach so I could enjoy my meal with a view. It's perfectly situated across the bay from Marina Bay Sands, and right next to Merlion Park. The views were spectacular, and even got to see the Marina Bay Sands light show twice while dining, incredible. Food wise I ordered what I came for, Chili Crab along with some Palm Beach Noodles and a Mango Breeze Cocktail. When they bring out  plastic gloves, wet naps, and a bib - that should be a warning for the carnage to come.. this meal was the messiest experience of my life. It was a fight for each morsel of meat, but once I got my bites in I was not disappointed. The noodles were also delish but heed my warning - the portions are no joke. The small would feed 3 people.I ate alone, and was served a meal for 4, at a price for 4. Overall pretty good. If I paid $50 I would give it 5 stars but for one person it was incredibly overpriced and under eaten.

Palm beach seafood has been in busines for over fifty years and is a great choice if you are looking for eating some classic Singapore seafood dishes like the chili crab. The restaurant has both indoor and out door seating. I would recommend grabbing a seat outside if you can as the view of the Marina and MBS is really great. The price can get quite expensive especially if you order the crab dishes. The food quality is good and you won't be disappointed with the food. Food: 4 starsEnvironment: 4 starsService: 3.5 starsValue: 3.5 starsOverall: 4 starsRecommendations: chili crab, fried rice, fried almond prawns, white pepper crabI came here for a work function and had the good furtive of being able to try the white pepper, black pepper and chili crabs. I was too busy eating the white pepper crab to take a picture and that is an indication to me that it was my favorite of the three. However, they were all pretty good and this is one of the better chili crabs I have had in Singapore. It is definitely better than no signboard or red house for chili crab. The other dishes were all really good and I liked pretty much everything that was ordered. The fried rice is superb, the prawn and vermicilli soup was also really nice.  Definitely a place to go for a seafood meal if you are in Singapore.

One of the more worthwhile "splurge" meals in Singapore.  If you get a seat outside around 8pm you will have a nice view of the light show at the marina.  We got 1x black pepper crab and 1x crab a la singapura.   They were around 1.6kg each and cost ~130 USD each.  The black pepper crab was really good and personally I prefer it over the more popular chili crab.   The singapura crab is this weird grilled cheesy buttery thing that was good but for most people I think going with 1 chili crab and 1 black pepper crab would be the way to go. My advice is just get two crabs and no rice or sides.  Eat the crabs here and if you are still hungry there are tons of restaurants and hawker stalls nearby to try other food.

Came here specifically for the chili crab and left loving the pepper crab even more. I have no basis of comparison to other dishes of Singaporean fame, but Palm's chili crab and pepper crab were absolutely phenomenal. The crab was of the highest quality and cooked to perfection, not to mention the ginormous size of 'em. The chili "sauce" was super flavorful; I wish I could've boxed it up and tossed it with some pasta. The pepper crab also deserves its glory as well. The flavor was quite pronounced from the locally sourced pepper. The downside was the price, but when in Rome (Singapore), am I right?I would suggest only sitting outside, where there are beautiful views of the Lion fountain, the water, and Marina Bay Sands. The inside is nothing to write home about.

Really disappointed with the service at this restaurant. Reserved a table for Valentine's Day dinner. The restaurant seemed to overbook itself and was unable to handle being at full capacity. Our servers, although very nice and friendly, were so busy they forgot about us completely.Food wise: Mango cocktail was nice, Asparagus scallop was good, Half crispy duck was great. Fried squid was not good at all. Three stars because the food wasn't overall bad. The experience: We were initially sat down at a dirty table. After it was cleaned, we sat there looking around for someone to help us, when were finally served water. The waiter who seemed like the outdoor seating Manager - again very nice but took our order and rushed away quickly. We got our food and didn't like the fried squid at all (very chewy and too sweet). However, no one attended to us at all and so we never had the chance to tell anyone it wasn't satisfactory. We then waited and waited and finally flagged down someone to get water re fills. Our table was never cleared and no one came by to ask us how we were doing at all. By the end of the dinner, we were so fed up that we just flagged down someone for the check and left. I was disappointed that we paid a lot of money for what we thought was a Michelin star level restaurant. I would not recommend this restaurant. However one plus was the gorgeous river and Marina Bay Sands view! And again staff was very nice but there needs to be some retraining on service and add more staff to handle the busy nights!

Good location at Merlion Park , Have Dinner with Family at weekend and nice service when get into here.Server kindly offer Apron for you to protect any stain when eating Crab.Order the Chili Crab as friends recommend mostly about this restaurant. Satay by assorted meat is tender , juicy with 2 different sauce . Grilled Garlic Scallop with Asparagus was tasty. The only complaint was from Grilled Water spinach, it is over Salty . Too much grease.Seafood fried rice is ok with lots variety inside.For sure will be back next time when trip to Merlion Park in the near future.

Good Chili Crab. Pretty mild in spice level. The fried buns were some of the best I tasted. Fried golden crisp with a nice level of sweetness and soft in the middle. Could have been dessert with a sweet sauce in the side. The chicken satay was good and so often it is SG. Overall an enjoyable meal.

Not the best chili crab and the crab was very big. Meat was super flaky and the gravy just lacked the flavor profile i was looking for. It had a very subtle tomato flavor but lacked the sweetness and acidity that tomato sauce has. There also wasnt much spice to it like what? Also the crab meat was definitely not worth the price. The meat came out in flaky bits and lacked the characteristic sweetness that good crab has. They at least had the mantou but since the AC runs very high in the restaurant the food becomes cold very fast. What a shame. I have had better at mellbem and engseng. If you are looking for good chili crab i would either recommend you give this place a pass or you consider making sure the crab they choose is a little smaller. Restaurant also has an odd off seafood smell at least that is what i can tell.

One of the long established names associated with Singapore's chilli crab. They've since expanded to more branches from its first at Kallang. This is where I bring overseas visitors, with its large tanks of swimming fish, crabs and lobsters.

Man, there were so many Koreans eating here that I thought I walked into a Korean restaurant! I guess we know where to congregate when we find good food!We didn't make a reservation and were lucky to get an outdoor seat on a weekday night. We ordered....chili crabs and golden almond prawns. Surprise! Both had excellent flavors.Yeah...it's a tourist trap but at least the food was good that I didn't mind paying a little more. Service was attentive and accommodating.

Everyone comes here for the view and crab dishes.. there's a reason why. The chili crab was decadent and perfectly seasoned. We also had razor clams and the calamari. Would not recommend the calamari as it was a bit too sweet for dinner. The razor clams were steamed to perfection and the sauce was a well balanced sweet and savory. I would like to come back to try the pepper crab! It looked less messy to eat.

Reserved last minute, so was not able to get any outdoor seating. The outdoor seat view from what I can tell is spectacular. Ordered pepper crab and chili crab. Love them both. Fried baby octopus is yum. Taro roots desert is lightly sweet and smooth. Love the texture.
Love the food and atmosphere. Make a reservation for outside around 8pm or 9pm so you can see the lasershow. Crabs are good. I really loved the almond cereal prawns.

After years of eating at Jumbo - I finally said, "man I need a change".So I opted to give this place a shot after some folks were hyperventilating on the internet about how amazing their chili crab was.Alrighty then ..Well, news flash - I personally didn't think the chili crab here was better than Jumbo.  I thought the flavor was a bit too sweet and the crab was just okay.  The price was also pretty expensive, which is to be expected.  The only problem here was the shell of the crab was very thick/heavy compared to what I get at Jumbo ... since these crabs are priced by weight, I felt like I paid a lot more just for a crab with thicker shells but the same amount of meat as in Jumbo.As for the other dishes, the kankung belachan was fine, and the fried mantous were fine and fit the chili crab sauce just fine.  The so-called "addictive" fried squid appetizer was okay but also not as awesome as it was billed by some overzealous internet fans.The experience was fine, and this is a convenient location if you're staying by MBS or any of the hotels in the area.  But personally I think you're still better off going to Clark Quay (or the East Coast) to grab dinner at Jumbo.  The one exception to that is if you're really itching for signature Singaporean seafood right by the Merlion or near the MBS area.

Our family of four came here for Christmas dinner on the recommendation of our concierge and we were disappointed. After being seated we waited over 20 minutes for someone to acknowledge us before my husband finally went over to ask the hostess if someone could take our order.  The food was mediocre at best. The duck was dry, the crab did not taste good. The seafood rice was the best dish, it was flavorful. Our waiter did not check on us at all throughout the meal, no plates were cleared. No one asked how things were or if we needed anything else. Every time we needed something we had to flag down someone who was walking by. The meal was almost $400 and they had the audacity to add $3.20 to the tab for the wet wipes they left on the table.  This is a high end restaurant? I would not recommend this place. Poor service, meh food, petty extra charges.

Very bad experience, chilli crab was cold, tasted really salty and way over priced.  I had much better experience at any other chilli crab restaurants in Singapore.It is a tourist trap, stay away and eat elsewhere!!!

My husband was very excited to introduce me to Chili crab as he had been to Singapore several times on business and had enjoyed the dish at several locales. Our concierge at Intercontinental had recommended Palm Beach as a higher end place with an easier commute in comparison to the places on the east coast. The view was great but our experience after that was not. There was first confusion with our drink order, which was not a big deal except that our drink server took the incorrect drink that I had already tasted and gave it to a guest two tables down. We ordered the chili crab at $160 Singapore dollars, the buns and two side dishes. The flavor of the sauce was tasty but there was almost no meat in the legs and the claw that I had was empty. There was a hole in the side of the claw and no meat in it. The other claw had meat that my husband shared with me. If I am lucky enough to return to Singapore, chili crab will not be on my list of must haves.

Definitely a nice upscale option for Chili/Black Pepper Crab, Palm Beach Seafood has a long checkered history, but feels right at home in its swanky digs by the Fullerton Hotel.  The outdoor seating in particular is stunning with the Bay and MBS in the background, especially during sunset,  The Chili Crab is also quite tasty as it is massive and I like the fact that they are generous with the rolls. The appetizer platter, while decent, didn't wow.  The fired rice was tasty but a bit too salty.  And Service outdoors can be slow.   So while Palm Beach Seafood isn't perfect, I still prefer the location and atmosphere to the zoo at Jumbo and in Clarke Quay.  Definitely a good option, for visitors and locals alike!

I don't typically like crab, it's often too fishy and a lot of work for not much reward in my view. But Palm Beach Seafood's chili crab really rocked! It is a huge serving, covered in delicious chili sauce and served with yummy little bread rolls that you dip in the sauce. Order some rice too.We started our meal with a tower of fresh fruit. Our waitress was a little confused, but it was a great start to a yummy lunch.

This was was first time trying the famous chili crab in Singapore.  The crab and fried rice, countered by the fresh seasoned greens was excellent.  For those of you with OCD for cleanliness, you'll need to get over that quickly with the chili crab -- it's worth it! Great location and view looking at The Sands.

Yes.  It's a great location, yes, it's good food.It's sort of pricey, so it'd better be that way. If you opt for that kind of food and restaurant, I think nevertheless the atmosphere at Clarke Quay is more appealing, though it lacks the admittedly beautiful sight of the marina bay sands light show.

Jumbo is still my go-to restaurant for friends and family who are first-time visitors looking to try chili crab.  But for those who've already experienced Jumbo and want something a little different, we head to Palm Beach.I would say Palm Beach is the more upscale version of Jumbo. The location is pretty sweet; it's near the Fullerton Bay Hotel and has a great view of Marina Bay Sands. If you go for dinner, I would definitely recommend sitting outside as MBS at night is such a beautiful backdrop. In terms of dress code, I'd say it's casual, but if you want to err on the side of caution, then a black smart casual outfit would do. (I mean, you'll be eating messy crab, after all!)Get your "That's what she said" line ready because let me tell you: the Sri Lankan crabs they serve are HUGE. We're talkin' 2 kg behemoths, with claws the size of a child's face. You'll definitely pay for it; the market rate was $80/kg the last time we went.Both the chili crab and pepper crab are delicious; I guess if I had to choose a favourite, I'd go with the pepper. But by all means, definitely try the chili so you can compare and write an educated Yelp review! For sides, I've had the kai lan and seafood fried rice; both good but not anything to Yelp about. I'd definitely save room for dessert though, as their fresh fruit platter is refreshing and the perfect palate cleanser. If you're dining with guests who don't live in Asia, it's even better; it's a great way to introduce delicious Asian fruits like jackfruit, durian, and mangosteen, produce that can be difficult to find outside Asia.After you're done, walk off some of that crab by strolling along Marina Bay and snapping some shots in front of the famous Merlion!

I've never received such awful service! We waited 30m for them to give us our table (we had a reservation), and then we had to wait another 30m for the waiters to ask us for drinks. After about an hour of waiting we had to signal a waitress to come and take our order and as she was going around the table she left! The waitress left our table and we had to call her back to finish writing down our orders. The food was lackluster as the meat was tough and bland. The rice came in cold with almost no flavor. My children will be visiting Singapore soon, I will tell them to avoid this waste of a view!

A good and reliable restaurant! 4 stars. Here's why:Food -- quite good variety. Our party comprised of a meat eater, a low carbs and no seafood eater, and a pescetarian. They catered really well for all of us - and amazingly as a share arrangement. I personally loved the fragrant tofu and the dried fish chips. Wine -- good variety. They also checked the temperature of the wine (always a good sign especially in Singapore). Service -- really quite good. I was very happy with the service. Helpful and polite but not in your face. Decor -- we sat inside which was pleasant. Outside was great, with amazing views of the river. Acoustics -- very good. A friendly buzz but we could easily hear and talk.

The Chili crab here was much tastier than jumbo. We had a seat inside near the live seafood tanks, and the crabs in there were some of the largest live crabs I've ever seen. We had chili crab, golden crab, prawns, fish wrapped in banana leaves...I can't even remember it was a seafood extravaganza. Unlike most places they actually gave us cloth napkins which was nice, in addition to the traditional finger bowls and wet naps. Recommended for seafood.

Great view of the bay, a classic Singapore sling and chili crabs. What more could you ask for?We came here with colleagues and had the whole gamut of foods including the whole friend grouper, chili crab and salt fish fried rice. At 20:00, the Marina Bay Sands puts in a great light show on the bay so come late and sit in the patio. The place was packed and the food was outstanding. On the downside, service was a little slow.

First off - just wanna comment on the restaurant's ODD name - haha - b/c its a straight up Chinese restaurant. Anyway - the food was alright and I am biased b/c I am vegetarian and although I appreciate the special veggie prix fix meal that they had available for 35$S - the food was super bleh. Now as for the seafood my friends devoured - they got the chili crab and the black pepper crab and a few other dishes and totally devoured everything. I am giving this place 4 stars not b/c of my experience but from watching how much the rest of my party enjoyed the place. Additionally - the location is just great - great view of the Singapore bay and a view of MBS

The reputation exceeds the actual experience at this famous restaurant. The service was very slow, often waiting 10m or more to get water refilled even though we were paying a fortune for bottled water. Food also took forever to arrive and not well paced (does anyone really want the vegetables before the main course arrives?) The food itself was okay, though personally I prefer more meaty flavorful San Francisco crabs or even the small Maryland crabs which at least are easy to hammer open. They do not provide the tools you need and are stingy with napkins and wipes. Overall the experience was well below what you would expect at a higher end place and of course there is no view from inside the restaurant (where there is minimal though insufficient A/C). If you want better crab (minus the view) I'd hit one of the outdoor food centre/hawker stalls. And beware the spicy chili oil will do a number on sensitive stomachs. I'll be generous with 2*
Food was excellent. I recommend the spicy crab. Also, sit outside as the view is great.

this place is damn good and damn expensive.. thankfully a friend's family picked up the tab.. if you like the heat... you can eat outside and enjoy the light show highlights include cereal prawn.. fried baby octopus.. and of course the chilli crab.. i'd skip their desserts thoughthe place is quite small.. and it also gets very loud
Pepper crabs were very good and better than the chili crabs. Atmosphere was bright and loud and not great for a large party.

extremely disappointed. seated outside, which was a good sign, then everything downhill. ordered drinks (wildly overpriced), appetizer (was highlight of the meal, should have left while ahead), then main courses: chili crab (the "small" was 1.6kg s$125. now think about that - s$125!!) + 2 other mains + fried rice. the waiter brought 1 main, and we waited for the other 2 + the rice, which was not served with the 1st. then the 2nd main arrived after the 1st was cold, still no chili crab!!?? lost appetite, cancelled the chili crab which sent everyone berserk. insult to injury, they brought the fried rice last. needless to say, not a good food time. the hostess apologized, big deal, the meal was ruined. thankfully, the company was great and we ignored the terrible service. we will never return for several reasons: restaurant is a tourist trap (don't understand why anyone would go, but then again never underestimate stupidity - this was recommended to us and was our 1st visit to Singapore), food average, stupidly expensive. i do not mind paying up for excellent food, but this was not excellent. the good news: day before, we had the chili crab at Jumbo, which was 1/2 the price & can only say, since i did not have at Palm Beach, therefore can't compare, but Jumbo's chili crab was excellent!  so i didn't feel i lost out on finally having Singapore's signature dish. be forewarned, even "IF" all dishes had arrived together, i would still never return - just not worth being taken for a sucker when there are so many great places to eat in Singapore!! help this helps those who are thinking of going because of the name and location. oddly, i have not been able to find their menu online? their website does NOT have the menu, which strikes me odd. another reason not to go!

address: The Fullerton Hotel 1 Fullerton Square Singapore 049178 Singapore
comment: Town was the restaurant we enjoyed our breakfast daily(x3). Their service, setting, and display (of foods) were excellent. Each day they made a minor change in their presentation of the foods. This exhibited they were serious in pleasing their guests, particularly the ones long-stayed in their hotel. For guests had to pay for the breakfast, it would cost $32. Certainly it would be good to include it as part of hotel charge ($325 per night). The foods presented included Chinese, Japanese, Singaporean and American. Marvelous!

address: The Fullerton Hotel 1 Fullerton Square Singapore 049178 Singapore
comment: when you pay a certain price, you get a certain pedigree of buffet (especially in singapore) - and most hotel buffets run the same gamut of international food: sashimi is almost mandatory, a cold seafood section, cooked food and dessert.over here, it's pretty interesting in that the spread isn't necessarily big, but there are salad counters (where you get to toss your own in gorgeously big bowls), a special-of-the-night section featuring some unique dishes (peranakan curries when we visited), a chinese roast meat section (with good roast duck and lovely charred charsiu) and a pretty large indian section (large being relative to the rather modest size of the buffet).and if you pay twenty more (the auspicious 88 instead of the still-auspicious 68), you get the option of seafood - and really, I'm not quite sure what that entails as my companions kept ordering plates of lobsters.they weren't the best shellfish specimens, so brace yourself - I think they were a bit salty (from sitting in a brine, posssibly?) and bouncy in a not-necessarily-entirely natural manner. but - edible, still tastes like lobster - you're still going to order it.I finished with cheese and fruit - the former being more impressive than the latter, which was a measly selection (straits at the hotel rendezvous has one of the better fruit and dessert spreads, if you're into that) - very nice.so it's a decent spread, it's a competitive price, and of course the environs are pretty lovely (considering it's the fullerton). my favorite buffet still remains melt for quality, the line as runner-up, and lime at pickering as second loser. go forth and eat!
This place totally gets it when it comes to healthy breakfasts.  Would have given a 5th star if it was little bit less expensive. But then again, this is $ingapore!

I have never ever been so disappointed by lunch before.I got the Superfood Salad, which was $18 ($19.80 after ++). See the picture attached with this review and decide for yourself if it's worth it. It's basically a tiny bed of tomato and lettuce mix with a teensy weensy bit of almond and walnut sprinkled. The dressing was tasty though.The general consensus is that if this place was $5 less expensive, it would have been okay. But it's not.I am typing this review in a queue for fish soup from a nearby hawker center because I felt like I haven't had lunch, even after paying $20.
Everything is pretty much gluten free. Good food but no ambiance. Great for quick breakfasts.

My work colleague always orders from Kitchen by Food Rebel and I've been coveting her zoodle with meat sauce for weeks.  It's not far from our office, so we treked over there Friday for lunch.  First off, it's expensive, even for Singapore, and their margins are pretty insane.  I mean I had a zoodle (zucchini spiralized with meat sauce) and it was $18.   I'm pretty sure a zucchini cost about $1.  The budda bowls looked pretty tasty, they also had some really good looking vegan desserts like carrot cake, an avocado mousse and brownie, but again all pretty steep on the price.  They serve breakfast and wine (not at the same time) and are a cute little place to go grab dinner with a friend or coworker, and the zoodle was good.  They do use quality ingredients, but for me it's still a bit steep.

Kitchen By Food Rebel is a cafe that makes clean eating delicious and filling! The food is delicious, healthy and creative - and I know where it has come from. The variety on the menu means there is something for everyone - if you want gluten free, dairy free, raw, organic, then you've come to the right place. The staff are wonderfully friendly and welcoming. I would highly recommend the vegan buddha bowl, incredible hulk smoothie and the rebel pie.

The most value for money destination for fresh sales with such generous portions! I always leave this place feeling full and healthy from the portions of greens and a variety of toppings to choose from! Highly recommend Honey Soy Garlic for a lighter dressing option without compromising on taste.
We came here to chill, drink, and enjoy the moment. The ambiance was ok and the service was ok. The drinks were also ok. There was nothing particular that piqued my interest in this place...
This is probably the worst place ever. Expensive and the worst customer service in the whole of raffles place
Really well presented salads in unique wooden serving bowls. Great coffee, friendly staff

An unexpected surprise. Came here for New Years lunch and was verrrry happy. Started with a pasta that was cooked perfectly. Followed that with two pizzas that were also delicious. Thin crust and crispy base. Finished with a slice of chocolate pie that was amazing. The quality of all the food was outstanding. This is probably the best Italian food at rob quay. Will definitely be coming back.

The food here is actually quite decent. Brought my family here for dinner and we ordered many of their signature dishes. We liked:* Roast Chicken Two Styles - I liked the slightly sweet sour taste to coat half the chicken meat. And the other style is crispy chicken. * Fish Head Curry - good taste. Can be spicier and the curry can be more in amount. I like to drown my rice in curry you see. * Sambal Fish - totally deep fried pomfret and a good amount of dry fried belacan Chilli * Baby Squid - well done. Not powdery and very crunchy and tasty. * Prawn Rolls - can taste its home-made and with a good mix of pork & prawn minced. Love it!A tad pricy but ambience nice and comfortable. Can return for more!

address: 24 Raffles Pl #02-02, Clifford Centre Singapore 048621 Singapore
comment: This casual Italian restaurant opened in the heart of Raffles Place in October last year but it only came to my attention recently when my friend and I were trying to find a new place in the CBD for reasonably priced and hearty Italian fare. The menu is unpretentious and serves the usual fare you will get at most Italian restaurants. Even their special pastas are stuff you can get elsewhere. Nonetheless, the pricing is reasonable and the quality of food is good generally. I had the penne al granchio and lava cake while my friend had the linguine alla vongole. We appreciated the relatively generous serving of crabmeat and clams, which were quite fresh too. And it's hard to go wrong with the very chocolatey lava cake.If you are going to burn the midnight oil and need a quick Italian fix, this is the place to go.

address: 24 Raffles Pl #02-02, Clifford Centre Singapore 048621 Singapore
comment: After 2 weeks on the road in Europe, I was thrilled to find find a pizza place within walking distance of my hotel. I stumbled upon the place in The Arcade while exploring and getting my feet wet, and while I look forward to trying to local fare, I really wanted a pie. These guys delivered. After a friendly chat with the owner I settled on an Italian sausage pizza. Within a very reasonable amount of time, my pizza came out. I took my bounty back to the room and turned on an episode of The Simpsons. I flipped open the box and there it was, a beautifully made thin crush sausage pizza with a bag of red pepper and parm cheese. I chowed down, and was thrilled. If you're in the area, and wanting a pie, give the place a try.

Being a huge sushi fan I've tried a lot of places for sushi here in  Singapore, from take away and Sushi Tei to Akashi and Kinki, and though some things have been decent I haven't been wow'ed... Until now.I really enjoyed all of their food. We have the giant oysters (a must try!), the sashimi platter, skewers with both fish, veggies and meat and all was perfectly seasoned, tender and delicious. The food came out fast although the waiter did miss a few green tea request, but otherwise I only have good things to say about this place, and still affordable. I will definitely come back - often!

Shin Kushiya specializes in kushiyaki, otherwise known as high temperature yakitori or grilled skewers. The skewers here seem to be flash grilled so you're able to enjoy highly fatty meat items like bacon or reba. I've eaten at Shin Kushiya twice for work lunches and I love ordering the Ladies Set and the skewer combo platters. The Ladies Set comes with sashimi, some meh cucumber sushi (which you can substitute with sashimi), unagi, chawanmushi, salad and other stuff. That sort of rings like a winner takes all bento to me because I don't eat simple carbohydrates like white rice (if the restaurant started offering brown rice that would be perfect). The skewers are available ala carte and in sets, some of which include mushrooms, pork belly, chicken balls etc. My host ordered a fatty chicken liver (the poor cousin of the duck I guess) and it was pretty tasty, although the portion was so big you'd feel sick if you ate the whole thing. I usually pair my meal with the Yuzu cooler diluted with water.Lastly, the restaurant is decked out to look rather modern Japanese with dark wood paneling and the obligatory pawing cat on the counter. It can get a little noisy so do  book a booth if you're having a lunch meeting.

if you don't look closely enough, you may miss the entrance to Linda's Home Kitchen. half of its entrance is shared with an elevator to the offices on the upper floors of this shophouse.Linda's home kitchen serves Hakka food so you can find favourites like abacus seed and young tau foo. May look oily but taste fantastic. The Ngoh Hiang is also very nice. Only worthwhile if you have multiple people to share your meal with or it may be too pricey. They even serve poon choi and not just on Chinese new year. Quite rare to find. Good for treating VIPs but there are no private rooms.

address: 9 Raffles Place, Republic Plaza #B1-01 Singapore 048619 Singapore
comment: A high three, probably even a four.  Good and inexpensive but not too divey - maybe even borderline hip.  Lots of locations around Singapore - this one is at Raffles Place is a good option for eating with a colleague or casual business lunch that will only set you back about $20-$30.  Food is clean, not-too-greasy and tasty Asian.  Seats are relatively comfortable but practically touching your neighbor.  Good for eavesdropping.

Good tasty stuff.. Its like Din Tai Fung but more with its tasty side dishes especially the mala roast chicken which is tasty and very good value for money.Items are fresh, service is fast yet attentive.

address: 18 Raffles Quay Stall 92, Lau Pa Sat Singapore 048582 Singapore
comment: Tapa Queen ($6.50)!! Awesomely sweet, spicy and tender beef. The sauce was quite addictive, wish there was more of it. Egg was cooked pretty well too, garlic rice also fairly flavourful (but not overly so, I don't think I had the impression of garlic breath or anything after eating). Comes with some tomatoes/onion - token vegetables.. Haha. Wish there were some greens, but I guess you could order garlic kangkong for another $2.

address: 18 Raffles Quay Stall 92, Lau Pa Sat Singapore 048582 Singapore
comment: I read a poll once that most people interviewed (if I remember right, out of a 1000 randomly surveyed) named McDonalds as *THE* fast-food chain of their childhood - with phrases of happy meal toys, playgrounds, and fries mentioned frequently.Well, that freaking poll doesn't apply to me.Yes, I remember McDonalds growing up...but I was never that FOND of them. No, if you grew up in the Philippines...you'd probably be like me and love Jollibee or Tapa King a LOT more than McDs.I am one of those who grew up being a BIG fan of Tapa King as my favorite fast-food breakfast spot. While others were chugging burgers and hotdogs at Jollibee or McDs, I would be having a RICE dish for breakfast like a freaking TRADITIONAL CHAMP. The rice dish is considered one of the most popular Filipino breakfasts to date known as  the TAPSILOG, which usually consists of a "tapa" (sliced spiced-meat and the main varying component of the dish), garlic fried rice and a fried egg (usually sunny-side up). To give you a better idea of what tapsilog is, here is a picture of the "Tapa King" set: yelp.com/biz_photos/tapa…There are many variations in this dish and are a part of the "SILOG" family. At Tapa King, you will see the flavor profile variations for the Tapsilog (with the King set - original flavor, Queen set - sweet & spicy, Prince - sweet, Joe - herbs, and Flakes - another variation in the seasoning) as well as a lot of different meat options that I'm going to go gung-ho on, such as CORNsilog and SPAMsilog, which uses corned beef and spam as the choices of meat.Not to mention, if you are a heavy rice eater...the garlic rice here is AYCE!
