(I must mention though that they don't seem to add salt to the garlic fried rice so its flavor profile is more on the "plain rice side with hints of browned garlic")They also offer a few other dishes that are not -SILOGS such as sinigang, which is one of my all-time favorite Filipino soups for its sour flavor profile. I'm eventually going to try those as well and will add to this review.Yelp 100: 10/100

Found this restaurant by surfing on the web. Ordered the Singapore infamous Red Chili Crab, man tao and dou miao (green veggies).Unlike the cooked food stall, there's a fixed price for the crab instead of charging by weight. Also, this restaurant has a good reputation that no MSG will be added to any of the food.Long waited the infamous Red Chili Crab was finally arrived. The crab was in decent size. The presentation was nice. I first worried about the red chili sauce would be too spicy. Actually it wasn't so bad. It's a mixture of sour and spicy and the level of spiciness was kind of in the middle. It was very good. This is a must eat dish in here.Mantau was a deep fried steam roll. It is slightly sweet. It has a wonderful texture of the crispiness on the outside shell and softness in the inside of the mantau.Dou miao is fresh.Other than the dishes. The waiters were patient to explain the dishes on the menu and to show me pictures of the dishes which I wasn't sure what they were. Highly recommend this place!

If you like crab, this is the place for you. We tried the classic Singaporean dish: chili crab. It's priced at $55 Singapore dollars, which is like $40 usd, not bad for a whole crab! The crab meat itself was really good and plentiful. The sauce is sweet and spicy at the same time. Be sure to order bread on the side to soak up the sauce. You can get the bread steamed or fried. We got steamed but kinda regretted it seeing other customers' fried bread.

When in Singapore you MUST get crab. Well, unless you're deathly allergic, then maybe not. But for everyone else, Chili Crab is a must. I was told a story that Singapore is green because it apparently looks like a crab and a brown crab is an unhealthy crab so they decided to plant many trees to make it a green crab. It's alive!I think I missed some of the parts to that story, but nevertheless, crab is a really important part of Singapore for all tourists. It's not too hard to find places that serve Chili Crab and they're usually swarming with tourists. Crab is also super expensive but I figured it was worth the splurge as long as I could get a review out of the trip.I decided to go to Mama Kong's because it was recommended to me by a Singaporean friend. I had tried to go last year and was turned away because I didn't have a reservation. I wasn't about to make the same mistake this time and booked a reservation for 5pm -- table for one!The restaurant is small with seating both indoors and outdoors, It's a clean, sit down restaurant with a cozy vibe. Very different from the Chili Crab places about a block away. Reservations were made online and they have a rewards program, but since I don't live here I didn't sign up. I had had Chili Crab before at a tourist trap and it was awesome so I was expecting good things.The Black Pepper crab is "The Original" crab that is most recommended here. I was told it was spicy so I decided to get the classic Red Chilli (spelling it how it's spelled on the menu) instead. It's advertised as your basic Chili Crab, but Mama Kong's style. Both crabs were priced at $50 ($36.67 USD), so it didn't make a difference in terms of budget. Again, crab is always expensive in Singapore. It's probably possible to find cheaper crab, though.I was parched and got an apple juice, as well. It was $6 ($4.40 USD) and it literally tasted like apple juice, so I wouldn't say this was special by any means. It was definitely over priced but whatever, I needed something to drink and Mama Kong's didn't have a special drink that I was dying to try.The apple juice came first, followed by the Chili Crab shortly after. The crab was huge and I also ordered Fried Mantou for $3 ($2.20 USD) which is commonly served with Chili Crab. The Fried Mantou were so good! They were a bit heavy for me so I didn't eat all of them, but while they may have been unhealthy, they were also very delicious. I dipped the bread into the Chili sauce and enjoyed.The crab came pre-cracked. They have a de-shelling service but I didn't need it. I made piles of crab meat on the small plate they provided. I then put the meat onto the big spoon and scooped some Chili Sauce. The crab meat was juicy and there was a decent amount. The Chili sauce was sweet with a strong kick. I don't like spice so it was borderline too much for me, but I was pretty happy overall. It didn't go too well with the apple juice, though. Next time, I'll opt for a water.The restaurant was pretty empty while I was there but it's probably because I got there so early. The waiters asked to take a photo of me and gave me a copy with my check. The service was good and every one was super nice.I think Mama Kong's is a great place to go if you're looking for Chili Crab and you want a nice, cozy ambience. However, the actual quality of the crab was similar to that of the crab I've had a tourist traps and the crab overall was a bit too pricey for what it was. Plus, the $6 apple juice really threw me off.TOTAL COST: $70.05 ($51.38 USD)34 Mosque StSingaporeThis review is copy and pasted from my blog of solo travels and solo reviews.

My wife and I visited Singapore for the first time after Christmas, following a trip to the Philippines to attend a major family event, and we made it a point to sample some of Singapore's signature dishes. We tried Hainanese Chicken Rice our first night and Fish Head Curry from Banana Leaf Apolo the following day. For our last full day in Singapore, we headed out to Chinatown to try Chili Crab at Momma Kong's.Our initial research pointed to No Signboard Seafood as the place to get chili crab. However, recent reviews of No Signboard Seafood point to a decline in dining experience so we decided to give Momma Kong's a try.Reservations are highly recommended as the place was quite popular and cozy, with indoor and limited outdoor seating. Even in late December, it was hot and humid in Singapore and indoor seating with AC is preferable. We made a reservation for 2 for 5:00 PM, right when they open. They must get busy since we were informed they have a 7:00 PM reservation for the same table and they hoped we would be done by then. I was a bit put off by that but I knew we would not be lingering that long so no harm no foul.I ordered the red chili crab (Sri Lankan mud crab fresh flown daily - at least that's their claim) with jasmine rice. My wife, a self-proclaimed "lazy eater" opted for the prawn fried rice. For starters we shared the fried tofu chips with a zesty tomato-based dipping sauce. To round out our order, we ordered fried mantou and a couple of refreshing calamansi juices (on the menu as lime juice).The chili crab was the unquestioned highlight of our dinner...and it got messy. The chili gravy wasn't spicy and even had a hint of sweetness. The crab was fresh and I had to work to extract the meat...for the both of us. They can de-shell the crab for a fee ($15?)...but where's the fun in that? Needless to say, I used multiple napkins (so rare to find napkins in restaurants in Singapore) during dinner. The prawn fried rice was good as well as were the fried mantous. The fried tofu chips were also a hit. Based on food alone, we were inclined to give this place 5 stars. However, I rate on the entire dining experience.So what were the negatives? For starters, we didn't ask for but we were served these coated peanuts. They were OK...nothing special. We thought they were complimentary only to find out we were charged $2 SGD (Singapore Dollars) for them. We also used the wet napkins on the table (of course...this was a crab place and it gets messy)...and was charged $0.60 SGD for them. Oh yeah, we also found out they added a 10% Service Charge for a dinner for 2! I just can't help but feel like we were being nickeled and dimed for what already was a relatively expensive meal...just took away from the experience.Dinner for 2 came out to just under $108 SGD...or about $75 (US) in "real" money.

We wanted to try out the famous Singapore Chili Crab. A friend of mine recommended this restaurant. The food was really great. We ordered the Chili crab, garlic prawns and grilled squid. It was amazing. My husband was at first a bit scared to eat the chili crab. But after tasting the first bites he was convinced. Service was good as well. Food was ready quiet quickly.It's not the cheapest place to eat. But the quality of the food was very good. The air condition was too much for us. It was pretty cold.

As today marks my one year anniversary of living in the little red dot I will review my favorite place to eat one of Singapore's signature dishes: Crab!I've tried Jumbo, No Signboard & Longbeach but this is the place I take all my visiting friends to eat crab. Momma Kong's might not have the "authentic" feel of No Signboard in Geylang or the history of Longbeach but their service is great, the staff is super friendly so it means that I don't have to deal with the grumpy, non-English speaking, "I don't wanna serve filipino helpers" auntie to enjoy my crab fix.The crab dishes are on par or even better than the previously mentioned restaurants and I love their mantou, they must have the prettiest and fluffiest mantou of all.Except for the chili crab, I've tried also tried the crab beehoon & pepper crab which are all good but my favorite is the steamed crab: this fantastic dish displays the freshness and glory of crab in all it's simplicity. Yes, simplicity is the ultimate form of sophistication!Highly recommended!**Additional bonus points are granted for the fact that they offer to de-shell your crab (for 15$ a pop) so little bananas like me don't need to get their fingers dirty.

When in Singapore, eat Chili crab, right? Came here based on a recommendation from a local, saying that this place was better, cheaper, and less crowded than all the other ones listed in all the blogs (long beach seafood, no sign).Came here on a Saturday night around 8:30pm and the place was packed, but they were able to accommodate a party of 1. That's where my journey started...Had to get the chili crab because that's what I came there for. $55 set price. It's known what you'll be paying, which is great so you don't get blindsided by the "Market price" tag. Fried dough buns. Holy crap these were delicious. Wasn't planning on getting these because let's be real, you have an entire crab to yourself. Can you possibly fit more into your stomach?The answer is yes. Order the buns to soak up the sauce from the chili crab. You won't regret it.Overall, this place is a solid choice. It's a bit much for one person, but I would definitely try coming here with others and sharing!

I wanted to try chilli crab during my visit to Singapore, it being the national dish of the country and all. I wasn't really sure where to go. Lonely Planet actually recommended this place and it wasn't too far from where I was staying in Chinatown. This restaurant also has a new modern look to it, compared to some of the other places on the same street. And the staff is really young. I was seated outside (which was disappointing cuz it's hot outside and there are mosquitos!), but I didn't have a reservation and they recommend that you do that in advance. They offer a lot on the menu - not just crab, but stingray and other plates as well. I ordered the chilli crab cuz that's what I came for. I added on the steamed mantou too, since everybody recommended getting that to dip into the chilli sauce. The crab was delicious! Some of the tastiest crab I've ever had. And the sauce was really good. It was spicy and had a nice kick to it, but it wasn't overly spicy. Really good flavor. They provide you with a crab cracker tool, a little bucket, a little silver stick to help you scoop out more meat, and a moist towelette. All the things you could possibly need. More towelettes and napkins would've been nice though (I had to dig into my own supply; bring your own moist towelettes/wet tissues with you if you can! Eating chilli crab is messy!). They also charged for the moist towelette. And they charged me for the little fish side dish they gave me, which I hardly touched. Overall, delicious chilli crab! Yum!
We ordered of course  the chili  crab. It was good. It comes with gravy/ sauce so  make sure you order the fried bread . You can dip it in the sauce.

Came here with my family, as it was a recommended spot to have chili crabs in SG.We ordered a ton of stuff... but I specifically ordered the chili crab, steamed and fried buns, and tofu chips.Chili Crab - star of the show! This was so delicious in every aspect. The crab was giant, and the sweetness of the meat was still there... even with the excessive chili sauce. The sauce was thick, and perfectly seasoned. I literally mopped up every drop of sauce with those delicious fried buns.Tofu Chips/Fries - not sure what compelled me to order these. I'm not a big fan of tofu on its own. But fried, they sounded interesting. The server also recommended them stating they were popular. I wasn't impressed. They weren't at all crunchy on the outside. It was just deep fried, spongy, tofu sticks. Soggy outside, spongy inside. Very bland.The service was kind of eh... we were rushed from the second we walked in. They greeted us, and informed us that a large reserved party was due to arrive within the hour. They were only willing to seat us if we could finish in under an hour... why didn't they just lock the doors and wait for that large party then?...

What to do in Singapore if not eating their famous chili crab? We tried to find a place that is far from the limelights but still do good chili crab, and the answer was right there in our own neighborhood ( we stayed in Chinatown ). Momma Kong's was just a few walks away from our hotel and it looked pretty decent joint, a small-ish one but with good reviews, so we went in. We didn't take the package (you should if you're a big eater, we found out later that the package for two people is really good deal), but we ordered one crab each, the black pepper and the chili one and a set of steamed mantou to wipe all those delicious crab broth away.The crabs were super delicious and we were super happy. I had problems with cracking the claws but the staff spotted it right away and helped with it. My boyfriend who never had such large crab experience before also dove right in without any problem. My chili crab was perfect with the perfect amount of burn and the black pepper was super delicious. The bill came at around 75 dollars or so, so it was almost the same price with the package ( I believe the package is without drinks, and alcohol is quite pricey in Singapore) and we had beers, so if you think you can eat a lot, go for the package.I would definitely go back to this place if I had time next time. I am still thinking about the chili crab these days....and do book a table online, they can be a bit busy!

Came here twice in a week! It's a good chili crab place that's clean and has AC! The staff is really nice and helpful as well. Prices are about average from what I've seen in Singapore, S$50 per crab. They have other flavors besides the famous red chili crab. They have side dishes as well, which seemed a bit over price to me. We tried the tofu fries - which came with a spicy chili dipping sauce, it was alright! I would definitely just focus on the crab. It depends on hungry you are, but it seems like one crab per person is the norm if that's going to be your main meal. Butter crab was a bit bland (so good for those who can't handle the heat), and pepper crab (the OG Momma Kong's crab) was too peppery (?). The red chili crab still my favorite, sweet, savory, and spicy. **TIP: try the steamed mantou buns. They're super soft and fluffy, and helps to soak up all the delicious crab roe and gravy.

Momma Kongs serves delicious chili crab for people who prefer to avoid giants to the likes of Jumbo seafood. Food quality is good, and setting very clean. They also take reservations and come around to take a photo for every table--including a complimentary  printout on your way out (a nice touch) Prices here are not cheap, yet I felt there were areas I was under served. For example, MK does not offer bibs for guests, a crucial element as we are expected to peel our own crabs. For you to get it peeled, MK charges $15 extra per crab.

I was in Singapore, googling spicy crab, this restaurant pop up to my cell phone, " the best chili crab in Singapore" . so I booked a table and went. Two of us ordered a vegetable, a chili crab and some other dishes. The crab of 55 Singapore yuan is very small , and not fresh, vegetable which costs 14 Singapore Yuan is tiny portion, we spent around 110 Singapore Yuan for a meal, and was very disappointed. The so called "Best chili crab" is a self advertised title. the portion is unreasonable small, the quality of the crab is no good, ( Not fresh at all ) There are better spicy crabs in the food courts and other malls which cost much less.

I enjoy a good dining experience and who I can only presume was the owner or manager of Moma Kongs delivered this, he had a really people personality too him when taking our order, ensuring he got photos of all the diners for his patrons for his ever growing marque, etc.Staying in China town and wanting to enjoy chili crab a simple still away this seemed out best choice, best of all they took booking which made it the top of my list.We had the three crab offering a big task for two people, we chose the chili and black pepper and were recommended the butter to even out the flavors; best of all for us tourists they offered de-shelling service at a small(ish) extra so I could concentrate on eating an enjoying (sorry to any purists out there)It went without saying that I found all the crabs enjoyable though I do not profess to be an expert at these things... The drinks menu was sufficiently stocked for a cantina style restaurant.As you can tell I would recommend. This to other tourists like myself who want a simple and approachable way to enjoy one of Singapore's most famous dishes!

I wanted to try Singapore chili crab while I was there. Decided to give this place a try. The place is small but looks very clean and modern. The chili crab was very good, can't wait to come back for more.

Food was good.  Crab was tasty as was the butter crawfish.  We got the meal for 2 which was 125 SDG for a four course meal.  The service was good at first but then Extremely slow.  We had to wait over twenty minutes for the check even after we walked in to request.

A charming place specializing in Sri Lankan crabs. The price was very reasonable- $48 for one crab with a variety of cooking methods. They even offer deshelling service at $15 per crab! Haha. The cereal crayfish almost stole the limelight from the crabs. In contrast, the stir fried kai lan was disappointing so maybe skip that. The crab soup with bee hoon absorbed the essence of the ingredients. Highly recommended dish! At the end of the meal, the staff even took a photo for us and gave us an instant Polaroid photo!

I would say: it's crap.The only reason we stopped here was to have a quick drink and perhaps a quick snack. We opted for the fried chicken chunks and fried calamari, not such an adventurous choice I admit. The tonic water I ordered came garnished with a nice stick of cucumber (as often seen in Gin and Tonic). I nibbled on that one first only vaguely registering something odd. The I began to sip the drink and I realised it actually was a Gin and Tonic, even though I can still hear the waiter say: 'one tonic water'. Quickly fixed. No hassle later with the check. The crispy chicken chunks weren't very crispy nor very chunky. They were actually not nice at all!When we ordered I thought the calamari wouldn't be nice but it turned out those actually were nice. More like thin and crispy  tempura than a thick layer of tasteless batter. I realise this place specialised in crab (which I haven't tasted here), but I was not very pleased with their other offerings.

Two little wolves went into Momma Kong's for date night and had a thrillingly messy time.  Huff: Most of the time, it can be challenging for a duo, however dynamic, to take on two Sri Lankan crabs, but at Momma Kong's, the crabs are around 600 grams, so it can be done!Puff: While the crabs are good, none of them are the best versions of each that you'll ever have, but the bee hoon and the butter are among my favorites at Momma Kong's.Huff: The Ikan Bilis starter is nice too, tends to be spicy, so order mild if you can't take the heat!Puff: Can't go wrong with the garlic prawns either!  Tender and flavorful!And I'll blow your house down!  The most magnificent thing at Momma Kong's is the fried buns...golden brown, gratuitously crispy and simply perfect for soaking up every drop of butter or chili sauce!  Truly the best fried buns this little wolf has ever had, and I've had my share! PARTING THOUGHT: bring a trio and order the special: 3 crabs (any style) for $118

My first and only Singaporean chili crab experience in Singapore and I'm sure glad it was here!This place is quite popular and always has a wait so it's best to make a reservation in advance. We requested to be seated indoors as outside seating was on a patio sidewalk and I wasn't about to endure the hot humid weather while eating this spicy meal.Our order included the crab, bread, and a scallop appetizer. I'd skip on the scallop and bacon appetizer as it wasn't a great combo. Bacon is usually good on anything, just not on scallops. The bread was nothing like I had before! It had a crispy twisted exterior but when you break it open, steam releases and visible is this soft cloud-like fluff! Whoa, I didn't see that one coming! On to the crab, it's not a huge one but the winner is the curry. The spice is really well balanced with the egg mixture and is manageable even for those who can't handle too much kick.This may be the beginning of a chili crab addiction..

Came here with foodie sister after her recommendations. Ordered bee hoon crab and decided to try something different with peranakan crab this time. Added a stingray and shanghai greens. Originally ordered a dou miao too but ad they totally forgot to place our second order, we decided to skip that. My sis, mum and bro in law have been here a couple times and raved about the bee hoon crab and butter crab. According to them the chilli crab which was supposed to be their best seller was so so. They had a not so great experience with sotong last time so decided to give the stingray a try this time. The bee hoon crab was cooked with bee hoon soup. Soup broth was milky and sweet. Very delicious. Crab was very fresh. Peranakan crab was so so. Found the sauce to be aromatic but lacking in taste and a tad too oily. Crab tastes great. Fried mantou was very good but slighlty oily. Stingray was bad. Tasted like they steamed or boiled the stingray first and just grilled it a little in oven with leaf and chilli. The sambal was also very weak in taste. Worst sting ray i ever had. Stingray had a fishy smell. My bil who had blocked nose was only one who could eat it. Shanghai greens was meh. Totally meh. Just fried with garlic and not enough salt. Conclusion: they are only good with their crabs. And honestly quite upset with their service as they missed out part 2 of our order which is the peranakan crab and veg and barely an apology.

A trip to Singapore feels incomplete without having chilli crab.  Most of the restaurants were busy with Chinese New Year in full swing so glad my friend was able to make a reservation at Momma Kong's.  For four of us, we ordered the 2 person set menu with black pepper and chilli crab with an additional side of tofu chips and crab congee.  It was most than enough for the 4 of us.  I thought we'd have to get a crab per person but they are so meaty that it really does fill you up especially with the sides.  The chilli crab was delicious!  I don't have too many other places I can compare it to but I really enjoyed it.  The black pepper crab was definitely much spicier than the chilli crab but really good as well.  I really enjoyed the grilled squid and the tofu chips were surprisingly good.  I tried a bit of the crab congee and it was good.  I prefer my congee to be a bit more on the bland side but that's more of personal preference as I usually have that when I'm not feeling too well.  When our food arrived, they took a photo of us - I think it was going on instagram but thought it was nice that they printed it for us and gave it to us when the check arrived.  As a tourist, I really appreciated this!

The chili crab was amazing as were the side breads. The sides were fresh and spicy. And the whole thing was about $50-60 a person total. A great deal for this quality seafood. It's a small restaurant not great for large groups but I'd definitely recommended over more expensive places like jumbo for small groups of 2-4 people. We went twice in the week we were there

The Chilli crab was dynamite. The Montou is required to sop up all the delicious sauce. The shrimp appetizer was fantastic. Service is top flight. Get there at 5 if you don't have reservations. We will be back!! The 3 Asahi for $30 is also a good deal.

My mother and my best friend love crabs, so very often I end up eating with my mother, my best friend, and her husband at places that specialise or feature crabs.JUMBO. More recently, Happy Crab. And this actually was the meal that inspired me to bring my best friend to Happy Crab... because this place really let us down.We had high hopes because I had heard good things... so when we arrived we discovered they had a buy three get one free offer. DING. Four of us. FOUR CRABS. Done.Chilli. Pepper. Fresh steamed. And Bee hoon soup. We had all four of their preparation styles. We also had their chili marinated top shell starter that was SUPER GENEROUS in terms of portion size, and a nice, spicy starter. Only I had to eat most of it because top shell wasn't too popular with the rest of the people at the table. A single portion shared amongst 6-8 people would be ideal though. It'd really whet your appetite.The crabs. Now the bee hoon soup was... average, the fresh steamed incredibly unmemorable, the chili a bit too sweet, but the pepper was quite delicious. Not quite Eng Seng at Joo Chiat level, but good. Why was it so disappointing though?a) Temperature: some of the crab pieces were actually a little cold. It seemed like all the crabs had been pre-cooked and then they're reheated and tossed in whichever sauce you order it in. b) Freshness: the crabs didn't come across as very fresh. The flesh had that slightly mushy, waterlogged texture that comes from freezing, and it was especially noticeable in the legs where the meat was really almost unpleasant. One of the crabs we had, I think the steamed one, also had a rather unpleasant smell of... ammonia. It tasted okay, still sweet, and a little mushy, but it smelled really unpleasant.Overall, the value was okay, but when I eat crabs, it's all about freshness. I'm sticking to Happy Crab at Pahang Street.yelp.com.sg/biz/happy-cr…At least there the crabs are super fresh.

user_location: Sant Pere, Santa Caterina i la Ribera-Born, Barcelona, Spain
comment: Very good, great atmosphere, well priced, friendly people.  Highly recommend this place to anyone looking to try properly priced, non- tourist trap crab

address: 9 Raffles Pl #01-22 Republic Plaza Singapore 048619 Singapore
comment: I have lost count how many times I passed next to this store and the wonderful smell was always there!I entered this store and I felt that I was in Disney, at least, my kind of Disney! with so many different tea flavors, teapots and cup of all sizes and forms.I wish I could take them all.The service was on point and their macaroons were extremely delicious, they practically melted in my mouth. All the flavors were screaming my name and the price was great; only $2.00 per piece.Thank you!

address: 9 Raffles Pl #01-22 Republic Plaza Singapore 048619 Singapore
comment: Rate: 3.5/5 Unexpectedly noticed this TWG shop during a work visit to the area and it was a pleasant surprise because I was looking for a nice treat. I love their tea and so their macarons flavors were a must try. Earl grey fortune and chocolate and Matcha were both tasty. A little soft for my taste compared to Lauderee which is a favorite of mine but I felt the flavors were great and it was the right ratio of filling to outside. For $2 a macaron, not bad. I wish they didn't sell out of the Sakura macaron which is their limited edition flavor. Service was fine as well.

address: 9 Raffles Pl #01-22 Republic Plaza Singapore 048619 Singapore
comment: Everything about Singapore was wonderful and an adventure.  The tea salon had lovely little tables and a chance to relax with a steaming cuppa tea!

address: 9 Raffles Pl #01-22 Republic Plaza Singapore 048619 Singapore
comment: This is the original, and my favorite TWG outlet. It's a small glass box in the lobby of Republic Plaza, generally quiet, even during the lunch hour rush. I really enjoy the tea-flavoured food (favorites being the smoked salmon, and the tea jelly that came with the scones). Service is attentive, without being obsequious. I'm not sure now that this is necessarily the best value for tea lovers, but it is a good place to go if you want to impress, or if you want a quiet hour or two to yourself in the early evening. Quiet is not something I can say about their other outlets.

address: 3 Temasek Boulevard #02-605A, Suntec City Mall Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: We were looking for more Thai Milk Tea after our trip to Thailand and we heard about Tuk Tuk Cha. Their Thai Milk tea is pretty authentic! It was a little too much on the sweet side for me, but you can customize how much sweetness/ice you want when you order.

address: 3 Temasek Boulevard #02-605A, Suntec City Mall Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: I like the shibuya toast. Warm and buttery with coconut ice cream dripping on it, it was pretty awesome. As a snack or dessert, it was more than enough to feed 3 of us. We also had the iced lemongrass drink which was not very sweet and was refreshing. The place was smallish with a huge table and chairs around it so you would have to share the space with others. The service was also quite non-existent. The whole time we were there, I felt like the staff could not wait to get rid of us (or any customers). They did not inform us when our order was ready, and when we realized it and went to collect the food, the vibe given was how could we not know the food was waiting. We had trouble finding this and actually walked up and down the stretch 3-4 times while consulting the directory map. Turned out it is a kiosk like stand in the middle of the walkway. This is next to Boost Juice and faces away from Kay Lee roast meat.

address: 3 Temasek Boulevard #02-605A, Suntec City Mall Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: From the owners of the Bedok Point $1 boat noodles come Tuk Tuk Cha!Tuk Tuk is the famous motorcycle taxi used in Thailand. The staff here are all mostly thai and you can tell, once you make your order!They sell thai milk tea, green tea thai milk tea, yuan yang and other hot and cold drinks ranging from $1.70-$3.20.A regular thai milk tea costs $2.80 and a large costs $3.20. I had a regular thai milk tea $2.80 with mango pearls 50cents which I really enjoyed. The mango juice bursting in your mouth wasn't the best idea with the thai milk tea but it was still refreshing.I witnessed the staff boiling and pouring the thai milk tea, so you're assured you're getting real thai milk tea! The entire dining area sits maybe 10 people, at bar top level. The whole area is surrounded by hundreds of carnation milk cans!We also had toast with thai milk tea kaya $3.80. Yes there's like 9 cubes of bread for like $3.80. It might sound overpriced by I really loved the crispy exterior of the bread, together with the fluffy inside that seemed to have butter melted on the inside.I wouldn't eat this daily for sure, as I would rather get my kaya toast, but it is a nice treat. They have also recently expanded to have an outlet in raffles city, next to gong cha and also a heartland outlet in Sun Plaza, Sembawang.

address: 3 Temasek Boulevard #02-605A, Suntec City Mall Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: Tuk Tuk Cha is a small cafe offering thai style desserts and drinks. Currently it has 4 outlets in Singapore. One of the outlets is located in Suntec City Mall. The cafe was small with a small dine in area of about 10 paxs. One would not miss the tuk tuk vehicle which front the dine in area when passing by the shop.Aloha Coconut Shibuya Roast ($10.80)It was served with coconut ice-cream, shredded fresh coconut, and honey, on top of the crispy toast. Although the toast looked quite thick, it sliced easily as it was quite crispy. The toast itself was quite yummy being buttery and honey sweet. The ice cream was quite milky and rich. Overall quite a delicious combination.Thai Milk Tea ($2.80/regular), Homemade Lemongrass ($2.80/regular)Not sure if the toast was too sweet. We felt that the drinks were just nice and not too sweet.Overall the food was great. Service was great too. Although we were the last customers left, the staffs did not chase us out.

address: 3 Temasek Boulevard #02-605A, Suntec City Mall Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: Stumbled across Tuk Tuk Cha while roaming around Suntec City, and found the homemade taro kaya toast to be fantastic. You get 9 cubes of toast with a serving of taro kaya sauce for $3.80 which I thought was reasonable. Paying $10.80 for an entire toast topped with ice cream seemed a bit much in my opinion. The toast was perfectly crisp and conveniently bite sized. The Taro kaya sauce was delicious, not too sweet yet enough to give your toast the kick it needed. I also tried the Thai green milk tea which is priced at $2.80. Previous yelpers had noted how they witnessed the workers brewing the tea right in front of them, but my experience was a bit different. Perhaps they have tried to operationalize the practice to be more efficient, but all I saw was the workers pouring pre-made Thai milk tea into my cup and sealing it. I think it took away from my perception of authenticity, but regardless, the drink was good. I would perhaps come back here if I happen to be hungry in suntec, but likely would not come back craving it.

address: 3 Temasek Boulevard #02-605A, Suntec City Mall Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: Super mediocre. I came here because I saw a mouth watering photo of the shibuya toast on a blog site. What a lie! I'm all for "Instagram worthy" food pictures but the presentation of the toast sucked. It was served in a plastic container. It did not look nice to eat. It was not only because of the presentation, but also how it tasted. The toast literally tastes just like toast. Topped with coconut ice cream. And some pieces of coconut meat. Nothing extraordinary about it at all. The portion was quite small too. Disappointing. However, the drink I ordered was delicious. Green Thai milk tea. It tasted like green tea and Thai milk tea blended together (duh). It was really nice.

Regular weekly lunch with my boss where we try a new location each time. We stumbled on this in a back alley near our office off Telok Ayer. More like a bar but they had great lunch set served Izakaya style. We had 5 course set and waited for the chef to surprise us. Loved the scallops and coconut pudding.

Amoy Street has been hot this year, with some great new places joining the hood.  Le Binchotan is a newish place, which has a lot offer in terms of food and drinks.  Although the address is Amoy Street, the entrance is around the corner on Gemmill Lane and is right next to Burger Joint.  Fortunately, there is a sign as well as windows which shows a long narrow bar looking like a submarine.  Once inside, you can also see dining tables off to the side.  The menu is Japanese French with small plates and kushiyaki as specialties, and throughout the evening, we had a chance a few types of dishes.  For our starter, we had fried enoki mushrooms which were delish, especially with some fresh truffles.  We also tried the clams in sake broth, which was so so.  The broth was quite nice but the clams themselves were tough and still had some sand.  Next up, we tried a number of kushiyaki - chicken thigh, scallops, Tsukune, and chicken gizzards.  The skewers were delicious but averaging around $15-19 per single skewer, it's a bit pricey.  We also tried a mushroom risotto which was also served with truffles and delicious.  The smoked chocolate cake (more like a brownie) was a great way to end the meal, and the smokiness haunts you afterwards as well. There was much more on the menu that I would have loved to try, such as the uni, as well as the pork jowl with curry.   We washed this down with a couple bottles of wine, fairly priced under $90, but still the tab came out to $150/person, and I was still hungry.  So overall, I would definitely come here again, but perhaps not as hungry, and I would love to try some of the cocktails as well.

We happened upon this bar and were glad we decided to stop in for a drink.  It is a unique bar with a friendly staff and creative cocktails.  We had Rice Tea, Floral Enchantment, and Le Binchotan cocktails and they were all delicious.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #01-02 Customs House Singapore 049326 Singapore
comment: Amazing place for authentic thai food. Good ambience but price can be slightly on the high side. Service is prompt and quick. Here are some of my favorite dishes that you can try:Chicken WingsPandan Chicken Thai FishcakesPad Thai Green Curry

address: 70 Collyer Quay #01-02 Customs House Singapore 049326 Singapore
comment: The food here is decent, but it's pricey for the quality you get.Kang Kong with yellow bean was pretty tasty. Prawn cakes tasted decent but they were quite cut with filler. Pickled daikon in chili sauce on the side was pretty good. Stuffed chicken wings were decent. They came with 2 sauces which was nice. Seafood Tom yum soup was pretty good. Less spicy was still pretty spicy. The flavours were clean. The pot contained 3.5 bowls of soup so this item was relatively good value. Crab fried rice was pretty decent. Coconut sorbet was pretty good with a good variety of toppings: sticky rice, attap chee, peanuts etc. Mango sticky rice was good too.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #01-02 Customs House Singapore 049326 Singapore
comment: Thai food by Marina Bay. Ok food, excellent ambience. Would recommend going for dinner in the evening and sitting outdoor if it's not too hot so you can enjoy the view of SG skyline by the water. Food is standard. We particularly like the pomelo salad but the rest was just ok. Service was very slow though and a bit unfitting of its self-described "fine Thai cuisine." Quite expensive for what we got (~$50/pax) but again guess you are paying for the atmosphere.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #01-02 Customs House Singapore 049326 Singapore
comment: Nice and cosy environment.  It is housed in Customs House.  No real scene if you sit inside.Food was average.  Excluding Tom Yum soup which was extraordinary.Service was really attentive and good.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #01-02 Customs House Singapore 049326 Singapore
comment: Yummy pomelo and papaya salad. With great green curry. The place is a bit pricey though

address: 70 Collyer Quay #01-02 Customs House Singapore 049326 Singapore
comment: Easily the best Pad Thai of my life so far. Also had a papaya salad that was very flavorful. Beyond the food, the restaurant is very nice. On the water. Spacious seating. Attentive wait staff. Very pleased.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #01-02 Customs House Singapore 049326 Singapore
comment: I used to frequent their first outlet in Ngee Ann City whenever I crave good Thai food. This is my first time to this outlet and due to the location, you can expect a mostly business crowd.Food is generally good but I still prefer Ying Thai Palace for my Thai food cravings, the stuffed chicken wings there is definitely better as it has glass noodles, etc in it, not just minced pork.I like the olive rice in Sabai as they sprinkle chopped bits of lime that gives a great tangy bite. If you are looking for Thai in this part of town, this is probably the best option closely.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #01-02 Customs House Singapore 049326 Singapore
comment: I love this location of Sabai Thai better than the others because of the atmosphere. It is on the water and has a relaxed, upscale vibe. The food is delicious. I personally love their Tom Kha Gai, Panang Curry, and Phad Thai. It is great for business dinners, to go out with friends, or date night.

I was staying in the Fullerton Hotel so I decided to have dinner in their 8th floor restaurant. To start with I had the Burrata Di Andria. It came with lovely heirloom tomatoes & a minuscule drop of pesto. The cheese itself was okay, but too large and served too cold. I also had the crusted red snapper with small puréed cauliflower dots as my main course. The fish was very good.Sadly, the service here is a distraction. While they attempt a snobbish appeal, they merely come off as sycophantic and lacking in sincerity.Location - 5 STARSAmbiance/Decor - 5 STARSFood - 4 STARSService - 3 STARSValue - 4 STARS

Tried booking for dinner a birthdayboccasion but was fully booked so chose lunch instead.   The hostess was to put us with a window view of the bay.   Other than the miss order and the so so pork chop we conclude that this place deserves a revisit for dinnner.   Granted the seating capacity is not that big but believe the food and the service compensate for it.   also lovely surprise with a bday chocolate cake and a picture post card.   it is precisely little things like these brings wonderful memories.

What an awful first customer interaction of the chief waiter Raffy on the Rooftop bar today of the Fullerton: "You are not allowed to drink you Whiskey here".  ....  It takes decades to build up the Fullerton reputation, but it needs one "Raffy" to destroy it over night. Worst Customer Experience I ever had while staying in an Luxury Hotel like Fullerton. Unacceptable for me to stay longer, we are moving out and change the hotel.

This place is absolutely awful. We showed up at 7:30 for reservations, and ordered food and drinks. Our drinks came in a reasonable time, and then around 8:30 we asked how much longer our food would take. Mind you, we only ordered 3 appetizers. At this point, we also had empty drinks and there was 6 of us. The server told us that he would check on our food and around 9pm, we asked for our checks because we had been waiting so long for our food. We were quickly given someone else's bill, and told that it was apparently the people before us that just walked out. (Honestly can't say I blame them). We asked for them to split the bill 3 ways for our drinks only. Takes about 15 mins and we explain to the manager how upset we were with the service. If you've ever been here, you'll also witness that there's only 9 tables and 3-4 people serving/ bar tending. There's honestly zero excuse for the completely awful service. The manager asked if we wanted a bottle of champagne and we told him that we did not want to stay there any longer, and we wanted our checks. His response "okay I'll make sure that's expedited" how can cashing out not already be expedited? This place is fairly expensive to begin with, and if I'm going to pay $25 a cocktail, I expect to be treated with better service and respect.

Fantastic dinner spot! Great service. I would call ahead to make sure you have a nice table. Also have a drink on the roof top great place to enjoy the light show. Oleksandra is fantastic ask for her!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Graced with one of the sexiest views of Singapore, this aptly named venue is a happy hour haven for post-stressed bevvie mavens!The best tables are almost always booked out. So getting here early ensures you'll get a good use of them before the reservees show up (and sometimes they don't). Best bang for buckets are the Kronenbourg 1664. All iced up you'll be knocking these puppies back whilst you drink in that view and soak up those tasty tunes.This is a bi-monthly stop and it never fails to entertain and delight.The one downside is the toilets are a slow elevator ride away. However, if your wallet is fat the sushi/sashimi located on the same floor is as sexy as the name suggests, so you can always relocate post happy hour tipple!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: It is a nice but compact rooftop bar, located in central area of Singapore.  The view of the Marina Bay is pretty good from all the sides. If you want to grab the best view seats, make sure to reach early (before sunset). Towards the end of evening, the crowd increases and so does the music pace and volume. Food and liquor are both somewhat pricey and menu is limited.Service is pretty slow and laid back. No personal touch, no courtesy, everyone is working like a zombie and doing their thing. Washrooms are located on the ground floor so you have to take the elevator every now and then. Since we were there during the happy hour, we just ordered 1-on-1 beers (1+1 corona and 1+1 1664). I guess, it was a good experience but I wouldn't wanna go their regularly.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Great views and vibes. Unfortunately their customer service is the reason behind my 3 stars. We stopped by for happy hour and although they offer you BOGO you have to order the same drink and they bring it out at the same time. Defeats the purpose if you want a cold beverage. What threw me off guard was how quickly they give you the bill. I understand this prevents customers from walking out to forget to pay but then it is also a turn off to want to buy/purchase more.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Kinki the restaurant = 3 stars Kinki the rooftop bar = 4 starsYou can find me, my husband, yuppie expats, and all the trendy Singaporeans that work in CBD at Kinki's rooftop on Friday evenings. I always roll in after happy hour, when the DJ is letting that beat rock, all the tables are taken, and the crowd is collectively cheering that it's the freakin' weekend.Drink prices are steep (for me... because Maker's Mark on the rocks = $18) but I put up with it. As other reviewers mentioned, it can get pretty warm, and the mega fans they have don't help that much unless you stand in front of them. Every time I'm there, they seem to play some super weird background videos of people getting tattoos. Anyone else notice that?! Does it annoy you as much as it annoys me?!Despite this, I've met some great gal pals here, and yes, we still keep in touch. As for the guys, I'm married, but I can say that a lot of them seem like eligible bachelors so if you're in the market for one, this would be a nice place to start!As for the restaurant, I've dined here (drunk) and all I can remember is that the sashimi was good quality, the portions were small, and the price kind of put a dent in our wallet... so maybe next time I'll be smarter and go to McDonald's instead, haha.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Visited both the bar and restaurant. Very overpriced for above average food, sub standard ambience and staff. We were by the window and it really wasn't that great. Portions are small so you'll need to order quite a bit. Thankfully I had good company or it would be a 1* experience.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Despite the name this place doesnt exude sex...well that depends on the amount of alcohol consumed. But anyways I will touch upon the restaurant and bar separately.   I went to the restaurant for my birthday and I would say it was very good. The food is a but pricey for the amount given but the quality is great. I LOVED the tai carpaccio and truffle rib eye. Also loved the spicy edamame. It had tons of flavor. I consider the sushi to be so so and not really worth the price.  There are plenty of better dishes and the okonomiyaki is not like the japanese varitey at all but is really just a pizza ( but its still good).  I wouldnt come for great japanese food but its dishes are inventive and pretty good with a few misses.The bar above is a really fun spot. I love the atmosphere, the view of the bay, the open air, etc. They also have these great miso pork nachos that are awesome.  Its fun and lively and a great spot to preparty or just hang out for the night.  Its just as good a view as the lantern but half the price.  Definitely on my go to spot for showing friends around singapore

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: My review is solely for the Bar and not the restaurant as I think the restaurant is ehh...for the exorbitant prices you have to pay for good sushi/sashimi.Kinki's Rooftop Bar is just out of this world! In my view, it's the best after-work / happy hour bar in Singapore. Friday nights are simply packed. First off, it's got an amazing view of Marina Bay Sands. Second, they play some fun catchy 80s tunes to get the party going (which brings me back to my old stomping grounds in Murray Hill, NYC)! Third, the drinks are relatively cheap, albeit watered down and/or measured, as is most alcoholic drinks in Singapore (ugh!). Fourth, the crowds are good looking expat working professionals (very few, if any, locals to be found).To conclude, I give this place 5-stars for the atmosphere, but more importantly it's the place where I've met so many of my Singaporean based friends, since moving to this country three yrs ago. I liked it so much that I had my 28th birthday party here!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Overall, this is a good meet up place for casual drinks coz of its central location, good views of the bay and the price of the drinks, there's one for one during happy hour (albeit heavily watered down I suspect).But if you decide to go there, you need to be mindful of all the other imperfections - service was slow and choppy.  During our 4 hours there we had three orders of food and the average waiting time is 40 mins, which is pretty long considering we only ordered snacks like sushi and hand rolls. They have left out certain items in our order until we checked and the food was just ok.  I would say go for the location and the view but nothing more.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: I was contemplating to rate this place with either 3 or 4 stars.There are PROS and CONS:Pros:1. Nice awesome view if you're lucky enough to get window seat2. Small but elegant setting3. Good quality food and fresh sashimi4. Fusion modern Japanese dishes Cons:1. Unfriendly staff 2. A little bit noisy due to small space3. Overpriced4. Tiny portionBest menu so far:Beef tataki (pan seared sliced beef)Tofu steakSeasonal sanma sashimi with ponzu sauce*I personally wouldn't order sashimi because it's overpriced and nothing special about it at this restaurant. However I think if you do eat meat, beef is always a good choice here. :DI'll be coming back to try other things soon! I'll keep you guys posted!Tip:If you don't wanna break your bank, try not to go for a dinner here when you're really starving.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: One of my favourite bars to go to in Singapore for a few reasons.Firstly, you get an amazing view from wherever you are seated within the bar, without having to pay extortionate amounts for drinks and be in a pretentious environment. Kinki is pretty casual, which I really like and if you go early evening, you can catch a really good happy hour. (2 for 1) When they don't have a DJ, they have an awesome setlist of old school R&B jams- which I really enjoy as its very hard to get that anywhere else in Singapore and it goes nicely with the funky, urban style setting of the bar.Bar food is great also. A must visit!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Come here when you are looking for a place to chill with nice view and serves alcohol. It gets very crowded at night though, so naturally it will get very noisy as well. You will have to put an extra effort to hear on what the other person is saying even when he/she is sitting right across you.Not recommending this place as your first date or business meeting venue. Portion-wise the food at this place typically is very tiny. However you could count on that the chef will decorate your meal to make it look very appetizing. Pretty food, pretty view.Last but not least, they do take reservations.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Good food and location. Average cocktails. Disappointed with their cocktails on the rooftop bar. The mango mint seemed to be using a mint flavour instead of real fresh mint. The yuzu martini tasted like an orange soft drink. The bite of martini was missing. And it was not Yuzu at all. At dinner tai carpaccio was awesome. But it was served on a black coloured plate. With out table in a dark corner this otherwise  beautiful dish was not getting the right attention. Rest of the fate like teriyaki chicken, pork belly and tempura etc were good. Salmon spicy sushi was very good.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Excellent view, great folks and very helpful.Reasonably price.  Get there early for good seating

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: I've eaten here many times and even had my 32nd birthday dinner here.  I am crazy for the Spicy Hachimitshu!!  It's like a cucumber martini infused with wasabi.  The sashimi is pretty darn fresh too.  Caution: Extremely pricey menu

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Don't let the name mislead you, this restaurant sells good Japanese nosh and good cocktails, and nothing sleazy. The great food will be sure to hit your unami spot. If you are down with a friend, be sure to order a cocktail each. Their mixes are delicious. I will recommend the Ume Mojito.Be sure also to get the Tai Carpaccio, a platter of thinly sliced Snapper topped with truffle sauce and shio konbu. Ok let's skip the fanciful words and read this: fresh sashimi with flavourful truffle = a clear winner. The Pork Belly with Truffle was melt-in-your-mouth lovely and left a aromatic aftertaste swirling in your mouth with the shaved truffle. Plus, indulge in the Fresh Sashimi Platter (with Maguro, Amaebi, Hotate, Hirame, Hamachi and Sake) which features fresh cuts of plump meat, no scrimping there.A word of advice, be down there when you are feeling ready to spend and order without looking at the price list. Also, be sure to grab seats near the wide windows so you can dine with the view of the city skyline.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: I've been here a couple of times for lunch with friends. Their set lunches, though not cheap, offer good quality food at reasonable prices. We had the nori crusted spicy salmon for $30 which came with a salad, miso soup, rice and mochi dessert. The salmon was of a generous serving, cooked perfectly moist and tender. The mochi dessert is always the highlight of my meal because it's delightfully chewy and fragrant - I wish they'd provide 2 pieces instead of 1 every time. I do find the price of $5 for tea a tad exorbitant but you're paying for a nice view with a relaxing ambience. It can get crowded at lunch if you're in a big group so make reservations on Chope.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: My review is for the rooftop bar. The view is nice but the service is poor. I booked a table for 12 in advance and when we got there on time, half of it was given to another group. When we asked, the waiters were rude and said this was it. Later the other group told us they were given our table and would leave in 30 mins an so we eventually got the table and weren't crammed. The service is super slow, they just ignore you while you try to order. Isn't worth going to for the service, many better options available in Singapore with similar views and price range.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Kinki is overpriced, in my opinion. However it's worth checking out if you go for their weekday lunch sets! I got the executive sashimi set for $46. The set came with miso soup, rice, pickles, a fresh salad and a mochi dessert. The strawberry cream mochi wasn't anything great, and the green tea mochi also had a cream and red bean paste within, but I thought the best one was the simple peanut mochi that had no filling.The rice was just normal white rice, so if you want Japanese rice, they charge you more for it. This seems rather outrageous, if you ask me. It's a legitimate japanese restaurant, so they should be serving proper japanese rice! The miso soup was average, salad was very fresh and crisp, but the cream mochi was too creamy so I didn't enjoy it. The sashimi was very fresh though! It was pretty good quality, and there was a wide variety. They have 2 pieces of each type, and one sweet prawn. They even give you 2 pieces of the fatty tuna and scallops, which are pretty premium.The service staff aren't friendly, but they are efficient at filling up your green tea cups and clearing your plates, but they're a miserable looking bunch with nary a smile for anyone.The other saving grace is the view you get overlooking the bay and their chic interior. I really love the strange but interesting light made of black cords and bare light bulbs arranged to look like a chandelier on a low ceiling. Save it for a special lunch date or business lunch meeting, I suppose, but I find that it isn't great value for money here.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Service was frustratingly slow and the food overpriced for what you get...

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: This place was LEGEND...wait for it...DARY! The view from the roof top bar was phenomenal and though service could have been a tad bit better the food downstairs was amazing (and that's coming from someone who really isn't a seafood fan)! We had platter after platter of some of the best sushi and seafood I have ever had. Definitely try the hot dynamite maki (my personal fave) and the hirame carpaccio. Can't wait to go back!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Utterly Disappointed - i had the worst Singapore dining experience here the other night. Sorry to say this as Kinki has a cool vibe and a nice rooftop where i've taken guests in the past. I thought the staff was poorly trained and the dine-in policies bizarre and inflexible. Suffice to say, I wont be going back.I attended my friends birthday party at Kinki where she reserved a table for 20 from 6 - 9 PM. My partner and I arrived about 1 hour late and at that time the table (for 14) that was given to us was over-packed already. We noticed that the table for four next to our large party was available and I asked to sit there so we could be close to the birthday party. We were told by the wait-staff that the table was reserved. Ok no issues, we were only 2 people and didnt want to take up the larger table so we asked to sit at a 2 person table in the vicinity of the party. Again, that table was reserved. We then approached the manager and told them of our situation: we had a party for 20 but were seated in a 14 person table but we arrived late and the wait staff wont let us sit at the tables nearby. So how?The manager let us know at that point that the entire restaurant was booked for the night. Perplexed, I looked around the restaurant of (im estimating) 30 tables and only 8 of them were occupied. As we were with the large birthday party, i inquired if could eat quickly at any one of the reserved tables before the parties arrived and was told that we could not as the tables were reserved. I then asked what time the people were coming for their reservation for the tables near the birthday party and were told that she didnt know. Then I asked since they didnt know, if we could eat and if the party came, they could be seated at another one of the 15 open two seater tables. Again, I got the "cannot sir". I asked her "so you are telling me that we are here for a birthday party already eating, you have 75% of your restaurant unoccupied and you are not letting us eat". The only reply i got was sorry the restaurant is reserved. I thought this was odd, and we were left awkwardly hovering near the birthday party table for about 10 minutes while they hurriedly finished eating. At that point we were told by the birthday girl that we had a reservation upstairs at the bar and that they had some bar snacks that we could eat. We hovered and waited for critical mass to finish eating and headed up stairs to the open air bar area. Despite a reservation for 20, Kinki gave us a table to seat 4 but was in the corner so we had some standing room only spots. We ordered a few bottles with all the mixers and ice buckets so there was little room for us to order food to eat. I asked the bar wait-staff, if we could sit at the table next to ours so that we could order some bar food to eat. Again, that table was reserved. Looking around there was our party of 18-20, and about 8 other people in the rooftop bar area and about 15 open tables. I asked the wait staff what time the table was reserved for and he said 10pm. Looking down at my watch, it was only 8 so i asked him to give us the seat for 30 mins so we could quickly eat and then we would go back to the original table. He said, sorry the table was reserved and walked away. However, he then came back a few minutes later and nicely said okay we could site there for an hour. Another wait-staff took our order and being vegetarian I ordered the Vegetarian Okonomiyaki. He told me that the Okonomiyaki was not available. There weren't many vegetarian bar snack options so I asked if i could order from the restaurant menu. "No, you cannot". I asked where the bar snacks were being prepared and he answered "the restaurant downstairs". Odd... I told him nevermind and that I ordered a drink. When he came to bring my drink he apologized and told me that the Okonomiyaki was available so I confirmed the Okonomiyaki order.The vegetarian Okonomiyaki was brought out abut 30 mins later and it wasnt Okonomiyaki looking at all. It was mayonaise atop toasted bread but wasnt bad tasting until I bit into something that tasted like chicken. At this point i was about to lose my sh*t. I asked my meat eating friends if it tasted like chicken and 2 out of 3 agreed. I approached the wait staff and  told them annoyingly that they had served me meat on a vegetarian dish. The wait-staff shook his head violently and flapped his arms up and said looking even more annoyed than me, "that was vegetarian". They sent another wait-staff who confirmed that it was mozzarella cheese. I never really knew mozzarella cheese and chicken could be so easily confused and let my friends eat the rest of my dish. No dinner for me after 3 hours of trying, thanks Kinki!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Despite the name this place doesnt exude sex...well that depends on the amount of alcohol consumed. But anyways I will touch upon the restaurant and bar separately.   I went to the restaurant for my birthday and I would say it was very good. The food is a but pricey for the amount given but the quality is great. I LOVED the tai carpaccio and truffle rib eye. Also loved the spicy edamame. It had tons of flavor. I consider the sushi to be so so and not really worth the price.  There are plenty of better dishes and the okonomiyaki is not like the japanese varitey at all but is really just a pizza ( but its still good).  I wouldnt come for great japanese food but its dishes are inventive and pretty good with a few misses.The bar above is a really fun spot. I love the atmosphere, the view of the bay, the open air, etc. They also have these great miso pork nachos that are awesome.  Its fun and lively and a great spot to preparty or just hang out for the night.  Its just as good a view as the lantern but half the price.  Definitely on my go to spot for showing friends around singapore

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Kinki the restaurant = 3 stars Kinki the rooftop bar = 4 starsYou can find me, my husband, yuppie expats, and all the trendy Singaporeans that work in CBD at Kinki's rooftop on Friday evenings. I always roll in after happy hour, when the DJ is letting that beat rock, all the tables are taken, and the crowd is collectively cheering that it's the freakin' weekend.Drink prices are steep (for me... because Maker's Mark on the rocks = $18) but I put up with it. As other reviewers mentioned, it can get pretty warm, and the mega fans they have don't help that much unless you stand in front of them. Every time I'm there, they seem to play some super weird background videos of people getting tattoos. Anyone else notice that?! Does it annoy you as much as it annoys me?!Despite this, I've met some great gal pals here, and yes, we still keep in touch. As for the guys, I'm married, but I can say that a lot of them seem like eligible bachelors so if you're in the market for one, this would be a nice place to start!As for the restaurant, I've dined here (drunk) and all I can remember is that the sashimi was good quality, the portions were small, and the price kind of put a dent in our wallet... so maybe next time I'll be smarter and go to McDonald's instead, haha.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: I have been off Japanese food for a while after a bout of food poisoning but I've slowly been trying to get back into it not least in celebration of my husband finishing his samurai computer game.  Did I mention I'm married to a nerd? What better place to reintroduce my tongue to Japanese than the uber-swanky new Japanese restaurant Kinki.  The place is decorated with koi acrylic floor paintings, Oishinbo inspired food portraits on the walls, and very low furniture making it seems futuristic and modern. Also the view is breathtaking.I had the edamame (salted to perfection), vegetable tempura (best I've ever had), and pomegranate miso black cod while my companions stuck mostly to sushi.  The sashimi we saw coming out of the kitchen made me drool by the way.  All of the food was spectacular and obviously was washed down with sake.  I would just caution that the miso was just barely cooked which I'm sure is the method de jour but I am just barely adult enough to handle undercooked fish.  Stick with the raw stuff if this bothers you too.  The sushi I was able to sneak off my husband's plate was fun and inventive and really tasty.At present the clientele is mostly older business gentleman. I suggest we turn this around and make it a haunt for the younger foodie crowd.  You won't be disappointed.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: It's a pretty decent place for after-work drinks as it's located right smack in the center of the CBD. The ambience at the rooftop bar is very chill and you get a great view of the Marina Bay area if you get a seat at the edge.Food-wise, I felt the sushi was decent, but if you really like good quality sushi please go elsewhere. It's more bar-food sushi than anything else.Loved their Kinki specials (drinks) though. They were really good! I can't really remember what I ordered but I remember wanting to order more and more.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Kinki is my favorite place for sushi in Singapore for quiet some time now.I like the quality of almost any dish and the service has always been very good and accompanied with a smile. :)One of my favs to order is sashimi and you can bet it is again one of the best I ever had here in Singapore. The price for food is in the upper range which is being compensated by the quality. The environment is nice so far or maybe I have just been lucky. I'm not into the pretentious places and so far Kinki this is not the case at all during my visits.The setup of this venue is ideal be it for a lunch or dinner, meeting or date.I'm not big on drinking a lot when eating sushi however they have a bar there which by itself is worth visiting as well. The pricing is ok, all in ~18$ for a drink.Enjoy ~ !!-s

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Take the lift to the top of Customs House and you'll be greeted by Kinki's bar on the roof top .This trendy place is yuppie paradise. I really like the vibes, as it reminds me of another painfully trendy place in London called Aqua Kyoto. I come here with colleagues after work sometimes. It's a good spot for post-work and farewell drinks. The drinks are OK-ish price wise (a Gin & Tonic costs around $12+++ I think) . I suppose you can expect to pay a little more for the ambience, etc.As Kinki is an open roof top bar, it can get a little warm on some nights. They do have fans etc. to alleviate the warmness though. It's usually busy and crowded. They play good music which sometimes veers on excessively loud to me (maybe I'm getting old?), so expect to do more shouting than talking.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: This place closes at 11.30pm - even on the eve of public holidays! This is what I've learnt when I visited the bar on such a night at 10.30pm. I really liked the roof top concept though and would love to go back and check more of it out. I've also heard good things about the music at the bar. However the closing of the bar at 11.30 is quite the downer, seeing how popular it is with the working crowd. We had to leave to go to Overeasy nearby because of that.The location also overlooks our beautiful Singapore skyline and buildings. The drinks are priced higher than normal but not that astronomical. What I really liked is the vibe and crowd.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Kinki is overpriced, in my opinion. However it's worth checking out if you go for their weekday lunch sets! I got the executive sashimi set for $46. The set came with miso soup, rice, pickles, a fresh salad and a mochi dessert. The strawberry cream mochi wasn't anything great, and the green tea mochi also had a cream and red bean paste within, but I thought the best one was the simple peanut mochi that had no filling.The rice was just normal white rice, so if you want Japanese rice, they charge you more for it. This seems rather outrageous, if you ask me. It's a legitimate japanese restaurant, so they should be serving proper japanese rice! The miso soup was average, salad was very fresh and crisp, but the cream mochi was too creamy so I didn't enjoy it. The sashimi was very fresh though! It was pretty good quality, and there was a wide variety. They have 2 pieces of each type, and one sweet prawn. They even give you 2 pieces of the fatty tuna and scallops, which are pretty premium.The service staff aren't friendly, but they are efficient at filling up your green tea cups and clearing your plates, but they're a miserable looking bunch with nary a smile for anyone.The other saving grace is the view you get overlooking the bay and their chic interior. I really love the strange but interesting light made of black cords and bare light bulbs arranged to look like a chandelier on a low ceiling. Save it for a special lunch date or business lunch meeting, I suppose, but I find that it isn't great value for money here.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Don't let the name mislead you, this restaurant sells good Japanese nosh and good cocktails, and nothing sleazy. The great food will be sure to hit your unami spot. If you are down with a friend, be sure to order a cocktail each. Their mixes are delicious. I will recommend the Ume Mojito.Be sure also to get the Tai Carpaccio, a platter of thinly sliced Snapper topped with truffle sauce and shio konbu. Ok let's skip the fanciful words and read this: fresh sashimi with flavourful truffle = a clear winner. The Pork Belly with Truffle was melt-in-your-mouth lovely and left a aromatic aftertaste swirling in your mouth with the shaved truffle. Plus, indulge in the Fresh Sashimi Platter (with Maguro, Amaebi, Hotate, Hirame, Hamachi and Sake) which features fresh cuts of plump meat, no scrimping there.A word of advice, be down there when you are feeling ready to spend and order without looking at the price list. Also, be sure to grab seats near the wide windows so you can dine with the view of the city skyline.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Graced with one of the sexiest views of Singapore, this aptly named venue is a happy hour haven for post-stressed bevvie mavens!The best tables are almost always booked out. So getting here early ensures you'll get a good use of them before the reservees show up (and sometimes they don't). Best bang for buckets are the Kronenbourg 1664. All iced up you'll be knocking these puppies back whilst you drink in that view and soak up those tasty tunes.This is a bi-monthly stop and it never fails to entertain and delight.The one downside is the toilets are a slow elevator ride away. However, if your wallet is fat the sushi/sashimi located on the same floor is as sexy as the name suggests, so you can always relocate post happy hour tipple!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: It is a nice but compact rooftop bar, located in central area of Singapore.  The view of the Marina Bay is pretty good from all the sides. If you want to grab the best view seats, make sure to reach early (before sunset). Towards the end of evening, the crowd increases and so does the music pace and volume. Food and liquor are both somewhat pricey and menu is limited.Service is pretty slow and laid back. No personal touch, no courtesy, everyone is working like a zombie and doing their thing. Washrooms are located on the ground floor so you have to take the elevator every now and then. Since we were there during the happy hour, we just ordered 1-on-1 beers (1+1 corona and 1+1 1664). I guess, it was a good experience but I wouldn't wanna go their regularly.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Great views and vibes. Unfortunately their customer service is the reason behind my 3 stars. We stopped by for happy hour and although they offer you BOGO you have to order the same drink and they bring it out at the same time. Defeats the purpose if you want a cold beverage. What threw me off guard was how quickly they give you the bill. I understand this prevents customers from walking out to forget to pay but then it is also a turn off to want to buy/purchase more.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
