address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Visited both the bar and restaurant. Very overpriced for above average food, sub standard ambience and staff. We were by the window and it really wasn't that great. Portions are small so you'll need to order quite a bit. Thankfully I had good company or it would be a 1* experience.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Despite the name this place doesnt exude sex...well that depends on the amount of alcohol consumed. But anyways I will touch upon the restaurant and bar separately.   I went to the restaurant for my birthday and I would say it was very good. The food is a but pricey for the amount given but the quality is great. I LOVED the tai carpaccio and truffle rib eye. Also loved the spicy edamame. It had tons of flavor. I consider the sushi to be so so and not really worth the price.  There are plenty of better dishes and the okonomiyaki is not like the japanese varitey at all but is really just a pizza ( but its still good).  I wouldnt come for great japanese food but its dishes are inventive and pretty good with a few misses.The bar above is a really fun spot. I love the atmosphere, the view of the bay, the open air, etc. They also have these great miso pork nachos that are awesome.  Its fun and lively and a great spot to preparty or just hang out for the night.  Its just as good a view as the lantern but half the price.  Definitely on my go to spot for showing friends around singapore

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: My review is solely for the Bar and not the restaurant as I think the restaurant is ehh...for the exorbitant prices you have to pay for good sushi/sashimi.Kinki's Rooftop Bar is just out of this world! In my view, it's the best after-work / happy hour bar in Singapore. Friday nights are simply packed. First off, it's got an amazing view of Marina Bay Sands. Second, they play some fun catchy 80s tunes to get the party going (which brings me back to my old stomping grounds in Murray Hill, NYC)! Third, the drinks are relatively cheap, albeit watered down and/or measured, as is most alcoholic drinks in Singapore (ugh!). Fourth, the crowds are good looking expat working professionals (very few, if any, locals to be found).To conclude, I give this place 5-stars for the atmosphere, but more importantly it's the place where I've met so many of my Singaporean based friends, since moving to this country three yrs ago. I liked it so much that I had my 28th birthday party here!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Overall, this is a good meet up place for casual drinks coz of its central location, good views of the bay and the price of the drinks, there's one for one during happy hour (albeit heavily watered down I suspect).But if you decide to go there, you need to be mindful of all the other imperfections - service was slow and choppy.  During our 4 hours there we had three orders of food and the average waiting time is 40 mins, which is pretty long considering we only ordered snacks like sushi and hand rolls. They have left out certain items in our order until we checked and the food was just ok.  I would say go for the location and the view but nothing more.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: I was contemplating to rate this place with either 3 or 4 stars.There are PROS and CONS:Pros:1. Nice awesome view if you're lucky enough to get window seat2. Small but elegant setting3. Good quality food and fresh sashimi4. Fusion modern Japanese dishes Cons:1. Unfriendly staff 2. A little bit noisy due to small space3. Overpriced4. Tiny portionBest menu so far:Beef tataki (pan seared sliced beef)Tofu steakSeasonal sanma sashimi with ponzu sauce*I personally wouldn't order sashimi because it's overpriced and nothing special about it at this restaurant. However I think if you do eat meat, beef is always a good choice here. :DI'll be coming back to try other things soon! I'll keep you guys posted!Tip:If you don't wanna break your bank, try not to go for a dinner here when you're really starving.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: One of my favourite bars to go to in Singapore for a few reasons.Firstly, you get an amazing view from wherever you are seated within the bar, without having to pay extortionate amounts for drinks and be in a pretentious environment. Kinki is pretty casual, which I really like and if you go early evening, you can catch a really good happy hour. (2 for 1) When they don't have a DJ, they have an awesome setlist of old school R&B jams- which I really enjoy as its very hard to get that anywhere else in Singapore and it goes nicely with the funky, urban style setting of the bar.Bar food is great also. A must visit!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Come here when you are looking for a place to chill with nice view and serves alcohol. It gets very crowded at night though, so naturally it will get very noisy as well. You will have to put an extra effort to hear on what the other person is saying even when he/she is sitting right across you.Not recommending this place as your first date or business meeting venue. Portion-wise the food at this place typically is very tiny. However you could count on that the chef will decorate your meal to make it look very appetizing. Pretty food, pretty view.Last but not least, they do take reservations.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Good food and location. Average cocktails. Disappointed with their cocktails on the rooftop bar. The mango mint seemed to be using a mint flavour instead of real fresh mint. The yuzu martini tasted like an orange soft drink. The bite of martini was missing. And it was not Yuzu at all. At dinner tai carpaccio was awesome. But it was served on a black coloured plate. With out table in a dark corner this otherwise  beautiful dish was not getting the right attention. Rest of the fate like teriyaki chicken, pork belly and tempura etc were good. Salmon spicy sushi was very good.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Excellent view, great folks and very helpful.Reasonably price.  Get there early for good seating

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: I've eaten here many times and even had my 32nd birthday dinner here.  I am crazy for the Spicy Hachimitshu!!  It's like a cucumber martini infused with wasabi.  The sashimi is pretty darn fresh too.  Caution: Extremely pricey menu

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Don't let the name mislead you, this restaurant sells good Japanese nosh and good cocktails, and nothing sleazy. The great food will be sure to hit your unami spot. If you are down with a friend, be sure to order a cocktail each. Their mixes are delicious. I will recommend the Ume Mojito.Be sure also to get the Tai Carpaccio, a platter of thinly sliced Snapper topped with truffle sauce and shio konbu. Ok let's skip the fanciful words and read this: fresh sashimi with flavourful truffle = a clear winner. The Pork Belly with Truffle was melt-in-your-mouth lovely and left a aromatic aftertaste swirling in your mouth with the shaved truffle. Plus, indulge in the Fresh Sashimi Platter (with Maguro, Amaebi, Hotate, Hirame, Hamachi and Sake) which features fresh cuts of plump meat, no scrimping there.A word of advice, be down there when you are feeling ready to spend and order without looking at the price list. Also, be sure to grab seats near the wide windows so you can dine with the view of the city skyline.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: I've been here a couple of times for lunch with friends. Their set lunches, though not cheap, offer good quality food at reasonable prices. We had the nori crusted spicy salmon for $30 which came with a salad, miso soup, rice and mochi dessert. The salmon was of a generous serving, cooked perfectly moist and tender. The mochi dessert is always the highlight of my meal because it's delightfully chewy and fragrant - I wish they'd provide 2 pieces instead of 1 every time. I do find the price of $5 for tea a tad exorbitant but you're paying for a nice view with a relaxing ambience. It can get crowded at lunch if you're in a big group so make reservations on Chope.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: My review is for the rooftop bar. The view is nice but the service is poor. I booked a table for 12 in advance and when we got there on time, half of it was given to another group. When we asked, the waiters were rude and said this was it. Later the other group told us they were given our table and would leave in 30 mins an so we eventually got the table and weren't crammed. The service is super slow, they just ignore you while you try to order. Isn't worth going to for the service, many better options available in Singapore with similar views and price range.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Kinki is overpriced, in my opinion. However it's worth checking out if you go for their weekday lunch sets! I got the executive sashimi set for $46. The set came with miso soup, rice, pickles, a fresh salad and a mochi dessert. The strawberry cream mochi wasn't anything great, and the green tea mochi also had a cream and red bean paste within, but I thought the best one was the simple peanut mochi that had no filling.The rice was just normal white rice, so if you want Japanese rice, they charge you more for it. This seems rather outrageous, if you ask me. It's a legitimate japanese restaurant, so they should be serving proper japanese rice! The miso soup was average, salad was very fresh and crisp, but the cream mochi was too creamy so I didn't enjoy it. The sashimi was very fresh though! It was pretty good quality, and there was a wide variety. They have 2 pieces of each type, and one sweet prawn. They even give you 2 pieces of the fatty tuna and scallops, which are pretty premium.The service staff aren't friendly, but they are efficient at filling up your green tea cups and clearing your plates, but they're a miserable looking bunch with nary a smile for anyone.The other saving grace is the view you get overlooking the bay and their chic interior. I really love the strange but interesting light made of black cords and bare light bulbs arranged to look like a chandelier on a low ceiling. Save it for a special lunch date or business lunch meeting, I suppose, but I find that it isn't great value for money here.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Service was frustratingly slow and the food overpriced for what you get...

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: This place was LEGEND...wait for it...DARY! The view from the roof top bar was phenomenal and though service could have been a tad bit better the food downstairs was amazing (and that's coming from someone who really isn't a seafood fan)! We had platter after platter of some of the best sushi and seafood I have ever had. Definitely try the hot dynamite maki (my personal fave) and the hirame carpaccio. Can't wait to go back!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Like other places over here, Kinki is about the view and the ambience. Where it's a step ahead of its competitors would be its menu. "Ginger and Cumkuat capirinha" sounds fantabulous right. Unfortunately it's beauty was in name only. Watered down overpriced drinks and inattentive staff means  I wont be coming back.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Literally the worst restaurant ever. Came from Canada and Ireland to visit friends working in Singapore. Thought the menu looked good online and the location was so central. Terrible service - took at least 20 minutes to bring a drink and the waitress with the dyed blue hair was extremely rude. She had an attitude and did not want to serve us. It was also very hard to track down anyone to ask questions about the menu or even take our order. When we finally got someone to help us, they told us the wrong info as we asked for example how many pieces of sushi comes with the Kinki Customs and he said two when infact it was 6 when it came out. My one friend waited for over an hour for her vegetarian pizza without any apology. She also asked for the meat one without a topping and they told her it was already made so it can't be changed. When the food came out, they just placed it in the middle of the table and left without saying what it was or even putting it in front of the person who ordered. Terrible service just seriously the worst. The food also was mediocre and extremely overpriced. Would NOT be returning ever. Don't go here it is not worth it.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: It's a pretty decent place for after-work drinks as it's located right smack in the center of the CBD. The ambience at the rooftop bar is very chill and you get a great view of the Marina Bay area if you get a seat at the edge.Food-wise, I felt the sushi was decent, but if you really like good quality sushi please go elsewhere. It's more bar-food sushi than anything else.Loved their Kinki specials (drinks) though. They were really good! I can't really remember what I ordered but I remember wanting to order more and more.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Kinki is my favorite place for sushi in Singapore for quiet some time now.I like the quality of almost any dish and the service has always been very good and accompanied with a smile. :)One of my favs to order is sashimi and you can bet it is again one of the best I ever had here in Singapore. The price for food is in the upper range which is being compensated by the quality. The environment is nice so far or maybe I have just been lucky. I'm not into the pretentious places and so far Kinki this is not the case at all during my visits.The setup of this venue is ideal be it for a lunch or dinner, meeting or date.I'm not big on drinking a lot when eating sushi however they have a bar there which by itself is worth visiting as well. The pricing is ok, all in ~18$ for a drink.Enjoy ~ !!-s

What better place to reintroduce my tongue to Japanese than the uber-swanky new Japanese restaurant Kinki.  The place is decorated with koi acrylic floor paintings, Oishinbo inspired food portraits on the walls, and very low furniture making it seems futuristic and modern. Also the view is breathtaking.I had the edamame (salted to perfection), vegetable tempura (best I've ever had), and pomegranate miso black cod while my companions stuck mostly to sushi.  The sashimi we saw coming out of the kitchen made me drool by the way.  All of the food was spectacular and obviously was washed down with sake.  I would just caution that the miso was just barely cooked which I'm sure is the method de jour but I am just barely adult enough to handle undercooked fish.  Stick with the raw stuff if this bothers you too.  The sushi I was able to sneak off my husband's plate was fun and inventive and really tasty.At present the clientele is mostly older business gentleman. I suggest we turn this around and make it a haunt for the younger foodie crowd.  You won't be disappointed.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: This is for the roof top bar only. Great view of the waterfront and of MBS, great happy hour, great crowd, great location. What more can you ask for. We had the fried chicken and it was crispy and delightful, albeit a bit expensive.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Utterly Disappointed - i had the worst Singapore dining experience here the other night. Sorry to say this as Kinki has a cool vibe and a nice rooftop where i've taken guests in the past. I thought the staff was poorly trained and the dine-in policies bizarre and inflexible. Suffice to say, I wont be going back.I attended my friends birthday party at Kinki where she reserved a table for 20 from 6 - 9 PM. My partner and I arrived about 1 hour late and at that time the table (for 14) that was given to us was over-packed already. We noticed that the table for four next to our large party was available and I asked to sit there so we could be close to the birthday party. We were told by the wait-staff that the table was reserved. Ok no issues, we were only 2 people and didnt want to take up the larger table so we asked to sit at a 2 person table in the vicinity of the party. Again, that table was reserved. We then approached the manager and told them of our situation: we had a party for 20 but were seated in a 14 person table but we arrived late and the wait staff wont let us sit at the tables nearby. So how?The manager let us know at that point that the entire restaurant was booked for the night. Perplexed, I looked around the restaurant of (im estimating) 30 tables and only 8 of them were occupied. As we were with the large birthday party, i inquired if could eat quickly at any one of the reserved tables before the parties arrived and was told that we could not as the tables were reserved. I then asked what time the people were coming for their reservation for the tables near the birthday party and were told that she didnt know. Then I asked since they didnt know, if we could eat and if the party came, they could be seated at another one of the 15 open two seater tables. Again, I got the "cannot sir". I asked her "so you are telling me that we are here for a birthday party already eating, you have 75% of your restaurant unoccupied and you are not letting us eat". The only reply i got was sorry the restaurant is reserved. I thought this was odd, and we were left awkwardly hovering near the birthday party table for about 10 minutes while they hurriedly finished eating. At that point we were told by the birthday girl that we had a reservation upstairs at the bar and that they had some bar snacks that we could eat. We hovered and waited for critical mass to finish eating and headed up stairs to the open air bar area. Despite a reservation for 20, Kinki gave us a table to seat 4 but was in the corner so we had some standing room only spots. We ordered a few bottles with all the mixers and ice buckets so there was little room for us to order food to eat. I asked the bar wait-staff, if we could sit at the table next to ours so that we could order some bar food to eat. Again, that table was reserved. Looking around there was our party of 18-20, and about 8 other people in the rooftop bar area and about 15 open tables. I asked the wait staff what time the table was reserved for and he said 10pm. Looking down at my watch, it was only 8 so i asked him to give us the seat for 30 mins so we could quickly eat and then we would go back to the original table. He said, sorry the table was reserved and walked away. However, he then came back a few minutes later and nicely said okay we could site there for an hour. Another wait-staff took our order and being vegetarian I ordered the Vegetarian Okonomiyaki. He told me that the Okonomiyaki was not available. There weren't many vegetarian bar snack options so I asked if i could order from the restaurant menu. "No, you cannot". I asked where the bar snacks were being prepared and he answered "the restaurant downstairs". Odd... I told him nevermind and that I ordered a drink. When he came to bring my drink he apologized and told me that the Okonomiyaki was available so I confirmed the Okonomiyaki order.The vegetarian Okonomiyaki was brought out abut 30 mins later and it wasnt Okonomiyaki looking at all. It was mayonaise atop toasted bread but wasnt bad tasting until I bit into something that tasted like chicken. At this point i was about to lose my sh*t. I asked my meat eating friends if it tasted like chicken and 2 out of 3 agreed. I approached the wait staff and  told them annoyingly that they had served me meat on a vegetarian dish. The wait-staff shook his head violently and flapped his arms up and said looking even more annoyed than me, "that was vegetarian". They sent another wait-staff who confirmed that it was mozzarella cheese. I never really knew mozzarella cheese and chicken could be so easily confused and let my friends eat the rest of my dish. No dinner for me after 3 hours of trying, thanks Kinki!

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Take the lift to the top of Customs House and you'll be greeted by Kinki's bar on the roof top .This trendy place is yuppie paradise. I really like the vibes, as it reminds me of another painfully trendy place in London called Aqua Kyoto. I come here with colleagues after work sometimes. It's a good spot for post-work and farewell drinks. The drinks are OK-ish price wise (a Gin & Tonic costs around $12+++ I think) . I suppose you can expect to pay a little more for the ambience, etc.As Kinki is an open roof top bar, it can get a little warm on some nights. They do have fans etc. to alleviate the warmness though. It's usually busy and crowded. They play good music which sometimes veers on excessively loud to me (maybe I'm getting old?), so expect to do more shouting than talking.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: This place closes at 11.30pm - even on the eve of public holidays! This is what I've learnt when I visited the bar on such a night at 10.30pm. I really liked the roof top concept though and would love to go back and check more of it out. I've also heard good things about the music at the bar. However the closing of the bar at 11.30 is quite the downer, seeing how popular it is with the working crowd. We had to leave to go to Overeasy nearby because of that.The location also overlooks our beautiful Singapore skyline and buildings. The drinks are priced higher than normal but not that astronomical. What I really liked is the vibe and crowd.

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Service wasn't great but 1 for 1 happy hour is not bad and the view is good. Chill atmosphere but a little cramped in my opinion. Nice place to meet people though

address: 70 Collyer Quay #02-02 Customs House Singapore 049323 Singapore
comment: Kinki is one of my favourite places for a date. It's the perfect balance between casual and chi-chi, yet also trendy with a great vibe with good service and a view of the water.Food : Ooh I love the foie gras and scallop sushi! Totally melts in my mouth. Also really like the wagyu aburi sushi, salmon belly aburi sushi, unagi and anago sushi as well as the botan ebi and uni aburi sushi ... all pretty tasty! We also really like the momotaro tomato with ginger dressing and snow crab, organic tofu and century egg with ponzu sauce and ginger. The grilled black cod marinated in Kinki pomegranate-honey miso served with braised gobo and scallions is supposed to be a Kinki specialty, but we thought it was just so-so. The wagyu ribeye cooked over cast iron seasoned with truffle sauce was pretty good as was the pan seared kurobuta pork belly served with Kinki's spicy sesame sauce. We were not impressed by the Kinki okonomiyaki, i.e. a Japanese styled pizza of Hokkaido scallops, prawns,apple wood smoked bacon, sweet onions and mozzarella. Kinki doesn't have a wide selection of desserts so we tried the most exotic sounding one i.e. the Oreo Sesame, which is black sesame ice-cream blended with Oreo cookies. Predictably it was a bit too sweet and heavy.Ambience : Love it love it love itService : Pleasant, welcoming and efficientPrices are a bit steep but the fusion sushi is great.

address: 18 Raffles Quay Lau Pa Sat Festival Market Singapore 048582 Singapore
comment: This is located in the Lau Pa Sat Hawker Center located near Raffles place. Hawkers Centers are the bread and butter of clean delicious Singapore street food. As I ran down the list of must try food in Singapore, having some Char Kway Teow was on the top of my list. Char Kway Teow are a type of fried noodles with soy sauce and usually complimented with a protein of choice. The chef was kind enough to substitute chicken for seafood that was not on the menu. The price was around 5 SGD dollars which comes out to about $3-4 dollar USD. The portions were generous and tasted authentic. You can watch the chef make your meal as it gets delivered to you. Seating was plentiful and you never really have to wait.

address: 18 Raffles Quay Lau Pa Sat Festival Market Singapore 048582 Singapore
comment: Part of La Pau Sat festival market food hawker. Punggol mee goreng sounded so exotic and just flowed over the top of my tongue so dramatically, but unfortunately it was just as dramatically flavorless & disappointing! Adding chili paste from Thunder Rice helped, so add away!! So much for my first Singapore hawker experience. Hopefully I'll learn the art of hawking by the time I'm back next wk!

address: 18 Raffles Quay Lau Pa Sat Festival Market Singapore 048582 Singapore
comment: For those working around the Raffles Place area, I'm sure you've been for lunch at Lau Pa Sat at least once, and its mostly because it's the one common coffee shop that has a large mix of local and overseas food stores for a reasonable price. One of the most top selling stalls is Lai Heng, which is a stall run by an aunty and a few of her sons. The Kway Tiao served here is one of the best that I've tasted, as it's not too dry with a good amount of sauce that isn't just water added at the end of preparing the dish. The noodle used is soft and thick, and they found a way of frying it such that it doesn't disintegrate or break up into tiny pieces in the wok. This means it's a lot easier to eat without having to literally scoop bits and pieces into your mouth, and also you get more flavor while chewing it instead of tasting more of the egg and pork lard used as seasoning. My only gripe is how slow the service sometimes is, and how the aunty always seems to get at least 1 in 5 orders mixed up, resulting in even more delay trying to figure out what went wrong. But people do make mistakes, and people do grow old. At least the wait was worth it!

address: 18 Raffles Quay Lau Pa Sat Festival Market Singapore 048582 Singapore
comment: I first heard of Lai Heng char kway teow from a local food blogger, as one of the old char kway teow families who have passed down the tradition for up to 4 generations. There were no spritely char kway teow nympths to greet me upon my visit to the lau par sat outlet, however - but that did not stop the food from tasting good. Firstly, note that Lau Par Sat is, by its location and set-up, very much geared towards the tourist crowd. Hence expect higher prices and less authentic food quality. I was pleasantly surprised, therefore, that my $3.50 netted me a rather large portion of the local dish. I felt the char kway teow was well-fried, with just the right amount of sweet sauce. The cockles, while fresh and plump, were few and far between, however. What gives this just an average score, in my opinion, is the lack of a distinct "wok" flavor one would find from the best of the best CKT stores. Nonetheless, it's definitely worth checking out if you are in the area.

Okay so can we please make a deal that we will NEVER let this place close or go out of business? This place is the best on so many levels. This is your neighbourhood bodega, your one stop shop, your deli, your place for a candy bar craving or batteries or panadol that you suddenly need. It has EVERYTHING. Don't let the small space fool you. Cold beer? Got it. Champagne at unbelievable prices? Got it. Fresh fruit and veg? Got that too! I was beyond happy to find this place. In our four years of living in an area where establishments change rapidly, I haven't been as attached to a place and as invested in making sure it stays afloat as this place. I love that they remember me and my children, that they help me when I can't get my massive stroller between the tiny aisles, that they always pick up the phone and tell me if something is in stock, that they deliver cases of beer if you live in one of the buildings nearby, and that they don't hike prices up (although they could judging by where they are and that they're one of a kind). P.S. their sandwiches are DELICIOUS!

When I lived at the Sail, I visited this place probably 4-5 times a week. This location is run by a family that is super friendly, always smiling, and remembers my name.  They are your typical convenient store with wine (decent prices) chips, candy, your basic food items (milk, bread, ect) but they also do some really tasty sandwiches and wraps.  My favorite is the tuna salad in which you can choose your bread.  $7 :)  They also carry little things like chia seeds, and fruit plates, and random hard to find healthy bars, ect.  Good prices, good service, and conventinet.

address: 121 Telok Ayer St #01-01 Stall 7 Singapore 068590 Singapore
comment: Anyway from the other two large hawker areas at Telok Ayer (right around the corner from the metro station) is an authentic and good tasking Malaysian Nasi Lemak place.  The spice on it defineity has some kick to it and the rice and chicken was well prepared and fresh.

address: 24 Raffles Place #b1-01/10 Clifford Centre Singapore 048621 Singapore
comment: Chain serving a Turkish-Mexican inspired menu of kebabs wraps, burritos and bowls. Great consistent quality of food and very reasonably priced. Take away only. It's my go to place for lunch most days when I don't bring food to work. My favorite is the chicken kebab with Mayo cucumber.

Really liked the ambience of the place! Visited on a Tuesday evening & it was busy but not annoyingly loud. It doesn't hurt that the staff were very friendly too! Got the fresh tagliatelle & a cup of chai latte- I frankly expected more from the tagliatelle but the chai latte was very enjoyable. A wonderful blend of cream & spice. I'll definitely be back, maybe not for the food, but for that chai latte!

The cafe was located just a 5 minutes walk from the MRT station. The place was packed during weekend with limited indoor and outdoor dining in area. They ran out of bread soon after I ordered. Remember to collect a poker card number tag after making payment.Omelette with cheddar, mushrooms & onions ($21)Served in a metal plate, with a slice of bread underneath.A bit tough to slice the bread. The omelette left behind a layer of oil. Somehow reminded one of pan fried egg with onions at home with its char edges. Could not taste the cheddar in it.Latte ($5)Quite rich with a slightly chocolaty and bitter taste.Overall the food was not bad. Place was crowded and quite noisy too.

It's my 50th review! , Sarnies definitely brings me back to Australia. From the décor, to the vibe, to the food - rustic, unpretentious and delicious with the use of fresh ingredients, portion is HUGE and the coffee is good. The cafe concept is hassle free too. Just walk straight to the counter, grab the menu and order right there. You will be given a card which is also your order number so grab a table and the friendly staff will bring your food over once it's ready. If the weather is not crazily hot, I will always opt to sit outside, away from the open kitchen inside the café. I came here twice - first on a busy weekday for lunch and second on a quieter weekend brunch. The sandwiches here are to die for and totally value for money. On the first visit, I had the smoked salmon sandwich while my boss had the steak with mushroom and caramelised onions sandwich, both selling at $13.90 and $15.50, respectively. Both sandwiches came with generous portion of filling (mine with lots of smoked salmon pieces on creamy dill sauce) and it sure filled me up until dinner. Unfortunately, the sandwiches are only available on weekdays and they have an entire different menu on weekend and dinner. On my second visit, it was a Saturday post gym brunch with my friend. I ordered the smoked salmon (again!) and scrambled eggs served on sourdough, while my friend ordered bacon and egg served on a mini baguette. While the dishes were executed perfectly, I thought the price was slightly on a higher side for brunch food. We paid almost $30 each for a main and a drink, hence I minus one star for this review. Even the dinner price ranges from $10 to $15 only. That's bizarre when it should be the other way around.  The café is open every day - Mon to Fri until 9pm, and weekends until 4pm, so swing by if you're around the area and give it a try. I'm sure you'll like it as much as I do.

Sarnies - Known in my neck of the woods (Straya) as a sanger or sambo - is a cute nickname the Brits have given to sandwiches.And Sarnies is a great incarnation of this moniker in Singapore. The sandwiches are cute and tasty and served fresh even during the rushiest of lunchtime rushes.My companion and I couldn't go past the steak sarnie. Let's face it, who can?This bad boy features grass fed cut steak, amazing sautéed mushrooms, onion, mixed greens and an in-house tangy steak sauce to round out all those flavours.To finish up we shared the Coconut cocowhip (think low-fat ice cream/yoghurt) which was a perfect end to the meal to cleanse the palate and refresh us both from the simmering SG heat.For a lunchtime haunt Sarnies is highly recommended. Just be ready for the queues and the no-available-tables blues! (You snooze you lose!)

I came here at 11am for lunch on a weekday and the service was very fast! Ordered, paid, sat down at a table and my sandwich came out within a few minutes. I ordered the Tandoori Chicken Sandwich and it was very delicious. The bread was nice and soft, with a rougher crust. The chicken was very tasty and the yogurt dressing tasted like the yogurt from Indian restaurants. Overall the sandwich read really tasty. I can only comment on coming for lunch before the crowd, but it's perfect at this time and I would definitely come back. My foodie coworker says the Grass Fed Steak sandwich was really good, so I will try that one next time.

Did a take away for lunch and dinner, so I got the aubergine and hummus sandwich for lunch and pesto chicken salad for dinner.The lunch crowd was still strong at 2pm so I ordered and came back to collect. Staff remembers faces so you don't have to keep your receipt, very convenient for people in a hurry.The aubergine and hummus sandwich had a generous spread of hummus on both side of the bread, and the aubergine was cooked until soft and tender. Overall the sandwich was huge and tasty, I could have this everyday if I were a vegan.The pesto salad was even better. Maybe I just needed some meat! The chicken breast was nicely cooked and mixed with the pesto dressing so it was not dry at all. The mixed greens inside was coated with olive oil which we'll complemented the pesto dressing. Definitely a big portion that can fill you as a meal!

I really wanted to like this cute hole-in-the-wall gem with the whole package of dim lighting, exposed kitchen, cute decor, large tables...but it was unfortunately quite subpar for dinner, at least. If I come here again (though I probably will not), id just get coffee & hang out here! Seating is limited as mentioned in other Yelp reviews with 2 longer benches & tables seating 6 ppl, and a few more tables for 2. Service was friendly, and the iced latte ($5) I ordered was good!! It had a strong espresso taste, the way I like it. The food unfortunately was lacklustre. We ordered 2 Thai disco spaghetti & 2 aglio olio. I expected a fusion dish of Thai basil beef with pasta but unfortunately it wasn't great. The texture of the spaghetti was kind of rubbery, and perhaps another type of pasta would be better suited to enhance the taste more. The beef was the sort of minced beef in bolognese, and was quite salty. The spiciness and vaguely tom-yum taste was there, but that was all. From trying my friend's portion, the aglio olio seemed pretty solid and garlicky with a generous serving of prawns, so perhaps it's the better choice. Another table ordered the satay chicken and it was three sizable slabs of grilled chicken (with no sides though). We also tried to use the Entertainer 1 for 1 app for main courses, and they only allowed 1 use of it I.e only 1 dish was free for the 4 of us (not 2 dishes).

The food is good, but you better confirm the prices before ordering. Today they had a list of lunch specials - 3 salads at $16, and a Chef Special. As these items were advertised in the same side of the wall - weekly lunch specials - and there is no price for the Chef Special, I asumed it was also $16. The price was $19 - written nowhere - and they have no paper or iPad menus. And when you ask why there is a price difference they tell you oh this item is $19, no apologizes. The customer is expected to guess and agree with the price. I did not appreciate this experience.

Phenomenal cafe & coffee shop in the heart of Telok Ayer. And in a country where pleasant service is often lacking (sorry SG, I still love ya) the staff here is ALWAYS pleasant, happy, and up for a fun conversation. Love this spot. Oh, and they play great music on the regular.

Sarnies is a small coffee shop next to a relatively busy road. The coffee is excellent, and all drinks are made with real foods (eg the ginger ale is made with real ginger). The staff are polite and quick, and the coffee art is excellent. The food and drinks menu are full of variety and can bend to any taste. However, it is small, and you can easily walk straight past it. Heck, we almost did. Inside, it's a bit dim in terms of lighting, and it's a bit cramped so it's best to sit outside. The seating is a bit uncomfortable, but is easy to sit in long enough that it shouldn't be too much of a problem. A pretty good spot for a quick coffee, but probably not best to stay for a long time. Smokers will sometimes smoke near the area, but it doesn't happen often. Definitely recommend it.

This place is without a doubt one of the best brunch places in Singapore. The cafe has a really small and cozy indoor dining area which can be a little claustrophobic at their peak period. But fret not, their outdoor dining area is pretty spacious and being located along Telok Ayer Street, you get to appreciate the well-restored, heritage shop-houses that lined the street as your dining view.When I'm there, I get my usual Bacon & Egg Sarnie with Tomato Relish with an add-on of Avocado! The combination of all that is just heavenly (I am even thinking about it right now as I'm typing this!). The serving is really generous; if you're a female, you could easily share it with another girlfriend of yours. Some of the other recommended dishes will be the Either the Homemade Granola or Pancakes with Berries, Honey and Greek Yoghurt.And before I forget, their coffee is fantastic too so don't missed that out! I'm can't wait to go back there again for brunch already. x
Great coffee and friendly crew. Coffee here never disappoints. Plus in the evenings they serve cocktails. Nice range of healthy dishes and gluten-free ones too!

Great place for brunch....if it was raining. Suuuuper small location but I gotta admit I love the food. To start, they know how to cook BACON!!! Which is FRIGGIN RARE! They big breakfast or whatever they call it was a awesome plate of food. Prices are crazy high but at least portions can claim to justify it. They serve a good cup of coffee and overall is a great place for a nice brunch or brekkie. The place is so small you most likely won't get a seat if you came in a group of three or more. Prices are no joke so make sure you already got this month's pay in the bank before you head down there!
Not my first time here. But unfortunately the quality go down. Service size of food, and coffee. But only the price increase. Too much success !? Anyway and bit sad :(

Ever since i moved to telok ayer for work, I notice there is always a lot of people enjoying their coffee outside Sarnies when I walk to work in the morning.  Putting aside the question of why so many people can have a sit-down breakfast during normal working hours on a weekday, I am curious about Sarnies' breakfast offerings. I have allowed my curiosity to build up until one morning last week when I found myself particularly free and decided to venture inside Sarnies.As i pushed the door and stepped in, I seem to have walked from Telok Ayer to England, perhaps some cute little cafe in East London. I could not help notice that the overwhelming majority of the clientele is angmoh and just a second ago, I was surrounded by the laughter of uncles enjoying their kopi at the kopitiam next door so wow! that was a bit unexpected.The set up is simple, there is a huge counter where you order and get your food and drinks and then a few tables and chairs against the wall and filling up the rest of the limited space.  A lot of people seem to opt for the outdoor seats which is a pretty good spot for people watching on the busy strip of telok ayer.  Having quickly scanned the menu on the board, I decided to get the salmon cream cheese bagel since I have not had a bagel for a while (actually never in Singapore to be accurate).  I was a bit disappointed that I could not choose the type of bagel. It is definitely not cheap, my bagel came at a cost of almost S$10 and with a flat white that brings the total damage to 14. I mean, to be fair, the bagel is huge and if you are willing to pay 10 for a sandwich in the cbd this is acceptable but still, $14 for breakfast seems a bit on the high side.  I opted to bring my bagel back to the office since the place is too packed.  Delighted to find that they have taken the time to wrap my bagel up in foil so by the time I sat down at my desk and opened the wrapping, it's still nice and warm.  The bagel itself is pretty good, soft and smooth cream cheese that blends well with the salmon and the portion is quite generous.  I really enjoyed it so quality wise I cannot complain. I heard their brunch menu is pretty good so will come back and try.

I have some mixed feelings about this place.The cafe is in a prime spot of telok ayer, a cute little street with loads of character and just an overall pleasant part of SG.The outdoor seating is definitely preferable, as it can get VERY cramped inside.Food: the food is good, but I think it's definitely too pricey for what it is. I have tried both the Caesar salad (good yoghurty dressing with some herbs) and the Halloumi salad (too salty!) here, and I have heard the bread is great too.  The Caesar portion is large but I still do not think it is worth the price, unless you're itching to spend $15-$17 for a salad! My main concern with this place is that the last time I ate here (had the Halloumi salad), I got food poisoning!  Regardless of their fancy spins on salads, I don't think I will risk it again and definitely not for the exorbitant cost!

Always decent coffee. But the thing though, is this; you hire young hipster wannabes that make eye contact upon you walking up to the counter and don't follow up with taking an order. Apparently it's cool to be snobbish. This was on a lazy weekday evening with a thinning crowd and not much going on. Stood there for almost 4 minutes. Just me. No one else. Looks like my friendly smile was too much and too uncool for these punk ass kids. I'll take my business elsewhere, thank you very much. I hear "FREE THE ROBOT" makes decent coffee around the corner. I work around here and tend to drink a lot of coffee. Wait up for a review.

Came here after work on a mission to fulfill a sudden craving for Caesar salad, and... Missed the day menu by 2 hours (I was there at 6). But the dessert special (churros) convinced me to stay. It's one of those treats that are so difficult to find in Singapore that I always jump at the chance to try some whenever the opportunity arises, although previous attempts have been somewhat dismal.Churros took a bit long to arrive (from my seat facing the kitchen, it seemed as though this applied to all the food in general) but exceeded my expectations. For just $8 (disclaimer: I consider any reasonably-sized dessert priced below $25 affordable.... Unless its just a slice of cake), I got 5 large sticks of churros. These were nice and crisp on the outside and perfectly moist within, substantial but not too dense. It came with a generous cup of chocolate sauce for dipping in, and some salt at the side. Tip: dip the churros in the chocolate, then dab on a bit of salt. The interplay between the sweet and savory flavours when you do that makes the dessert so much more interesting!Appreciated the service, I was there alone and the staff went out of their way to make me feel welcome, by engaging me in polite conversation and constantly checking if there was something else I needed (and sharing their thoughts about the churros!) Although the cafe was getting crowded, not once did I feel like I was being rushed to complete my meal.Will return soon for the sarnies and that elusive Caesar salad!

Had the matcha and regular brownies which are both very tasty, though they are on the sweeter side. The cafe is quite small, but pretty cozy. There are also ample seats outdoors which is great for those who want a little more space to breathe. Will definitely go back to try their brunch items.

Yum! We arrived here just before they closed in between lunch and dinner. Though I only had the yogurt, fruit and muesli I was happy with the quality and coffee and enjoyed a few bites of my fellow diners sandwich. Good for a quick lunch.

A very Australian reminiscent spot not just in name, but in coffee and sarnies (sambos, sammies, sandwiches.... whatever you want to call it) too. The sandwiches are MASSIVE with each bread slice the equivalent of 3 normal slices of bread I estimated. Hence the $12-15 price tag. I recommend sharing a sandwich and having heard rave reviews about the brownie, sharing a sweet 'something-something' too. My roast chicken sandwich was yummy, with LOTS of chicken. I wish the guacamole was a bit more chunky than thinly spread, but hey you win some you lose some. The chicken schnitz and also the ham sarnies looked appealing. Soups and salads too.My flat white was pretty damn good. $5 a pop. Have to walk kind of through the kitchen to get to the toilets, which is a bit naff, but it's a small shop... service is fast and friendly. I'll definitely go back if I'm craving a blemmin good sandwich or carbo loading for a marathon (who am I kidding, only the former).

It was my first time at Sarnies and it certainly lived up to the high praise from my friend. I ordered the bacon, eggs and tomato relish breakfast sarnie and a white coffee. Everything is made in-house including the bread, roasting of coffee beans, relish, bacon etc. The sandwich came and it was humongous!!! I was a little worried I won't be able to finish it but when I took one bite, I knew I'd finish the whole thing (and I did!). The sarnie was AMAZE-BALLS! The bread was crispy on the outside and light and fluffy on the inside. The bacon...oh my word...the bacon was all kinds of yummy! It was crispy without being oily and was sweet & savory at the same time. Best. Bacon. Ever. The tomato relish brought the whole sarnie together. The white coffee was delicious. It packed a flavor punch without having the typical bitter aftertaste of coffee.  All in all, what a great food experience! My friend raved about the pesto. I can't wait to go back and try that!

This is a great sandwich joint (serves other foods as well) that serves awesome and wholesome sandwiches with fresh ingredients and most importantly at very affordable prices. My favourite has got to be the steak because they added mustard and makes the meal so tangy and yummy especially with my favourite mushrooms too.Moving on to desserts, the brown little square of brownie is my favourite as it is so chewy and full of flavour, and they sized it just right so you would not get sick of the cake after awhile. Best of all it is not too sweet, just the right amount of chocolate and sweetness.Overall i think they sell value for money food with the right portion and price. Very good choice for a good dinner.
My favorite place in the area, hands down. Nice outdoor seating, very chill. Has alcohol, food, coffee, sandwich. Very good for groups with different preferences! And such friendly folk :))))

I love Sarnies. The bread is great, the sandwiches are huge, the salads are substantial, the breakfast is spot-on. The only thing I don't love is the (slightly) expensive nature of the dishes...$20+  for a brunch entree? Sigh... But I can't knock off a star for this because I still keep coming back. The food delivers, and the service is way above-par for Singapore, especially for a casual spot.My favorites include:- Pesto chicken salad (I have this for lunch on a weekly basis)- Brunch muesli bowl with yogurt and honey (it is to DIE for)- Steak sandwich (or any of the sandwiches, really)The Sarnies folk have also been kind enough to put together a hodgepodge of side dishes into one breakfast entree for me: scrambled eggs, sliced tomato, grilled mushrooms, avocado, and the fabulous Sarnies toasted bread. Best breakfast I've had in a long while.

First time here, but no photo can be post, because the experience here was not so nice. Ordered breakfast..... 2 sunny side up eggs, bacon, sausage and mushrooms. Eggs were over cook and become tough, bacon was dry and too salty. Then coffee was low end one. Sorry I would not recommend to my friends
Interesting place. Quite a short food menu but it has wonderful atmosphere. Aussie joint

I've been to Sarnies now, and with my office just around the corner, I'll probably be back a few more times. Prices a little steep. A sandwich or salad ranges from about $13-$15, and an iced tea is a staggering $7. That said, the sandwiches and salads that I've had have been HUGE. Like, too big to put in your mouth HUGE for the sandwich (yeah that's what she said) and I was surprised I was STILL EATING HUGE for the salad. So I've seen the steak sandwich, the roast chicken sandwich, and the chicken pesto salad first hand, and they're all huge. A main in and of themselves huge. Worth the price? Ehmmmmm close. Portions wise definitely, quality wise really on the border definitely.I highly recommend the pesto chicken salad. Chicken pesto salad. Whatever. There're mushrooms, pesto, TONS of chicken, plenty of greens, cherry tomatoes, and a big slab of bread. You'll notice I've been using a lot of capitalisation in this review. Portions here just FEEL LIKE THAT. IN YOUR FACE. As for their $7 iced teas, it's pricey, but they are quite delicious. The green tea with honey and ginger, the orange with cinnamon are both subtly flavoured and very thirst-quenching. Okay, a little wallet hurting, but I like iced tea so I've usually been able to convince myself that it's worth it. (It's not, not really... I'm really good at lying to myself.)The coffee's decent, but the staff. The staff are friendly, and really cool. They really try to engage you, they make sure to smile, and it really feels like they're having fun as they work through the lunch crush. So if you're in the area and a little stumped for what to eat, I'd give Sarnies a try. They're a little pricey, but it's a very very pleasant experience.
Fresh food with good portions meant that as a work lunch spot Sarnies excelled. I will definitely be back, there are so many yummy things on the menu

Sarnies was recommended by many friends before i eventually went to it. I wasn't wowed. The best friend's soba salad was really jnsubstantial, mangoes were sour and. I'm not too. Sure how it could constitue a hearty salad. My greek salad was mot well spun resulting in alot of water in the bowl, making the vegetable soggy and unpleasant. However, the service was commendable. We reflected the problems, and they were taken back, and replaced. We even had a free muffin on the house with a staff checking if the replacement was okay.Perhaps it wasn't a good day that we had visited since most items sold out by the time we reached there. It does have alot potential though, and i would try it again if i were in the area.

ZOMG. How did I not know that Yelp had hit the shores of Singers? Well, this can only mean one thing -- I'm returning with a vengeance!!!! To commemorate, today's lunch choice gets a bit of Yelp love... if only because I'm currently wired from the espresso and happily chomping down on my chicken pesto salad from Sarnie's. Just take it as I'm in a good mood. This cozy little shop is a reliable lunch spot -- with classic salads and sandwiches to get your mid-day fix. The bread is addictively good so don't complain when your sandwiches come with massive slabs -- you'll thank them, I promise. Oh, they make their own coffee blend -- so a perfect caffeine fix for the sleep-deprived. Staff is friendly so even when it gets busy, you never seem to mind. The steady stream of expat regulars seems to attest to this. I'm fast becoming one of them.

Sarnies is a cute sandwich shop along Telok Ayer Street. Since opening almost a year ago, the place has really grown and has a strong following with the office crowd around the neighborhood, most of whom are expats. They serve great breakfasts here. Try their homemade muesli with vanilla yogurt. The yogurt is super yummy and made with real vanilla pods. Lunch can get pretty crowded here and they have a variety of sandwiches served on brown or white bread. They even sell alcohol here and after work, they serve some bar food like quesadillas They also recently started serving brunch during the weekends, which I have yet to try. Staff here is super friendly as well, and really get to know the customers.
Recommended to me by a mate, had a roast chicken salad with guacamole and was very impressed. Will definitely be returning. Great coffee as well and near my office. Win
i would eat the roast chicken sandwich again... and again. comes with the crispy house-cured bacon, flavourful chicken and a darn good bread. (rustic white and good solid bite)
I was in a bit of a rush so only had a coffee which was very nice, smooth with a good flavour. Good atmosphere being so close to cbd. I'll def come back and try the food as the menu looked good.

Delicious Korean/Chinese-style food. Jjangmyun (black bean noodles), sweet & sour pork.Forgot to order dumplings this time but saw them at other tables. Looked super appetizing. Recommended by a friend and it did not disappoint.Go check it out!

As all Korean restaurants do, Dong Bang Hong offers massive quantities of food that comes in a set menu for both lunch and dinner. The great thing about these restaurants is how they have private booths for large groups of 6-10. I would recommend it for corporate gatherings like a normal lunch or a farewell do! Very private with quick and efficient service. There is a good mix of local and Korean staff, so no fear of any awkward gesturing and language barriers during your meal. It's located just nearby Raffles Place which means a mostly office crowd and and quiet atmosphere for lunch. But it does get rowdy during Fridays and dinners, we all know how alcohol is never missing from the table at Korean gatherings! 2 main items that are a 'must-try' would be the Jjajjangmyeong (Bean Sauce Noodles) and their Seafood Soup Noodles. Both feature their signature slick and bouncy hand cut noodles that keeps you digging at the bowl even with a full stomach!
A place for classic Korean food. No surpise.

Excellent jajangmyun and tangsooyuk. We have been here twice, and have left fully satisfied both times. I'm hesitant to try other Korean Chinese restaurants since I'll regret going to an inferior place. There are other interesting items on the menu, but I hardly vary my order when dining in a Korean Chinese place since I come craving for jajangmyun. We did try a cold beef appetiser the last time and it was excellent, although pricey.
Very solid Korean-Chinese food.  The classics would be noodles in black bean sauce and sweet and sour pork.

Can't speak for the food but the drinks and the service were phenomenal. Came in by myself on a Friday night and there was a fairly large crowd. The bartender served me in less than five minutes so that speaks to their efficiency. Even though they didn't have my favorite whiskey they still managed a stiff drink that was totally work the $17 bucks. Besides when the view is of the Marina Bay sands how can you complain?

Great American comfort food in the heart of the Financial District is a nice getaway from the hussle and bussle. You get a great 180 view of the water and the milkshakes are great and delirious here. The only down side with the area is that it's hard to seat more than 5 people. The tables are configureable, but I would go to this place during lunch. If they have a dinner menu, I would be interested, but for now their food tends to lean towards the lunch/brunch time. The burgers were great and large, so come hungry! This is a place where you come to, to purchase individual meals, then sharing family style. All in all, I'd come back here for lunch, but for dinner I can skip this menu and go somewhere around the same strip.

The ambience is good, they serve good burger. We ordered 'to die for' burger and a truffle beef burger (I can't remember the name). I personally prefer 'To die for' burger because the taste is stronger and better. What a cool place to hang out with friends. If you don't mind the heat, they have outdoor seating, facing the MBS.

OverEasy is one of the many restaurants overlooking Marina Bay. Prices are crazy high, but I guess that's to be expected along the water, with gorgeous views of the hotel/casino. I happened to come on national day, and all the tables were reserved for later in the evening, but the staff did accommodate us and let us know we'd only have a short time to eat/drink before the reservation. The menu has a good selection of food and beverages. Again, prices are a little crazy. My passion fruit iced tea was $10 and alcoholic beverages range from $18-$25. They do have "happy hour" but it's only for one particular drink each day. On the day I was here, happy hour only applied to whisky. Lol. The service was friendly and efficient, we had a really great view and it was overall a really great experience.

Food is so-so although I would recommend the lobster macaroni and cheese. What you will enjoy and hence I rated it 3 stars is the fantastic view of the bay and Marina Bay Sands with its nightly laser show.

The main reason to come here is the view, especially at night when you can catch a good view of the light show at Marina Bay Sands. For as busy as they were the service was pretty good. The food was alright, it was enjoyable but not really memorable. A few vegetarian options here that were good, my favorite was the truffle mac n cheese.

I like the food. The service not so much. Truffled mac and cheese with wild mushrooms, anyone? The smell of the truffle is enough to send me to 7th heaven, until I get sick of the scent. Best to share it as it can get a bit too much after a while. The spicy wings are equally good. Spicy sour with the blue cheese dressing to neutralize the heat. The steak frites is delicious with the truffle fries and bearnaise sauce. Drinks are not watered down and juices are refreshing.Note: Service can be a bit slow. And I do not like their system where they need to hold your credit card (when you are not requesting the drinks to be on tab) just because you want to utilize the happy hour promotion. I don't understand why they need to do that, especially when credit card fraud is so common now.

The food here is decent, but it's overshadowed by the pricing.  I understand that everything is more expensive in Singapore, but $20+ for a burger is a bit steep, and if that's what you want to charge, then make damn sure they thing is delivered as the customer asked.  Drink prices are also quite high, except during happy hour, when they approach reasonable.

The venue earned the 4th star, the food is decent but nothing spectacular.When the stock market is down, sliders are $1 each which is great since 5 of these little burgers cost you $16 on the regular menu. This $1 deal ends at 7pm, so be sure to get there early. I like that the sliders are cut up steak pieces rather than minced patties. The handcut fries with parmesan and rosemary is great. Almost as perfect as fries can get.Happy hour 1 for 1 ends 8pm. If you have UOB card, it ends at 8.30pm.

American brunch place. Average food overall. Had the standard American big breakfast (fried eggs, bacon, ham, baked beans, sausages, grilled tomatoes, etc.). Food was a bit underwhelming - it was cooked fine but nothing particularly stand-out and feels like a bit like a dish you can make at home with a few times of practice...Usually don't have high standard for brunch dishes since there's a limited scope you can work with eggs/classic breakfast dishes but some brunch places just execute it really well. Unfortunately, this is not one of them.

One of my fav hangout place when in mood for some fancy burgers. Best part? They operate till late, 3am on a Friday night! Go for their signature truffle burger. I love how the beef patty integrates so well with taste of the cheese! Always looking forward to the burger. Ask for truffle fries if U're in for a little more truffle! However I would say that the standard and portion has dropped some fair bit. A pity but still good on the taste buds. Also ordered their buffalo wings with spiciness on a scale of level 2. Not too spicy for locals but definitely a bomb for foreigners. Disappointment of the entire meal was... The buffalo wings were uncooked!! Didn't ask for a change as the staffs looked under-manpowered. Overeasy Fullerton was quite obviously under staffed, but can't be helped as they're popular, sporting a large crowd with guests queuing for tables on a Friday late night! Had their chicken BLAT burger too, was quite appetising with the soury mayonnaise. The mayonnaise taste very much like the same kinda mayonnaise we can easily find from our 'neighbourhood' cafe haha.There's a lovely draw to this place. Maybe It's the droopy lightings. Maybe it's The 'hype' atmosphere and airiness of this overeasy chain. It's quite relaxing, u can watch MBS's laser show here too as it's right smack ooposite from MBS!

We came on a weekday evening and chose one of the tables outside. What happened was really disappointing - it started raining and everyone just fled from their tables. We were all standing in the sheltered area. Plates, cutlery, glasses and beer bottles were still standing soaking the rain while the waiters hurried shifted the tables in one-by-one. It was almost amusing seeing them frantically trying to make sure the customers didn't run away without paying, and also to re-seat the customers who left stranded.Among the two of us, we shared two plates of mini burgers (I think it was 6 burgers on a plate), a caesar salad and a prawn pasta. I got an Asahi to go with the food. We first ordered a steak but the order didn't come after we had finished everything. My friend was gathering exasperated by the inattention of the waiters; we changed the order into another plate of mini burgers.Well, he really did enjoyed those burgers, which I hear is famous over here at Overeasy. I found them to be just okay - i like burgers with leafy salad, tomato, cheese and all. These burgers only had a patty (it was like a cut of steak and pretty juicy, though slightly too cooked for my liking) enclosed with two buns and a toothpick to hold it together.The salad was just okay, I think I can make better salad lolCan't remember what the white sauce on the pasta was but the prawns were really fresh! It was moderately okay, and it did remind me of the copious amounts of pasta I used to eat (and make myself) when I was in the States.The bill came up to 50+ per person. A little ex, but considering the nice location (you can see the whole marina bay front from the dining tables outside), it would still recommend this place.
We enjoyed the set lunch. We had kale salads and the best fried chicken sandwich on the planet. Incredible French fries rounded it out.

Consistent! Been to this joint (as well as the just-opened branch at Orchard Road) several times due to its location. Service is still really crappy. Long waits, disorganised. Staff feeling entitled. Ambience is also almost non-existent, more like a create-your-own environment. Other than happy hour drinks, all the other elements were absurdly painful. Food is terrible - too greasely or overboard. Saving grace is the fries. Great texture

Pretty disappointing. I went there after a long day and I was extremely hungry. We were 3, and waited for at least 30 minutes for our food to come. They were really disorganized. My dish came first, and it wasn't until another 10 minutes that the next plate came, and another 10 more for the last dish to arrive (my two friends ordered the exact same dish, I don't know why it had to take them so long in between both). I started to eat first and two of us ended up watching the last one eat.

I've heard a lot of good things about this place but I've never had a chance to check it out until recently. Everyone recommended the "To die for" burger.For a $20 burger, it was a bit on the small side, with a small pile of fries on the side.The burger was not bad but nothing to die for... I liked that it was a substantial, meaty burger patty and not the mushy stuff you tend to get at a lot of joints in Asia (think Mos Burger).After I finished my lunch, I was still a bit hungry.This place is just okay in my books.

Went to over easy for the first time in June 2015 with a group of about 10.What to say, we left extremely disappointed.Starters were ok, little slider burgers, Nachos etc and really the only reason I'm not giving two stars as combined with happy hour cocktail prices it's not too badMains however were terrible. Basic burgers and for $20+ a meal I thought they should be great but they weren't even good, much better burgers available in Singapore for at least $10 less.One of the guys even sent their meal backService was ok, not great.

Nice dining establishment near the Fullerton Hotel. Husband and I came on a Friday evening so it was hoppin' with locals and tourists alike!I ordered the 'to die for' burger and my husband got the truffle Mac and cheese. The truffle Mac was to die for! My burger, not so much. I enjoyed the "special sauce" (dear God I hope nothing bad is in it... ahem) but I found the patty a bit bland. I think the staff mixed up my order because it had cheese, which I didn't order because it's an additional $2 and I'm a cheap ass, and it was served well done instead of medium. However, I was hungry so I wasn't about to send it back. So sorry to the person who got jipped with my burger. (Sucker... Wha?)Since it was a busy Friday night, the staff seemed a bit stretched out. Service wasn't good, as they forgot to give me a bottle of ketchup, no one checked up on us after we got our food, and it took a while to get the check. Overall, nice place to have dinner, but too busy on popular nights. Might be best to go during lunch (if they're open?) or off peak weeknights.

This place is very noisy especially indoor. There is air conditioning too but the doors are open and the place is packed. Kinda stuffy. Being lazy people, we decide to settle our dinner there too. I ordered a spicy linguine and my friend a burger (can't recall the exact name but it's their popular burger). My linguine was not bad, springy pasta and prawns. The spiciness doesn't overpower. But for the burger, it wasn't quite what we expected. My friend requested to change the fries to salad. The salad was a pile of arugula with dressing. Won't it be boring to have one kind of green in the salad, in terms of mouthfeel and taste? At least that is what we thought. Midway through, we changed to outdoor seats. Which is way better as it is fresher air and music isn't confined. Great view of the skyline and laser show at MBS that go well with a pint of beer. Oh, and thumbs up for the attentive server for the outdoor area! :)
View is great.  Food is ok.  Service is terrible.  Waitstaff too busy checking their phones and avoiding eye contact to check on their guests.
I come here for the malt milkshake and the view of the MBS. Other food is ok, but definite share the milkshake because the portions are huge!

Overeasy serves really good bar grub, and I love the American Diner's design concept that guides every aspect of the experience here. They've got a great outdoor seating area as well, and I generally prefer getting a place out here because, unfortunately, Overeasy's indoor space tends to get as cacophonous as a dim sum restaurant. It gets incredibly loud in here, what with the loud music and patrons straining to have a conversation over it. For your sanity and comfort, I strongly recommend getting a place outside, but it does get crowded very quickly on weekends, so try to head down in the early evening or call ahead for a table.

So I'm pretty much in love with this place for a few reasons. There Mac N' Cheese is probably the best I've had in Singapore, there Chicken Wings pack a mean punch, and there Malt Milkshake is the bomb. Seriously, this place has become my go to American diner and I can't applaud the service, the food, and the all out amazing-ness that is OverEasy enough!

The food wasn't fantastic. We ordered truffle fries and a BLT burger, and there was no hint of truffle taste in the fries. Though the Mac and cheese was good.The only thing that ticked us off was the poor service. We had to call at least twice for a waiter to come help us with whatever it may be (order taking,rushing them for our drinks,calling the bill),and they are just so messy and blur even though the place wasn't even crowded.My friend even had to go up to a waiter. When she asked "excuse me?",he just looked at her and walked away. The table next to us were three Korean tourists,and they had to ask for their wine to be served 4 times. Average overpriced food,disappointing service. The manager was nice enough to waive off the GST charge for us.

1 for 1 happy hour and spiked milkshakes.  Mediocre sliders, but they're only a buck when the STI is down.  An extra star for being the site of the Berkeley club of Singapore happy hour locationIn general the food isn't great, and the drinks are pricey,  but Overeasy is a big after work bar in SG so all this is expected. All that said, t's nice having the view of the bay and the MBS light show in the evening

I've only eaten here once or twice and spent the rest of my time drinking. This is one of those places where you go because it's there and you need a drink. They have a good enough booze selection and the service is competent enough to get totally forgettable while still delivering your drinks in a reasonably timely manner.The highlights are the double-whammy view of Marina Bay on one side and hilariously drunk punters streaming out of Butter Factory on the other - depending on which time of the evening you go, of course. Oh and they have Oban 14, my favourite single malt. Huzzah!

So my Brit-mates sprung me a surprise visit in Singapore on a Tuesday - and they were flying out on a Wednesday! That warranted much worry as it meant I had only 16 hours to show them how awesome Singapore was. I initiated them to my lovely home country with an epic night-out in the BING style ... and kick-started my chain of bar/club-hopping with OverEasy - the first place which came to my mind!OverEasy is definitely my favourite chill-out bar in downtown Marina Bay. It is lovely both indoors (with a live DJ on most nights ... darkish romantic ambience) and outdoors. The crowd is a right mix of local and expat yuppies (the crowd DOES contribute a lot to a place's ambience and 'feel'). Get a table (there are couches or high tables) outdoors ... and sip your cocktail or wine while admiring the magnificent Marina Bay Sands. Be here at either 8:00PM or 09:30PM daily to catch MBS' light and wonder show from the comfort of your couch/stool (my touristy friends were quite in awe)!Drinks are priced quite decently as well. Good place to have a civilised drinks catch-up with friends before hitting Butterfac next door!

This cool joint is perfect to start your clubbing night (Hipster Butter Factory is just next door) or a great place to enjoy the view of Marina Bay at night. Opt for the outside seats - it may be a little more humid but it's easier to hold a conversation and airier to boot.The bar grub is good - my favourite is the famous cheese steak sliders which are small and 2-bite-sized. Food in general is also quite nice, though one might feel the more breakfast like food seems a bit pricey...Still, I'd recommend this to anyone who wants a nice night out with friends and beer!

I will admit that OverEasy provides welcome respite and clean toilets from the uncomfortable crowds converging for butter factory. However, I really like OverEasy for its great ambience and the amazing al fresco seating area that overlooks the water, with a lovely breeze blowing through at times.The tunes they play here at are also pretty chilled out or funky. Very comfortable with the vibes here. Staff are attentive, even f they are sometimes a little slow.I've not eaten much here, but is tried the mini sliders here and they are pretty good! A juicy chunk of meat cooked to a medium rare perfection is nestled in between the buns. I'd definitely recommend coming here for a pre-party, post-dinner drink with friends.

One of the main draws of Overeasy is its location. Apart from the fact that it's conveniently located near Butter Factory, making it the ideal pre-drinking spot for those who can afford it, it has a wonderful sea-front view, facing straight into MBS (so obviously you get all the sights around it too).They have a great selection of alcohol to boot, collecting some favourites from around the world. One of my favourites is the Little Creatures pale ale, which isn't stocked at many places (I picked this taste up from The Plain, of all places).Overeasy also do surprisingly good food. I know their burger comes highly recommended, as do their slides, especially when the market closes below a certain index (then they go for $1!). I went for lunch once and enjoyed the breeze as I dug into the most perfect bowl of truffle mac and cheese with mushrooms. It's hard to imagine how something that sounds so simple can taste so amazing. I don't think it's just the 'whole truffle oil makes everything magic' idea, because the cheese was toasted to such perfection, topped with some crumbs to add a crazy mix of texture to the whole dish. The mushrooms were pretty good as well, not the cheap button mushroom sorts, but the nice kind you'd expect from a restaurant. Loved it so much. a Five-star dish if I've ever had one. Must try!

Overeasy is located right opposite Raffles Place and is easily accessible by public transport. Drinks during happy hour are decently priced. The secret though is to check the status of the Singapore stock exchange for the day - if the market ends down, the bar serves mini sliders at $1 per pop. Even in Singapore where food prices are relatively lower as compared to other developed cities, it is hard to find any other bar which can beat Overeasy. Overeasy is also located right on the bay front, making it the perfect spot to chill alfresco with your friends. The sea breeze ensures that you never feel hot and sticky, though you might want to style your hair accordingly (hairspray!!)
Food is poor, drinks are expensive.  Location is its savior.   Though service is friendly.

I was really disappointed by this place. I went here to get a hotdog which I was really looking forward to, but the bread was stale and was generally a let down. I asked for regular fries, but got truffle fries which I hate. Also, I saw a few cockroaches running around which was rather surprising as I've never seen a cockroach in Singapore before. But I guess at least they enjoyed the food. If you're looking for a hotdog NEVER go here, I'm sure their other food isn't so bad though, we also had chicken wings which were pretty decent. Their cocktails are actually pretty yummy too. If it wasn't for them this place would get 0 stars.

I quite enjoy this place.  It has a nice vibe to it.  Not too quiet and not too rowdy.  Come by sometime Saturday night and enjoy good music with a live DJ.  Oh, and don't forget to try the Truffle Fries :)Based on the atmosphere, I think this place is perfect for small groups.

I love Overeasy for its waterfront location and outdoor seating where you can get great views of the bay while basking in the relaxing evening sun. You can see why it's so popular with the afterwork corporate crowd. In particular, Overeasy has a great happy hour. You get can 1-for-1 drinks including Kirin and Heineken on tap (that's just $7 a pint) and housepour wines and spirits. It's always a happy day when the market closes lower for the day (if you're not a trader) because Overeasy has a slider promotion where you can get these lovely mini burgers at  $1 each. The sliders are really good too. Proper chunks of sirloin with cheese sauce sandwiched by a bun, they go great with a beer.

Great spot to chill with pals in the city area post-work or pre-club, with an amazing view of the bay. Drinks are a little pricey but the sliders are delicious, and cost $1 when the STI drops. Lemon drops here are good.
My parents and I ate here lunch earlier this month while we were seeing the famous lion.The food is very good and definitely upscale.It has an amazing view of the bay.

Right by the Merlion Park, the restaurant provide the spectacular view of Merlion and Marina Bay Sands while dining at this place.We walked in on Sunday around 6pm without any reservation, and we got lucky to get a great corner table inside.  (it was still warm outside and we wanted to be in air conditioned room although patio provides better view of the MBS.We started our dinner with a bottle of red wine. We were a little disappointed by the selection of wine listed under premium wine.  We also ordered a bottle of sparking water to help ease spicy food later.Cucumber salad with garlic was crunchy yet tender.  Fresh cumber mixed with red chili and garlic sauce was very good, after we finished eating cucumbers, we kept the sauce to use it later for other dishes.Asparagus appetizer was cooked well and it also went good with the chili garlic sauce we kept from the cucumber salad earlier.Steamed Sea bass was so moist and tender, sauce used to flavor the fish went really well with sea bass.  In fact, we ate every edible parts of the fish.  The fish was that good.We also had their famous chili crabs. They were good but it seems like all chili crabs taste the same.
