So we had to wait around 15 minutes before we could get a table.The service was prompt and attentive, and we ordered a fish head curry, roast chicken, beancurd and baby kalian for the vegetables.We had to endure another long wait thanks to the crowds here.The fish head curry arrived on our table first, and we found that the fish was very fresh. The curry was perfect: it was fragrant and the degree of spiciness was just nice. We also had the roast chicken, which was very tender and the skin was crispy and flavorful (the skin is always my favorite!). The vegetables rounded up our meal and despite being a hardcore carnivore, the vegetables here tasted pretty good as well. All in all, a very nice place for a meal.

address: Blk 104, Yishun Ring Rd Singapore 760104 Singapore
comment: Got the oyster omelette via grab. I cannot over state how delicious this dish was. The added fish paste made for a joyous early evening meal. The eggs were crispy and the oysters flavorful. I don't commonly eat the same thing while visiting new locations, but this dish will most certainly be eaten again. YUM!!!

address: Blk 104, Yishun Ring Rd Singapore 760104 Singapore
comment: With more than 50 stalls, variety is the name of the game at Chong Pang Food Centre, one of the more famous traditional hawker centres in Singapore. For people like me who are tired of the more sterile food courts that serve the newer estates, Chong Pang Food Centre is not only accessible, but is infinitely more down-to-earth, authentic, lively, personal, and the vaiety and quality of the dishes are just unbeatable. The hawker centre is located at the heart of Chong Pang Town and arguably its biggest attraction. It is easily accessible by bus from any of the train stations in Yishun, Sembawang, and Woodlands. The premises are clean and well-ventilated, and while weekend mornings require patrons to exercise some patience to secure seats, weekdays are considerably more forgiving.Be sure to check out Xiang Xiang's fishball noodles, Tian Tian's Hokkien prawn noodles, and the Bedok Chwee Kueh stall.

address: 101 Yishun Ave 5 #01-03, Swee Sian Yuen Eating House Singapore 760101 Singapore
comment: The zhi char stall in located in Swee Sian Yuan Eating House, which is just across from the Singapore's most well known lottery 7-11 store (because the 7-11 got one of the most number of winners in TOTO lottery in Singapore). The zhi char stall is taken over by the current owner from last November, who is also a wholesale seafood supplier. Currently the stall was having promotion for its crabs with 2 pieces (each weighing about 400 to 450 grams) at $38.80. Lala Beehoon with superior broth 上汤啦啦米粉 ($20/ large)The soup was full of flavours. Remember to eat it fast because the bee hoon will soak up the stock very fast.Crab with bee hoon 螃蟹焖米粉 （粗）Seasonal price 时价The stock used in this dish was made by cooking the crab in stock for long hours. One could really taste the seafood flavour in the soup.Threadfin Fish Head 顺风午鱼头 （招牌蒸）($68)Seasonal price 时价I was surprised by the huge size of the fish head. One cannot imagine how big the whole fish must be like. The fish was meaty and juicy. The soup was slightly sour. Mixed it with the spicy chilli paste on top of the fish head, it gave a kind of tom yam like taste.Salted egg crabs 咸蛋螃蟹Seasonal price 时价2 Female crabs with lots of roe was used in this dish. Rich creamy sauce which made one wishing for some bread to dip with.Ayam kalasan (Not in menu) ($18/ half chicken) This dish was different from Ayam penyet (smashed fried chicken) as the chicken was boiled before frying. It gave the meat a more tender and moist texture.Green Dragon Vegetable 青龙菜 ($10/ small) This vegetable was also known as Chives and could be found growing in Cameron Highlands, Malaysia. The vegetable had a kind of unique sweetness.Salted Chicken 盐鸡 (菜园鸡) ($18/ half chicken)Cooked with Chinese Angelica root (Dang Gui), the chicken was very tender and flavourful, soaking up the flavours of herbs without the bitterness. Salted egg prawns 咸蛋虾 ($16/ small)Personally I like this version than the crab's version, as the sauce was thicker and rich here.The thick sauce coated the peeled prawns evenly. It was so well fried than one had no problem having the crunchy crispy tail shell part.Overall the food was not bad. Way better than the previous zhi char stall, whose standard was not consistent.

This Thai restaurant is good at its reasonable price and huge portion. It is suitable for family, gathering, and also celebration! Our company celebrate chinese reunion in the same restaurant for 2 consecutive years! We had abalone, fish, duck, fried sotong, and others delicious foods for just sgd 199!It's super cheap and fast serving!

Bei Sheng's  a very affordable 'tze char'- like Chinese & Thai restaurant. The variety of food available is ALOT! Here's what I've tried and highly recommend: - Pineapple fried rice: Ask for extra pork floss!- Deep fried calamari: These are the biggest calamari rings I've seen so far! Chewy on the inside and crispy on the outside.  - Tom yam soup The ambience inside the restaurant isn't that great. The tables and chairs are very coffeeshop- like (that is, the Singaporen kind of kopitiam). The waiters are always busy but nonetheless, still pretty attentive to customers' orders. But hey! For a good price, decent food and the comfort of dining at a place with A/C, what more can you expect?Can get pretty packed during the weekends, PH and on special occasions like Mother's day. Be prepared to queue!

I came here with my family for a meal upon the recommendations of a friend. The place was rather noisy and boisterous, which is rather typical for a restaurant of this kind. Anyway, we were seated fairly quickly and began ordering. Service was quick and attentive.We ordered the following few dishes, including the thai deep fried fish with sauce, pineapple fried rice, stir fried beef and oat prawns. The deep fried fish was very fresh but we thought that the taste was quite average. The pineapple fried rice was really awesome! It was very fragrant and the flavor was very well balanced with the pork floss. The beef was very tender and this was one of my favorites as well. I did not eat too much of the oat prawns but I thought that it was very fresh as well. We ended off our meal with the fish maw mushroom soup, which I really enjoyed.Overall, a great place to have a nice meal with your family.

No photos taken because too hungry to do so. Visited here due to friend's introduction and went here for our breakfast. We ordered two big bowl of Bak Kut Teh, you tiao, Preserved Vegetables and one bowl of Braised Pig's Trotter to share among four of us. I have to say this Old Street Bak Kut Teh is really good. The food are delicious, the Bak Kut Teh soup was really delicious till we refilled it again and their service was good too. The soup for the Bak Kut Teh can be refill again and again. Total price for everything is around $80+ so each person pay around $20+. Definitely will be back again for more next time.

The restaurant was newly opened in Sun Plaza and we decided to try it. We arrived at the restaurant just before the dinner crowd. The place was not crowded. But we patiently stood at the Wait To be Served queue, although there was empty tables with unclear cutlery around. In the end no people came to assist us and we walked to one of the unclear table. Requested for the menu from one of the staff, who just pulled out a drawer from the table and left. Turned out that the menu was on the ipad which none of us knew. Just as I was about to submit my order, a staff arrived with an order of pig's liver soup ($7.20++) and insisted that I had ordered it. I was furious with this attitude from the staff. After much fireworks, the bowl was removed.Soon the food started to be served. But cutlery was not served so we asked the staff for it, who just declared it was at the table. Turned out the cutlery was in a hidden compartment at the side of the table. Thank to the helpful customers from the neighbouring table. Turned out that they also faced similar experience when they first dining in here too.Remember to help yourself to the various sauces such as sliced chilli, minced garlic, chilli sauce, dark soya sauce, light soya sauce, and sesame sauce at the counter. None of staff care to advise us on it.The food arrived in batches with different printout. Take note of having sets. Ordered a Set B which turned out one of the dishes in set had not arrived even after a long wait. Told the staff who gave a disbelieve look.Set Menu B ($15++)Premium Loin Ribs($11.80 ala carte) + You Tiao($2 ala carte) + Beancurd($2.30 ala carte) + Rice ($0.80 ala carte)The meat on the rib was quite tender. Soup was average. Surprisingly the first dish to arrive, turned out to be the dessert - sweet cold beancurd. Last to arrive was the you tiao.Preserved Vegetable ($3.90++)Felt that it was overpriced. The dish was not stewed soft enough. Could not taste the sweetness from the vegetable.Braised Pig's Intestines ($8.50++)It was the worst dish in the whole meal. The intestines was bitter and not soften enough. A sign of not enough cleaning of the intestines being done. Awful dish to have.Mee Xian ($2++)The noodles was lumpy and powdery. Quite awful to taste.Braised Pig's Trotter ($10++)It was tender but still not to the melt in the mouth texture yet.Pig's Stomach Soup ($7.20++)It was average.Sour Plum ($2++)It was served hot without ice. Tasted ok.With another bowl of rice ($0.80++), total bill was $58.10 which I felt was overpriced. Overall the food was awful. The service was the worst kind. Furthermore there was GST and service charge when one was expected to walk to the cashier to make payment oneself. The queue at the cashier was quite long too. Didn't think of visiting this place in the near future.

address: 604 Sembawang Rd #01-26, Sembawang Shopping Centre Singapore 758459 Singapore
comment: It used to be located in the food court in the second floor. Recently it has moved to its current location and expanded its menu. Only cash and NETS payment is accepted here. The place is decorated in a industrial look, with a play area for kids.Cordon Bleu Chicken ($10.90++)Served With any 2 side dishes from selected choices of mash potato, potato salad, olive rice, fries, garden salad, coleslaw,ratatouille, and plain rice.I was surprised when the dish was served. It was not the cordon bleu or schnitzel cordon bleu, which is a dish of meat wrapped around cheese (or with cheese filling), then breaded and pan-fried or deep-fried. Instead it was served as deep fried chicken cutlet, topped with ham and melted cheese. It was also served with a garlic aioli sauce. The chicken cutlet was crispy except that it was a tab too dry. The garlic aioli sauce helped to moist it a bit. I like the stretch of the melted cheese. I had the dish served with mash potato and coleslaw.Overall the food was not bad. The place was relatively quiet on a weekday night, with most customers having takeaway. Remember to help yourself to the iced water and condiments at the counter.

My family ate here for the first time and really enjoyed the food especially the Assam Fish and Fried Cauliflower. Suresh the owner and his staff were very helpful and courteous. Everyone in our party of 10 enjoyed the food.

Anthony Bourdain, eat your heart out!  Well, not literary...This is the BEST place to get Hainanese Chicken Rice in the entire island.  The chicken is so tender, succulent, and flavorful, the chili or ginger sauces are not needed.  The rice is so aromatic and equally flavorful that I end up pass my "eat only half" carbs rule.  That should speak volumes.  To top it off, it has been very consistent: never has the chicken or rice gone dry - EVER.  The only down part?  This is a hidden gem inside a business park.  I don't know if there is public access, but if you can, it's better than the downtown establishments like Chatterbox and, should I mention it: Tian Tian in Chinatown.    You have been enlightened!

The restaurant was located at the second level of the old wing, taking over part of the space formerly occupied by Popular bookshop. The brand started off as a stall in Lavender Food Square in 2010. When the food court was closed down, the brand was bought over by the Ministry of Food and became a chain, offering authentic Northern Chinese fare served in a contemporary Chinese restaurant. 3 classic favourites in 1 basket一笼小笼包．三种口味 (S$8++/ 6pieces)Enjoy 2 pieces of each flavour of Xiao Long Bao Original, Salted Egg & Chilli Crab Xiao Long BaoOne would prefer that the dishes to be served hotter. The skin of the xiao long bao could be thinner and there's not much juice in each dumpling. The salted egg version was kind of overwhelmed by the salted egg taste, while the chilli crab version was lacking of spicy taste.Pork Belly Roll with Crushed Garlic (S$8.80++)Interestingly the cucumber looked much bigger than the thin slices of meat. The slices of meat looked rather dry. Thankfully the sauce helped alot.Pan Fried Chives & Pork Dumpling (S$7.20++/ 6pcs)Although looked tiny, it was full of filling inside. One wished that the skin could be crispier.Signature Noodle with Steamed Chicken Soup (S$12.80++)In the menu, the soup was served in a ceramic pot, but in actual the soup was served in a tiny bowl which barely fitted the 2 pieces of chicken and a mushroom. There was barely space for soup. The signature noodles which was inspired by local bak chor mee taste and tossed in a mild spicy sauce, but there was barely any spicy taste and the texture was rather dry and hard.Washed down the meal with a glass of Lemongrass Drink (S$4++) which did not taste homemade.Overall the meal was rather disappointing. Noted wet tissue was chargeable at S$0.30++/ piece and takeaway was charageable at S$0.50++/ per item.

rest_name: Yi Qian Ling Yi Ye Steamboat Buffet 自助火锅店
comment: The restaurant had recently opened at the new wing of the mall. It was chinese style hotpot buffet restaurant. The different from the usual hotpot buffet restaurants was that the food was served in conveyor belt style, similar to conveyor belt sushi restaurants. One could opt for small individual hotpot, or share a yuan yang hotpot up to a group of 4 persons. As part of its opening promotion, the restaurant was offering lunch priced at S$16.80+ per person. This also included free flow of soft drinks, soft serve and condiments at the counter. For the group of 3 of us, we shared a yuan yang hotpot with a selection of Herbal Chicken Soup and Boiled Fish with Sichuan Pickles Soup (With a topup of S$6+). At first glance, it seemed like mostly vegetables such as assorted mushrooms (shiitake, abalone, Enoki), and green leafy vegetables (Tang O, cabbage, spinach), bean curd (firm and soft version), corn, and tomato. As we were sitting at the far end of the belt, most of the meat were taken by the time it reached our side. The staffs were helpful to bring big trays of sliced meat such as beef, mutton, and pork from the kitchen without us requesting for it. The Boiled Fish with Sichuan Pickles Soup was value for money as it was packed with slices of fish and preserved vegetables in it.Being newly opened there was no GST, but there was a 10% service charge on the bill. We were given discount vouchers for next visit.

rest_name: Yi Qian Ling Yi Ye Steamboat Buffet 自助火锅店
comment: Horrible service.I made a reservation at 19:30 for 2 and arrived at 19:26, the restaurant was packed at the time and there was no seats for us despite our reservations. To which the staff #1 told us to choose our soup base first and we would be seated as soon as possible. After choosing our soup base, we waited for about 5mins and asked again about our seats and why are we not seated promptly despite having reservations. This time round staff#2 told us that she did not see the reservation made and that's why we did not have a seat. We made a concession and decided to walk around and return in 10mins. By the time we're back and asked again regarding our seats and how long more we should wait. Staff #2 now tell us that they would give us the next available seat once it's available. Another 5 mins passed and a table opened up, and they happily decide to seat customers that arrived later than us at the table first. And their reasoning is that the table is for a 4pax and we have to wait for a 2pax table. And they can't even give us an estimated waiting time which makes no sense since it's a timed buffet. Staff #2 even suggested we go into their shop and eat some fries while waiting. With no seats available, i think she expected us to stand and eat.In conclusion, this is really horrible service and they did not even try to resolve the issue. It doesn't help that they did not even do what they promised of giving us a table first. What's the point of making a reservation in this case.

rest_name: Yi Qian Ling Yi Ye Steamboat Buffet 自助火锅店
comment: Went there yesterday and experienced the worst buffet ever. Variety was bad and meat and seafood were not exactly free flow and you need to order for them to be delivered in pathetically small portion.Feedback to store supervisor but the service of food preparation staff remained the same. The staff seemed to be well feared by her fellow PRC colleagues as all of them had to call her aunt politely and wait for her to take her own sweet time to prepare for food. What's worse?  I'm down with food poisoning now! (didn't eat any food after this buffet). Really horrible place to spend your money. more than double loss.

rest_name: Yi Qian Ling Yi Ye Steamboat Buffet 自助火锅店
comment: I Had to wait for 35min even though reservations was made earlier. Was seated at the rear corner of the restaurant. Food on the conveyer belt was really tiny portion.  As per plate they serve only 1 prawn. Most of the food was not fresh as well. We have to order trays of food. Came pretty slow as well. Their free xiao long bao was never top up through the whole period. I think the only thing nice about their food was the Maggie mee. I will only come back if they pay me to eat there.

rest_name: Yi Qian Ling Yi Ye Steamboat Buffet 自助火锅店
comment: Went during the New Year Eve. We paid extra for my tomato soup base and was waste of money, nothing WOW about the soup as recommended by the waitress. Hubby had mala and asked for extra spicy 大辣. Well, it was salty and not spicy in this case.Perhaps, not an good idea using conveyor belt for buffet esp dinner. Those sitting near to the kitchen will grab most of the dishes before it can reach customers sitting far back. We saw the staff reusing the plates (from conveyor belts) without washing (his boss did) and plate the pork/beef/veg etc and back to the belt again. Food contamination probably didn't come across his mind :PFloor was slippery so those sitting near to the kitchen, be extra careful esp when the staff holding pot of hot soup!Next, xiao long bao were served at the buffet counter (besides water melon, that was the only dish on the counter). And guess what, the pork filing inside was RAW! I checked with the staff and confirmed that the dish should serve cooked! Luckily I saw it before eating, and inform the staff immediately. They merely retrieved the uncooked dish from the counter without making sure no one still eating it. I was the one who went over to few tables to stop people from consuming. No word from the boss or staff!Overall, the dinner was expensive and taste was mediocre. Paper thin (and 2-3pcs/plate) slice of meat, few 1 prawn/plate, few leaves of veg/plate etc. Will we be back, Hell No!

Came here on Sunday the recommendation of Makasutra's article in Sunday Life! on 23 Oct 2016 for the putu piring but alas it was closed. It's supposed to be closed on Mondays! Maybe Mr Putu was afraid of the crowd after appearing in the newspapers!Love it for its variety of stalls - Mr Putu, Burock, 101 Rojak, Hup Lee Fried Bee Hoon, Mee Rebus/Lontong/Mee Siam, Seafood by United F&B Pte Ltd, 118 Fishball Noodle and S. Bistari Changi Village Ayam Pengyat.Has lots of outdoor seats.Burock: This stall sells apam balik, churros, kachang pool, nasi bukhari and roti John. See photo for the different types.Anyway, we ate apam balik - original (whatever that is), cheese, chocolate rice and combo. I like it that the dough was very soft. It is more like the Chinese mee chiam kueh or chiu chia kueh rather than the Indian apom. S. Bistari Changi Village Ayam Pengyat (takes orders through an i-Pad lookalike):Bought a piece of fried chicken breast that comes with chilli - came with clear soup, think it's because the chicken is a bit dry on its own. Come with chilli and rice with a bit of cucumber and a leaf of lettuce. So so. Looks better than it tastes.

Hainanese Chicken Rice Since 1990Chicken rice is one of the most popular dish in Singapore and you can find this dish literally everywhere. The technique of finding a reputable stall is as easy as tracking down the longest queue, and my journey led me to the stall-front of Yishun 925 Chicken Rice.HALF CHICKEN (12.00)Skillfully deboned, chopped and dressed in an emulsion of light soy-sauce and sesame oil, the glistening steamed chicken is rested on a bed of sliced cucumber, served with a portion of acar on the side.As I ordered the half chicken, instead of the regular plate of chicken rice (3.00/4.00), there was a mix of both dark meat and white meat.The boneless meat has a silky smooth appearance with a firm and springy texture. Served at a cold temperature, the flesh was juicy and succulent. Some people remove it, but I can't miss out on the layer of slippery soft skin that literally falls apart in your mouth. Definitely one of the best place to have Chicken Rice.Full review with pictures, prices and ratings at - zacbhl.blogspot.sg/2016/…Zacbhl - Eating, Writing, Sharing

I'm surprised there hasn't been a review for this place yet. Isn't this supposed to be one of several popular chicken rice spots in Singapore (the amount of chicken spines hanging there is pretty freaky; perfect horror movie scene for fowls)? I was introduced to this spot by family ages ago while I was but a pup and re-introduced by a close friend when I first got back to Singapore. It was instant reunification like long lost friends that led me to visit at least once a week to get my chicken rice fix in the northern part of Singapore.But what makes this particular stall stand out among the endless chicken rice stalls available in Singapore?The chicken; definitely the chicken - sauced right, cooked right, tender...and not-so-oily. Since I usually order extra chicken or the half chicken, it always comes out on a plate that looks like chicken resting within a swimming pool of sauces. Oh, they even garnish it with a slice of tomato (lol), peeled cucumbers (as usual), and *pickled* cucumbers. Yet, it is only taste that really matters and that is something they definitely succeeded in.As for the rest?The rice, chili, and soup...are just slightly better than the typical chicken rice stall. Nothing spectacular...like the usual composition of a star's entourage./recommended-ONLY-if-you're-in-the-areaYelp 100: 38/100

Maybe it is blasphemy in the land of many chicken rice lovers, but I am not a fan of it. I can take it or leave it. I have never crave for it or dream about it. To me, chicken rice is like fast food. It is something which is easy to order as take-away. No soup, no mess. Just sliced chicken over a mound of rice and maybe some cucumber slices with a small packet of chili sauce. My colleague who lives in Yishun told me there is nothing much in Yishun and recommended two food stalls to try when he found out I will be heading this way. This is one of them. It does seem strange to refer to Yishun as if it is in a far away place when it is probably about a 30 minutes drive away (but if you take public transportation of bus/train, it can get to 1-2 hours, depending on where you come from). I found this place, which is actually very near the bus terminal. It occupies a corner stall in the coffee shop and is very well managed. There is a queue system. Order at the cash register, get your receipt on which your queue number is printed. Wait for your queue number to be called. Collect your food when called. It has many recommendations on its signboard by various TV shows. Now I am a bit skeptical about such claims after the Tiong Bahru market experience. But this place does serve pretty good chicken rice. I ordered the $3.50 portion to go. Since it is Hainanese chicken rice, only "white" chicken is available, no roasted version. The packet of chicken rice was very hot, piping hot. It was the first time or since a very long time I had such a packet where the food was actually hot. It was still warm when I got to it like 3-4 hours later. The chicken was not silky smooth or succulent as I would like, I put it down as maybe I left it for too long, but it was not totally dried out or tough. It was still soft but with more bite to the meat. The rice was amazing. Oh my goodness, they drizzled sauce over the chicken and rice and after the 3-4 hours, the rice just soaked up the flavor. I could literally just eat the chicken rice as is, without the chili or dark soya sauce at all. It was that delicious. It also came with a few slices of pickled cucumbers or something, adding a bit of crunch to it. I would order this again when I am in the Yishun area.

If you live in Yishun, you will likely have dined at this coffeeshop we affectionately call "925 Coffeeshop". Among friends, we simply refer to it as "925". Now, I'm no foodie, but everything here tastes good. Good enough to stave off hunger, and good enough to satisfy a man's enormous appetite. But this is a review of the Hainanese Chicken Rice stall at 925 Coffeeshop.I've dined and ordered my fair share of chicken rice here over the years and it still tastes as good now as it did back then. The price has increased over the years, but still remains affordable. $3.50 for a packet of piping hot, succulent and mouth-watering slices of boneless white chicken served with fragrant rice, pickles, pineapples, a slice of tomato and "Yan Xu". I think the vegetables are Yan Xu(s).Whether in a large group, or dining alone, the stall serves enough for any occasion. I've heard of other places touting mouth-watering, gravity defying chicken rice at least 5 times the cost of a plate here, but this is a stall that serves up a mean dish of Hainanese chicken rice.On any day, and any time, make your way down to the coffeeshop and you will see customers tucking into plates of chicken rice. If I were to exaggerate, I'd say that half the coffeeshop is filled with eager mouths chomping down on chicken going by the pastel purple plates that never stop filling tables.If you've not tried the stall before, try it once and you may very well be a convert. It is, after all, a simple plate of chicken rice. But, there could very well be more than meets the eye, and mouth, and taste buds too.

address: 24, Jalan Permas 10/5 Bandar Baru Permas Jaya 81750 Masai, Johor Malaysia
comment: Food: 4/5Decor: 4/5Service: 2/5While I was on a business trip to Johor, I was craving Japanese food like usual, so my girlfriend recommended this restaurant. Based on her experience, we called to make reservation first even though it's a week day and that was such a brilliant move! When we reached around 8pm, the restaurant was packed! and there were more than 10 people in the queue outside the restaurant. Even under the circumstance where we've made reservation, we had to wait for around 10 minutes for the table. The decoration of the place was very classy and they have individual pods which allows for a little bit more privacy. We had sashimi (salmon, salmon belly and tuna). Presentation of the food was elegant. The sashimi was served in a bowl with dry ice. Needless to say, the sashimi was very fresh. Besides that, we also had soft shell crab tempura, which decent but not anything special. We ordered also the really unhealthy deep fried chicken skin, which we did not finish as it really tasted quite bad. However, that was the only dish that we didn't like. The waiters were not really attentive nor patient as the restaurant was really packed out. It would make our dining experience a better one if they can improve on their customer service.

address: 24, Jalan Permas 10/5 Bandar Baru Permas Jaya 81750 Masai, Johor Malaysia
comment: Food: 4/5Decor: 4/5Service: 2/5After trying just for once at Nijyumaru with high school friends, I've always wanted to return to Nijyumaru and eat  to my heart's content. Unfortunately, my parents are not a big fan of Japanese food and hence, throughout the years, though I often pass by the restaurant but never since then had chance to dine in again until my boyfriend finally came to Johor on his business trip. We made reservation in advance as I am well aware of the crowd in Nijyumaru especially during dinner time. We were served after 10 minutes of waiting at the entrance. It was thoughtful of them to prepare seats outside for customers who are waiting. Overall, the food was great! However, there was an unpleasant miscommunication with the staff. After ordering the first round of food, we figured it wouldn't be enough as we were still hungry for more! We were rather indecisive in what we wanted, but we have finally decided on another portion of salmon sashimi, grilled bacon roll and fried chicken skin. The waitress, though confirming that we were adding three more dishes, actually put in the fourth item. When the grilled enoki mushroom that we didn't order was served, we clarified that we did not order that dish and the waitress did not take it very well.

Went for dinner during weekday as there was a promotion where every order of main course came with a choice of side and drink/dessert.Flossperity Pizza (S$22.80++)Arugula, Pork Floss, Bak KwaOne of the 3 items in the Chinese New Year menu.Although it was served in a tomato base pizza, one could not taste the usual sour tomato paste's taste in it. It was a more sweeter taste similar to raspberry. The savoury sweet pork jerky and savoury pork floss balanced the bitterness of the arugula quite well.For choice of side, I have selected Grilled Chicken Salad which was grilled chicken served on a bed of mesclun salad.End the meal with Baked Caramel Banana which was served with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and fruit. Water was served free of charge. Do come early. Queue could be quite long even on weekday nites.

In full disclosure I only had the mixed grill. I did not have the basalt stone grilled steak which seems to be popular. The ribs were ok. Chicken average. The rest very average. Will come back to give them one more try with the basalt thing some day. I guess for the price it's ok.

The restaurant had recently opened at the new wing of the shopping mall, offering Sichuan dishes. The restaurant also had another 3 outlets in Singapore, with one just right across the street at the bus interchange.Common Sea Perch 金目鲈 (S$38++)Special Toast - Pickled Cabbage flavourCurrently it was having 20% discount promotion for this dish at the Northpoint outlet.Slightly spicy, although it could get quite salty towards the end. Packed with slices of potato and lotus root, black fungus, kelp, golden mushrooms, potato glass noodles, bean curd skin, and bean sprouts. The grilled fish was boney. The dish was more on salty side than spicy especially towards the bottom of the dish.Fried Pork Intestine (S$16++)The spare part was soft and chewy in texture, with no strong taste or smell. Crab Yellow Bean Curd (S$10++)Orangey in colour, the dish tasted better than its look. There was bits of salted egg yolk in the sauce,Steamed Pork With Vegetables (S$12++)From the picture it looked Steamed Mui Choy with Pork Belly (Mei Cai Kou Rou/梅菜扣肉), but the taste was quite difficult from the expectation. It was very saltly especially for the vegetables.Fried Rice With Eggs (S$6++)The rice was not bad.
Cheap and good Thai food. Cannot beat the sembawang Thai food. But still good enough.

The restaurant was in causal style. Find your own table and place at the counter. There was no service but had GST. Menu was a single sheet. One had visited the place twice yet both times there was no BBQ pork rib. Waited for the queue to flash on the screen to collect the food at the counter. Help yourself to the condiments such as chilli sauce and sliced green chilli, as well as, the cutlery at the counter.Duck + Roasted Pork + Char Siew (S$26.80+/ big)The staff said the serving was for 3-4 paxs but dad said that the serving looked reduced in size.The roasted duck looked more like quarter of a duck and most pieces were quite boney. The skin tasted quite delicious.The roasted pork was not bad.The best was the char siew, honey with charred edges, while juicy inside.Accompanied the meats with Plain Rice (S$1+) and Plain Noodles (S$1.50+). Do take note that the noodles was served dry, tossed with dark soya sauce with chilli (optional). As the meats were served without sauce, do take note you could request for sauce from the staff.Shrimp Dumpling Noodle Soup (S$4.50+)Typical Hong Kong style. The dumplings were fat and juicy inside. The noodle was so yummy that the little one finished it off all by himself.Herbal Black Chicken Soup (S$6++)The soup was flavourful and herbal, packed with chucks of meats.Washed down the meal with Barley (S$2+/ cold) and Canned drink (S$2.50+).

Order 1/2 duck @$26, a small portion roasted pork and char siew @$10.60 with plain rice @$1 and a plain noodle @$1.50. The 1/2 duck is actually 2/3 of the 1/2 duck or at most 3/4 of the 1/2 duck. Please do not treat your customer like fools as I am sure most will know what a 1/2 duck look like. Overall the food is OK but think they are other selling the same food at better value.

Located on Tagore Lane is Xian Seafood Village, this seafood zi char is less than a year old. The entire coffee shop operates in the afternoon selling a variety of food, including herbal soups and lunch sets catered to the office and industrial crowd. By night, Xian Seafood Village is transformed into a full fledged seafood eatery.Xian Seafood Village prides itself in serving fresh seafood, as showcased with their numerous fish tanks of live sea animals. The owners have had experience in the fishing industry as well as F&B, hence they Really know their stuff in regards to fresh seafood.(1) Tasty Lady's Finger $10.00 (sml)The lady's finger was indeed tasty. Do not let this simple dish fool you, some might wonder, why is such a simple dish showcased?! Because it's really tasty! The texture of the lady's finger is just right, chewy, soft and yet oozing with veggie juicy goodness. Instead of ordering your typical fried kang kong, try this instead!(2) Flower Crab Trio Seafood Bee Hoon $25.00 (med)At a seafood zi char eatery, a special must order is their crab bee hoon. Few are able to execute this right. Flower crabs are usually chosen as it is able to bring a level of sweetness to the dish. However, the beehoon and the broth here didn't quite pick up the tinge of sweetness or flavour from the flower crab that I had expected. Xian Seafood Village is indeed generous with their ingredients in this dish of seafood bee hoon. I would say this is more than enough for 4 pax.(3) Specialty Braised Meat $15.00 (sml)Instead of sweet and sour pork, get this! A delicious meaty dish served with a layer of fats, aka the three layered meat. The pork was tender and you could taste the positive end results from the braising process.(5) Hong Kong Style Steamed Shark Lips $35.00 onwards (sml) About 600gmSo, this is a very interesting dish, labelled as Shark Lips, but the owner shared that this is actually lips of a Sturgeon. Which after some research shows that it is a label for some 27 species of fresh water fish. That may or may not be endangered. This really begs the question, since everyone is so afraid of eating sharks, thinking it's not environmentally friendly, how much "better" is it for the environment, if we eat another type of fish as a delicacy? But in all honesty, sturgeons do look alot like sharks.|(6) Fragrant Garlic Pork $10.00 (sml)The sliced pork all curled up nicely when fried and I half expected a crispy, crunchy texture. But alas, it was not. It was rather tough but it carried an aromatic fragrance that was pretty appetizing.(9) Cheese Baked Seafood Platter $138 onwards- Lobster, Jumbo Crab, Prawns, Fan shell scallops & LaLa.A feast fit for a king. This dish definitely showcases Xian Seafood Village's capability to serve up a wide range of fresh seafood in a newer style of cooking catered to the younger palate. The crab here was very fresh and it absorbed the cheese sauce rather well. The cheese sauce is thick and gooey! But it was again, more buttery and milky than it was cheesey. It wasn't gerlat at all, while digging into this dish.(11) Soft shell crabs $25.00 ($5.00/pc) *highly recommended*I am SO COMING BACK FOR MORE OF THIS! Crispy, freshly fried soft shell crabs that just go CRUNCH CRUNCH! in your pre-molar and molars! The batter isn't too think such that you find it dripping in oil.You can actually taste the crab meat that is beneath the fried soft shell crab.  This is probably what I would think is their stand-out signature dish, quite unseen anywhere and this is where other seafood zi char have yet to offer.Overall : Amidst the hype about cafes and ice cream dessert spots, Zi Char is something that never dies out. While the influx of online novelty cheese creations, Xian Seafood Village manages to tie it with their fresh seafood offerings. The location is okay to get to via private transport, it's airy and well-cooled. The staff are extremely friendly and helpful as well. Definitely try their fried soft-shell crab!

I have never felt the need to post a review to warn people about how bad a place is until today. We were celebrating mothers day as well as my grandmother's birthday and invited all my aunts to have dinner with us. The experience was so bad it really ruined our day.1. Even though we had a reservation for 8 we had to pester them to see if we could have the open tables.2. After ordering we waited for at least an hour and 15 mins (plus after multiple complaints), before we actually got our first dish and rice.3. My grandmother was so hungry she actually finished a whole bowl of rice when the first dish came and we had to wait at least another 15 mins before the other dishes started to come.4. The food wasn't even worth the wait. There were a few redeeming factors like the 鱼头汤 and soft shell crab, but everything else didn't taste good. The sambal kang kong had no sambal taste. The sauce in the broccoli with scallops was tasteless so it just tasted like plain boiled broccoli. The fragrant garlic pork was easily the worst dish of the night.5. By the time we were done eating, we were pretty much the last table to leave (around 10:40), and all they did was say 不好意思. We were NOT the last table to be seated.To be fair, the prices are reasonable but the service was ridiculous. Please don't come here and ruin your own day. Will definitely NOT recommend to anyone.
Waited over 2 hours and no food was yet served.We even had reservations made and arrived in time.Fair warning.

Was there at 5pm, Q for 45 mins and ordered our food but was told we have no table number orders cannot be processed! Prior to Queuing was informed table will only be available after we place our food order. Most tables were either reserved or occupied. No table available after half hour decided to take out. Was very disappointed with the above arrangement and stall was in chaos! Many frustrated customers too! Food was good tho. Perhaps it's the weekend.

The Japanese restaurant was opened recently on 23 September. It was located next to the information counter, with a small dine in area. Do take note that the last order was just before 9pm. Order was taken by tablet on the table. With spot lights all over the place, the place was pretty hot. Iced water was not served even after order was taken. It was finally served when one requested from the staff.Akimitsu's Signature Tendon 秋光天丼 (S$14.90++)Prawn, White Fish, Egg, Seaweed, Assorted VegetablesServed with chawanmushi and miso soup Selected Asakusa original sauce as Tendon sauce.Free flow pickled bean sprouts on the table to help yourself to.There's also chilli powder and Tendon sauce on the table.There's tempura egg hidden under the pile of 2 prawns , 1 fish, 1 carrot, 1 mushroom, 1 eggplant, 2 french beans, 1 baby corn, 1 pumpkin, seaweed which looked deflatedWhile the tempura was crispy, it got rather dense halfway.Fish tempura was a tab too mushy inside.Topup S$4.90 for iced lychee lemon tea which looked pretty cloudy.

address: 930 Yishun Avenue 2 #03-06/07 Northpoint Shopping Centre Singapore 769098 Singapore
comment: Recently Seoul Garden HotPot has opened, taken over the space of sister restaurant Breeks. From western food, it now serves Korean hotpot, BBQ and rice dishes. Although the menu looks limited, the business seems not bad based on the crowd on weekday nights.Ginseng Chicken ($17.90++, Member's Price $15.80++)Served with pickles and plain rice. The soup was very rich and flavourful which we finished all till the last drop. The chicken was tender and stuffed with rice, ginseng, garlic, and jujube. The ginseng would be better had it been cooked longer. Quite hard to bite.Premium Seafood HotPot ($16.90++, Member's Price $14.80++)Served with pickles and plain rice. Topup $1++ to upgrade the plain rice to Kimgaru rice. The seaweed flavour was quite tasty itself.Available in Kimchi and Miso soup bases, we selected miso one. Quite rich and tasty. The soup was filled with slices of abalone, prawns, clams, golden mushrooms, glass noodles and leek.Deep-fried Wing Sticks ($5.90++)The chicken looked not bad but I felt it not crispy and juicy enough.Deep-fried Fish Skin ($5.90++)The worst dish of the meal turned out to be this. Quite crispy but left a oily feel.Cinnamon Tea ($3.30++)The only free flow drink on the menu, available in both hot and cold version. Mother had the hot version which was pretty hot. Strong in cinnamon taste with a couple of jujube on top. The right drink to have on a cold day.Santa Cinnamon Cane ($6.90++)A Christmas special drink. It tastes creamy with slight cinnamon flavour in it.Overall the food was not bad. Staffs were quite friendly. Although the place was packed, it was still easy to get the staffs' attention.

I eat at Toast Box a lot whenever I'm in SG mainly because I've been going for a long time and I know what I like. Throughout the years the taste quality of the food has stayed the same. That's a good thing; I only come to SG about once a year and I like that I can depend on a place to maintain the same quality of food I had a year ago. However, I am dismayed with how the prices have increased. If you're going to begin charging more, than maybe amp up the quality, or at least the portion sizes. Will it hurt to serve a little more extra rice? My go-to order is the chicken curry and I am never able to properly finish with enough rice to curry ratio. This was fine back when the food was cheap. But this whole meal was nearly  SG$17 and I hardly got any satisfaction out of it. The hawker centers provide better food for way less. Only reason this place gets a 4 star rating is because I love how Toast Box has convenienced me in the past with their location and static menu item. I've also had fond memories of coming here with my mother, so the high rating is also for sentiment.

rest_name: Song Fa Bak Kut Teh 松發 肉骨茶
comment: Delicious bah kut teh broth with unlimited refills. Thoroughly enjoyed my meal with the tenderloin sliced meat version instead of the conventional pork ribs which usually required some effort to clean out the bones. There was an abundant portion of sliced and minced meat easily consumed without any bones, tender and seasoned well which goes perfectly with the fragrant tasty pork broth that has a nice peppery oomph to it. Coupled with tau pok in a tasty braised broth sauce on rice and continuous soup refills generously conducted by the friendly staff, I am pleased to declare this as one of my favorite meals in recent times, thank you!

rest_name: Song Fa Bak Kut Teh 松發 肉骨茶
comment: Song Fa was a well known chain in Singapore. Just a day ago, it had just opened a outlet at Northpoint Shopping Centre. The place was packed during lunch but we managed a table all the way at the end. Order was taken on ipad by staff. Wet tissue on the table was complementary. Pork Ribs Soup 排骨肉骨茶 (S$7++/ small)The rib was tender with none of the porky taste.Pig's Kidney/ Pig's Stomach Soup 猎腰与猎肚汤 (S$8++/ small)The spare parts were tender and easy to chew.Braised Chicken Feet with Beancurd Skin 焖凤爪与腐竹 (S$4++/ small)The chicken feet was well braised and tender.Braised Trotters with Intestines 卤猪脚与粉肠 (S$8++/ small)Well braised although would to be washed more thoroughly as it still tasted of a tab of bitterness. Kai Lan 芥兰 (S$4++/ small)The stems were chopped into small pieces and easy to eat.Mee Sua Plain 面线汤 (S$2.50++)Plain Rice 白饭 (S$0.90++)Soup was refillable and the staff often came around to refill. There was condiments such as sliced red chilli, chilli sauce, dark soya sauce and light soya sauce.

rest_name: Wan Chai Hong Kong Tea Room
address: 604 Sembawang Road, #03-12/13 Sembawang Shopping Centre Singapore 758459 Singapore
comment: To satisfy my craving for Hong Kong food, we decided to visit this place. The design of the interior is fairly standard and looked ordinary. We found a seat fairly quickly and were attended to by a waitress quite promptly.The food here is pretty standard HK fare: noodles, baked rice, toast and desserts.What's interesting is that they have various Yuan Yang dishes, which serve various foods of contrasting colors together.We had the cheese baked Yuan Yang rice, which came with a combination of pork chop and seafood. I liked the white creamy part better, and that part mainly consisted of seafood. The red part was just average though.The Yuan Yang cream was quite nice even though the presentation was not up to standard. Finally, we had the Yuan Yang coffee-tea, which came perfectly mixed.Overall, a decent place to have a good meal.

address: 54 Sembawang Road, #01-01 Hong Heng Mansions Singapore 779085 Singapore
comment: The name of this place sounds pretty boastful but we decided to give it a try since we were in the area.The décor of the place is fairly standard and the service was quite good. But let's talk about the food.Honestly, I thought that the food here was fairly mediocre. We had the steamed fish but I thought that the fish was not that fresh. A few other dishes weren't very satisfactory as well, but fortunately the serving size was adequate. Give this place a miss.

address: 900 South Woodlands Drive, #01-07 Woodlands Civic Centre Singapore 730900 Singapore
comment: I went to this restaurant a while ago with my friends while we were craving some Thai food.I ordered the fusion dish, which was basically thai fried noodle with chicken cutlet. This dish was quite nice! I liked the texture of the noodles and the chicken was also quite succulent.My friend ordered the set lunch, which came with a main dish, tom yam seafood soup, and rice. To be honest, the tom yam soup was somewhat bland and I was not very impressed with it. Another friend ordered the black pepper beef and that was quite nice.Overall, I think the set lunch is quite value for money, and the casual ambience makes this place a pretty good place to chill. Recommended.

Recently the coffeeshop had gone through a change and renamed 31 Coffee Shop. All the stalls in the coffeeshop had been replaced with new stalls. The zhi char stall was now called EC Kitchen 简单小厨. Being new, the coffee shop was packed during dinner time. We were lucky to grab a table facing the flat screen television.Curry Fish Head ($22)Served in a claypot, the dish was topped with lots of crispy beancurd skin, which went quite well when dipped in dark soya sauce. The curry was spicy and rich. The vegetables such as eggplants and lady's fingers were soft and moist in the dish. The fish meat was chunky and meaty.Yam Ring ($18)The yam ring was crispy and moist and soft inside. I like that there was not too much flour mixed with the yam paste to form the ring, based on the taste and the color of the yam ring. The filling in the centre was moist and crunchy without being too wet.Prawn Paste Chicken ($11/ medium size serving)The chickent mid joints were crispy and moist inside. Slightly salty due to the prawn paste, although I wished for a stronger prawn paste taste.Claypot Beancurd ($10/ medium size serving)Pieces of fried beancurd, with assorted vegetables and roast pork. The roast pork was soft and tender.Vegetables with 3 Types of Egg Yolk ($12/ medium size serving)The dish was well cooked and the gravy was drinkable as soup without being too salty. The dish was even spread with the mixture of eggs in it.Dried Tang Hoon ($4.50)The noodle was moist and not too oily.Overall the food was delicious and reasonable priced. Service was fast and smooth.

This place is pretty inventive with their BBQ/steamboat combination. The way it works is you BBQ your meat on the top of the grill, and the juices from the meat flow down into your soup, adding more flavor the more you grill. There are two soup bases you can choose from: Tom yum or pork. The quality of the meat was not amazing, but the flavors were really good and their Thai iced tea is so good here! I would come again if given a chance.

People in this place are really not friendly.They do not takr time to explain to customers.I also noticed that some veggies are frozen and some of them have not been washed.The place itself is smelly and dirty. I do not recommend at all.

So, we heard good things about the food here. We decided to give it a try. Came around 1pm, looked around, decided to go sit inside to order. It seemed like a few big groups had recently left (empty dirty tables), so the staff was running around to clean up. Understood.We sat there a good 10mins before we flagged someone to take our order (we made up our minds thanks to the photos on yelp because nobody even acknowledged us until that point). The guy stops, we order 1 thing and are about to order something else when he looks up and start talking to someone else and just leaves our table.Later as he passes by again, we look at him expectantly and he just laughs at us while going on with his life. Another 5mins and we ended up leaving since still no acknowledgement of us was done.Maybe they have great food, maybe not. We sure didn't get a chance to try.Terrible experience.

address: 598 Yishun Ring Rd #B1-06 The Wisteria Mall Singapore 769698 Singapore
comment: The outlet was located at the basement of the newly opened neighbourhood mall. For a relatively new outlet, I was kind of surprised that it charged GST. Just opened, already got taxable turnover exceeds $1million?Black Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen (S$13.90++)A touch of roasted garlic oil add a punch on signature Tonkotsu ramenThe presentation was kind of plain. It was served with black fungus, bamboo shoot, 2 slices of cha shu, and a half serving of Ajitsuke Tamago (lava egg). The broth was milky. Overall the dish was average without any WOW. For this price I expected more. There was no free flow hard boiled eggs and marinated bean sprouts as commonly offered by Ramen outlets. The fresh bamboo shoot was kind of too big in size and further more it was the fresh kind instead of the usual marinated type.

Newly open in late September 2016 inside a coffee shop near Chong Pang Food Stalls & Market.  Blk 101 Yishun Avenue 5 #01-03, Singapore (760101). Busy crowds queuing for food.  Tried both Grilled Chicken Chop and Grilled Salmon. Simply fresh and delicious, even it's a takeaway order! Highly recommended!

The restaurant was located at the south wing of shopping mall. Although the restaurant was crowded, one was would able to get a table fairly quickly. Food was served very quickly too. In fact I went to the loo straight after placing order, yet the dishes were served before I came back. There was no GST but got 10% service service.Hot Lemongrass (S$3.90+)Not too sweet and tasted flavourful.Mango Salad (S$7+)Tangy without too spicy. Beware of the sliced chilli padi.Bangkok Chicken (S$8.50+)It was served with Red Thai Zesty Sauce, which was spicy and tangy at the same time.Sambal Kang Kong (S$6.90+)The vegetables was well fried, similar to typical zhi char style. It was just delicious to go with plain rice.Green Curry Chicken (S$9.50)Rich without too spicy.Red Ruby with Jackfruits (S$4.50+)The pile of shaved ice looked slightly smaller than expected but the texture was quite fine. Remember to mix as it could be quite sweet on top.
Good Thai food. I tried their fried rice, tom yum, and mango sticky rice, with iced Thai tea and lemongrass drink. In my opinion all came out  Will come again for sure. #recommended

The restaurant was part of a chain, and was the latest outlet to be opened at Northpoint. Being new, the place was crowded even on weekdays. Do take note that the wet tissue and pickles on the table are chargeable. Water was chargeable too. Wuyishan Da Hong Pao 武夷山头春大红袍 (S$6.90++/ pax)15 days per year, prime harvest periodPrized as an early spring tea from Wuyi Mountains with only a golden harvesting period of 15 days. PUTIEN Da Hong Pao excludes the premium quality through the crisp fresh taste and lingering fragrance.As part of the opening promotion, the restaurant was giving away 500 Ceramic Da Hong Pao Mug* with every order of the tea.The tea was light and refreshing. One could also ask the staff to refill the tea with hot water. There was timer served with the tea, so that one would know how long to soak the tea leaves in water, before drinking.Starters Platter 精美四彩拼 (S$16.80++)Seaweed and Mini Shrimps 虾苗拼头水紫菜, To retain the best texture and nutrition of the seaweed, we use only 15cm-long top-grade seaweed that is harvested within 30 days after cultivation. Tossed with quality mini shrimps imported from the South China Sea region, every mouthful of this starter is a delightful and refreshing experience.Braised Homemade Bean Curd 卤水嫩豆腐, PUTIEN's specialty bean curd braised for savoury bursts of flavour every biteCold Pork Trotters Jelly 水晶猪蹄冻, An all-time favourite packed with flavour and collagenBraised Pig Intestine 九转粉肠The Seaweed and Mini Shrimps was being replaced with Braised Bamboo Shoot. Bamboo shoots smoked in slow fire, then braised for a savoury finishOne wished that the staff would inform the customer about the change when placing order. The jelly was pretty disappointing as it felt more like plain jelly topped with spicy sauce. The bean curd was the outstanding dish here as it was soft and soaked up the flavours rather well here.'100-Second' Stewed Yellow Croaker 百秒黄花鱼 (S$13.80++)The yellow croacker is stewed precisely within a hundred seconds, which is a revolutionary breakthrough cooking technique which originated from PUTIENThe meat of the fish was very tender, but beware of the many fine bones which could be found in the fish.Spinach in Supreme Stock 上汤苋菜 (S$13.50++/ small)The soft and tender chinese spinach is first stir-fried on high heat for flavor, then stewed in rich supreme-stock mix of century egg and salted egg to give it a burst of flavour.Served in an orange colour broth, the dish was light and flavourful, although one could not differentiate the salted egg from the normal egg.PUTIEN Ca Fen 农家擦粉 (S$9.50++/ small)A mixture of mee sua, noodles and bee hoon in a delicious, heartwarming soup with an assortment of vegetables, seafood and pork. It was fine noodles in thick broth with lots of ingredients such as crab stick, bean curd, clams, and sliced intestine. Looked gluey, it was rich and flavourful.PUTIEN Crispy Shrimp Roll 甫田虾枣 (S$11.90++/ small)Golden crispy chunks of prawn, pork and water chestnut with sweet sauce dipThe dish was the last to arrive. One could not help but suspect that the kitchen staff cooked this dish in bulk, as every table was served this dish at the same time. It was served with sweet sauce. While coating in a light and crispy batter crust, the inside was more like fish cake, as it was minced too finely and packed with too much flour, lacking of crunchy texture and natural sweetness of crunchy shrimps, and crunchy water chestnut.Interestingly the staff served each table with mentos as mouth refresher after the meal, which was uncommon for chinese restaurants. As the restaurant was still new, be prepared to wait quite awhile for the dishes to be served.

rest_name: Takezo Ramen by 麺屋武藏
comment: The Japanese restaurant was recently opened with a small dine in area. It specialized in ramen dishes which was offered in 4 different soup bases, as well as, dry maza soba version. Although the place looked pretty crowded with long queue, the queue moved quite fast.Yakibuta Maza Soba (S$12.90++)Made it a set at S$15.90++ with a choice of small side and a cup of Houji teaFree upsize of noodle for maza Soba up to 3X, which I selected 2X. The ramen was dry and lacking of flavour. It looked just tossed with dark soya sauce. Would prefer if there is some chilli sauce to add some kick to the dish.The dish was served with an onsen egg and a cup of broth.The pork belly was pretty tiny comparing to the picture on the menu. Felt cheated. Anyway not tender enough too and very fatty.The Ramen Cracker was hard and kind of preferred some dip to go with it.Free Chijimi (S$5.90++) when showed the staff that you had liked its Facebook page. It tasted like spring onion pancake, served with a soyu dip.

rest_name: Takezo Ramen by 麺屋武藏
comment: Ramen noodles don't taste authentic Japanese  , noodles are not home made , pork are boiled till soft and bland, instead of chewy and meaty taste. Soup is too salty and didn't have the fragrant and rich taste as expected.lemon tea is taste more like sugar tea.Didn't have a pleasant experience as I expected.

rest_name: Takezo Ramen by 麺屋武藏
comment: Ordered chashu ramen garlic w gyoza set. Broth was fantastic ... unfortunately noodles was  below par. Felt like maggi noodles.

address: Blk 236 Yishun Ring Road, #01-1000 Singapore 760236 Singapore
comment: This place is delicious!I grew up eating vegetarian because my parents are vegetarian (buddhist vegetarians, which means no seafood too!)While visiting Singapore on my vacation, I stumbled upon Zi Zai. This place reminds me of the home-cook meals that my parents would make when I was growing up.I came to this place twice before I had to travel back to the states.I will be back when I am in Singapore.

address: Blk 236 Yishun Ring Road, #01-1000 Singapore 760236 Singapore
comment: I am a hardcore carnivore so it is really rare to find me at these types of restaurants. However, for some reason my friends decided to visit a vegetarian place, so I had to tag along.Anyway, I thought this place was quite okay. The assam fish was pretty good, and the other vegetarian dishes were quite nice though (considering that I am a meat lover). Quite a nice place to get a taste of vegetarian dishes.

address: Blk 236 Yishun Ring Road, #01-1000 Singapore 760236 Singapore
comment: Uber delicious and huge Roti Prata. I went for Murtabak with veggies. Usually comes with cheese, but I asked to remove it. Freshly made and tasty - recommended.

address: 201 Yishun Ave 2 #01-01 Khatib MRT Station Singapore 769092 Singapore
comment: The outlet is located in the mrt station, just in front of control station. It sells a range of items from chicken rice to nasi lemak to fried noodles with various toppings to deep fried doughs.As the place was packed, I decided to takeaway a pack of fried bee hoon, topped with a begedil and chilli sauce. It cost $2.50. The bee hoon looked simple but was flavourful. The begedil was made of mashed potato, chopped shallot and chopped spring onion, and tasted quite flavourful and chunky. The chilli sauce which looked quite spicy, had a sweet aftertaste, which I wish I had asked for more.

address: 201 Yishun Ave 2 #01-01 Khatib MRT Station Singapore 769092 Singapore
comment: The chicken rice stall is cheap at $2 and though I initially assumed that good food could't be found in such place. The chickens is surprisingly good and tender while the rice is very fragrant. Soya milk is cheap as well. It opens till late so you can still grab a late dinner at this convenient location of Khatib MRT.

address: 201 Yishun Ave 2 #01-01 Khatib MRT Station Singapore 769092 Singapore
comment: chicken rice is cheap at $2. ventilation is bad, one will smell like food after a meal there. i packed a $2.50 thai fried chicken rice for takeaway. taste average. will consider this place if i am on a budget.
One of my cousins introduced me to the white beehoon that this restaurant is really well known for.  Service was fast and pricing was good.

Chinese have their Tu Tu Kueh, Malay counterpart is called Putu Piring. I chanced upon this Putu Piring in 2005 at a stall in Changi Village Hawker Center. There after, I sought after it at the same stall but they no longer carry it. I had the chance to eat it again at Bedok but I could not remember the exact place I saw and lost it once more. This Putu Piring is basically flour with Gula Melaka (Coconut?) steamed to perfection and then served hot with grated coconut. The grated coconut is salted and gives the combination a good taste. They have many fillings to try but I decided to stick to the original Gula Melaka filling. Each pack comes with 3 small size Putu Piring and grated salted coconut. A definite "will come back to buy".

The restaurant was opened recently at the new wing of the shopping mall. The dine area was rather small and tables were quite near to each other. Do take note that cutleries are located in the drawers under the tables.Tteokbokki Jjigae  (S$38.90++)It was rice cake stew fiesta and came with succulent mussels, egg, fish cakes, spam, sausages, and mushroom. Selected non-spicy so that the little one can enjoy the dish too.The soup was clear and tasted more on the sweet side. The colorful rice cakes were in tubes and star shapes and packed with different fillings.Rolling Cheese Chicken Wings (S$22.90++)Roll roll the cheese gently on the chicken wings! And fries on melted cheese ...Yum!Selected honey garlic flavour for the chicken wings. The staff melted the cheese at the table and wrapped the chicken with cheese. Mixed the rest of the fries and shredded cabbage in the leftover melted cheese. It was such a sinfully cheese fries.Sinsa PatBingSoo       (S$15.90++)Rockmelon, Pat, Nata De Coco, Cornflakes, Almond, Vanilla Ice creamInterestingly presented in a rockmelon. Not too sweet even after adding the milk.Hot Yuzu (S$3.90++)Beer Popsicle (S$11.90++)Selected melon flavour which was why it was served green color. Could not taste the beer in the soda drink. Felt a bit cheated.Overall the food was kind of overpriced. Paid over S$110 for this meal.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: The place was opened 24 hours with a selection of local food and drinks such as prata, and mee goreng. It was under the Mr Teh Tarik Group, which also have Mr Teh Tarik Eating House and My Briyani House under it. Prata Banana Cheese (S$3)Not sure why the sweet prata was served with gravy by the side. Anyway there sugar at the counter to help yourself. Too bad the prata was not hot enough to caramelise the sugar.Teh Tarik (S$1.30)The drink served with lots of bubbles on top. It was rich and creamy without too sweet.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Ordered Mutton Chop which cost at $8.50. When the food is ready the fries was fried using used oil which being used for mamy times. The fries really look not fresh at all. When requested to get a fresh fries. The cashier refused.

address: 1 Woodlands Square #02-10/K10 Causeway Point Singapore 738099 Singapore
comment: Made a reservation before going to the restaurant. The place was not crowded. Selected the booth seat table which overlook the ground floor. Quiet end of the restaurant so a tab difficult to get the attention of the staff. Please note that plain water was chargeable, at $0.30++ per glass.Enquired about 1-for-1 promotion by FEAST mobile application. The staff replied that its only available before 5pm which I replied it was not stated. The second staff replied that one redemption could used. But in the end, all 3 redemptions available at this restaurant on the application in my mobile phone were being processed as used by another staff. It was an confusing experience, but at least I received 1-for-1 my orders of 2 mains, pizza and pasta.Hawaiian Pizza ($14.90++)Say Aloha to this generous spread of honey baked ham, pineapple and shredded mozzarella cheese on a crispy crust served with pizza sauce.Lots of liao on the pizza. Crispy fluffy base.Grilled Chicken Fettuccine ($14.90++)This amazing fettuccine is served with a hefty portion of grilled chicken, sundried tomatoes and garlic cream sauce.It looked like noodle soup when served. The dish was tasty and the thick amount of sauce kept the noodles moist and hot.Empire State BBQ Pork Ribs ($17.90++)Fall in lover with this tender pork ribs rubbed with signature spice seasoning and flavoured with homemade BBQ sauce. Served with fries and mesclun salad.The serving was huge. The meat was tender and well flavoured, tear easily from the bones.Grilled Salmon with Thermidor Sauce ($17.90++)Salmon grilled the way you like with a themidor sauce and served with mashed potato and buttered vegetables.The fish was juicy and moist. The themidor sauce was a tab of sourness.The place was just next to a playground where the little ones could have their fun while the adults eat.

address: 1 Woodlands Square #02-10/K10 Causeway Point Singapore 738099 Singapore
comment: Service was friendly and while it's off peak, the place was still busy on a Sunday. The ribs was a bit tough, fish and chips was one big crispy slab and roast chicken was just ok. The fries were disappointingly soggy.

address: 1 Woodlands Square #02-10/K10 Causeway Point Singapore 738099 Singapore
comment: This is a place that serves "traditional" American fare, such as burgers, pizzas and the like.I have to admit that I am not terribly fond of American food (having spent over a year in the states), but my friends insisted on coming here, so here I am.I ordered the pepperoni pizza, which was pretty tasty but nowhere near authentic I must say. However, my friends and I really enjoyed this quite a lot. The dough was thick and topped with oily and cheesy pepperoni. The whole thing was pretty big so I guess sharing among 3 is just nice.We also had the house burger and honestly, I felt that this one was just okay. The beef patty was pretty generous and nice, and the bun was just okay, and that was about it.Overall, this is an affordable place for decent western food.

address: 1 Woodlands Square #02-10/K10 Causeway Point Singapore 738099 Singapore
comment: Been here twice and I wasn't that impressed with the restaurant. The 4-cheese pasta was gooey and sticky. This time we ordered a half chicken and a marinara pasta with a starter dish, cheese sticks. Oh, I'm sorry. It's not cheese sticks it's cheese popiah (aka cheese egg rolls). We were disappointed with it and my friend doesn't even touch it. My pasta was still gooey it was edible because I added the hot sauce and parmesan cheese. My friend finds the half chicken's sauce is too salty. I had a bowl of mushroom soup which is a little too salty too. Don't think I'll come back again. I rather go to Arby's and IHOP in America.

address: 1 Woodlands Square #02-10/K10 Causeway Point Singapore 738099 Singapore
comment: I am not sure of this place. I had it when they were open near Bugis a couple years back and it was really tasty....had it 2 weeks ago in Woodlands and was really disappointed. The only thing they got right was the milk shake. The hot dog tasted bland, the french fries were bland, the brownie...bland....It just wasn't that memorable. Customer service was ok...but I was there at like 3pm when there were few other customers so it was easy to get someone's attention.

address: 3 Northpoint Drive #01-04 Yishun Town Square Singapore 768020 Singapore
comment: The restaurant was opened in late May this year and offered conveyor belt sushi. What made this place different from other Conveyor Belt Sushi restaurants was that items ordered  on the ipad were sent to the table through the upper deck conveyor belt with music along and notification on the ipad's screen informing one of incoming orders. Remember to press the button by the side of the sushi car after collecting the order.We went wild on its new Mentai menu.Ebi Mentai (S$6.80++)Thick layer of the rich creamy sauce which makes it so sinfully yummyGintara Mentai (S$8.80++)Another yummy dish but beware of its bones.Salmon Mentai (S$7.80++)French Fries  Mentai (S$3.80++)Looks simple, but addictive.Karatsuki Hotate Mentai (S$5.80++)The scallop was smooth with the creamy sauce on top.Foie Gras sushi (S$7.80++)It smell very yummy when served. The sinfully rich liver was melt in the mouth.Toro Sushi (S$15.80++)Not bad although kind of wished it could be more fatty. One Chirashi Don (S$12.80++)So colourful presented with the range of sashimi.Help yourself to the tea bag on the table to make green tea with the hot water off the tap.
Dory Fish & Chips from the Western Cuisine stall - simpleBut teh-o is only $0.50 per cup. No other foodcourt (i think ) we can find teh-o this price!

Among the several culinary heresies that I nearly committed on the way was forgetting to have the seriously amazing frog leg porridge available at several spots in Singapore. I didn't have much time left and was honestly quite sick of traveling more than 15 minutes, which meant being seriously limited to a location that is rather pathetic when it comes culinary choices. Despite being frazzled and hauling the last few "donations" of accumulated material wealth to those who had first dibs, I still tried to remember if there was anything in the bucket list that I *needed* to get done before I flew out.I was 100% sure I forgot something - that the list was incomplete. Yet, as much as I searched within, I came up empty. Thankfully, one of the cousins brought me to the light.FROG LEGS. Holy freaking toddler. I forgot about FROG LEGS. Scramble the jets, we've got a national emergency. Where can I get decent frog leg porridge in the area? A barrage of text messages and phone calls later, I found myself back in Yishun 925 yet again - and not for Hainanese Chicken Rice!All opinions received pointed out the same thing: Frog Leg Porridge here is as good as the famous spot in Geylang.While I obviously never tried the one in Geylang (nor any other spot that is), the "Kung Pao Frog Legs" here was beastly awesome. So freaking awesome that it justified the binge.About $30 for 3 legs and a large bowl of porridge left me half dead from a combination of the chili-heat and the intense humidity of this particular food court (mixed with the infamous Singapore heat) BUT completely satisfied that I just dodged another culinary heresy.For the record, anyone who claims that frog legs taste like chicken...should never be a food critic. It tastes better than chicken. Definitely, tastes WAY BETTER than chicken. If anything, it tastes more like $$$ grouper $$$ cheeks - absolutely IMMACULATE.Yelp 100: 59/100 (yeah, yeah, yeah, I'm behind...I'll catch up soon...)/My-last-3-weeks-in-SG

address: 18 Yishun Aven 9 #01-23 Junction Nine Singapore 768897 Singapore
comment: The sushi outlet was the first outlet in Singapore. It was located in a neighbourhood mall. The outlet was decorated in a no frills style. The place was packed with family crowds. It was well known for its conveyor belt sushi which were priced at $1.30++ and $1.80++. Hot water from the tap was free of charge. NETS and cash were accepted here but cash was the preferred mode as there was high probability that the payment could not go through, which I had seen happened to the customer in front of me. Sashimi Salad ($8.50++)Salad topped with fresh salmon & octopusThe salad was served with sesame dressing by the side. The greens looked a tab flat.Salmon Mentai Dragon Maki 明太龙卷 (S$7.50++/ 4 pieces)Prawn sushi roll topped with salmon roasted with cod roeIt was a party in the mouth with its rich, creamy and crispy texture.Yasai Tempura ($5.50++)Assorted vegetables tempuraThe tempura was crispy but the carrot ones were quite hard to bite.Asari Miso Shiru ($3.80++)Miso soup with clamsThe soup was flavourful and not too salty.Chawan Mushi ($2.30)Steamed egg custardFelt that the texture was a tab too watery.Marinated jellyfish ($1.80++)Marinated octopus ($1.80++)Deep fried salmon skin ($1.80++)The texture was quite hard and dry.Ebi Fry with Tartar Sauce ($1.80++)The serving looked different from menu online as it was served as cut up into 2 pieces instead of 1 piece with a large piece of prawn as showed on menu. It tasted crispy and creamy.By the way don't expect any calls because your mobile phone will most probably unable to receive any network.

address: NorthPoint Shopping Centre 930 Yishun Avenue 2 #B2-17/20 Singapore 769098 Singapore
comment: Was in the area with my friend and decided to pop by for a quick meal.The chicken here was pretty good in our opinion. Although the serving size is admittedly pretty small, we thought that the chicken was quite succulent and the meat was quite tender. The taste was pretty good too; I liked the bbq coating.My friend had the garlic chicken steak, which he thought was pretty good. One feature of this place is that everything is fried in olive oil, which is supposed to be more healthy. Honestly I couldn't be bothered about this, but this may be something that people like.Overall, a decent place to have a meal.

address: NorthPoint Shopping Centre 930 Yishun Avenue 2 #B2-17/20 Singapore 769098 Singapore
comment: For students, BBQ Chicken's promotion is so tempting you wouldn't mind coming back again, and again. Although it is said to provide Korean dishes, but BBQ chicken, in my opinion, serves more Western dishes than your kimchi-filled spicy delights.From steaks to grilled chicken and dory fish, expect some good food for the amount you pay! Expect to wait for quite a long while as everybody wants a piece of some good deals in Singapore. The outlet at NorthPoint is rather small, so perhaps waiting for at least half and hour during lunch and dinner breaks is considered normal. Other than that, it's pretty decent, and good!

address: NorthPoint Shopping Centre 930 Yishun Avenue 2 #B2-17/20 Singapore 769098 Singapore
comment: Their one-for-one and student deals were tempting and sounded like good value for money, so the family and I came down to this branch for a birthday celebration on a weekend. It was packed, so we had to wait for quite a while to be attended to. Don't expect authentic Korean dishes here. What they actually do seems more like adding a Korean twist to Western dishes. They don't serve rice and soup together with the dishes; the dishes are accompanied with fries and coleslaw. We shared the hot hot drum (so spicy, two thumbs up!), olive luxury chicken (rather oily), Jamaican jerk spice (tender, succulent meat) and Korean traditional charboiled. The best was without a doubt, the hot hot drum. The promotion also meant we could choose free sundaes, salad, any fish item or any omelette rice. We decided to pick sundaes for dessert. It was certainly a filling meal that didn't burn a hole in our pockets.

address: NorthPoint Shopping Centre 930 Yishun Avenue 2 #B2-17/20 Singapore 769098 Singapore
comment: Food is great here! But what I dread the most about dining at BBQ Chicken is the extremely long time that they take to serve their customers. I literally waited for close to ONE hour for my food to be served. When I asked the waiter for an explanation for the long wait, he replied that the kitchen only starts cooking when an order is made. Ok, I appreciate that part. But that doesn't really make up for the extremely long wait. Food is great. Especially during their promotion periods e.g. 1 for 1 deals. If you're a student, check out the student specials page on the menu. Main course is around $7.90. But seriously, they've got to buck up on their speed. Else, their customers (myself included) are gonna scoot off to somewhere else with a more efficient kitchen. Recommended: Hot hot drum

address: 604 Sembawang Road #01-22/23, Sembawang Shopping Centre Singapore 758459 Singapore
comment: The Agedashi tofu is not bad and worth eating than other japanese restaurant Agedashi Tofu. First of all the sauce mixture is unami complete with totem asparagus and sexy prawns. It feels like swim at sentosa adventure cove with an explosion of dashi broth and flying sting ray. What you should eat here? Salmon Kaarage, Soba, Hotplate chicken and Agedashi tofu. I love sexy dishes....

address: 604 Sembawang Road #01-22/23, Sembawang Shopping Centre Singapore 758459 Singapore
comment: Located at sembawang shopping centre, this place simply reminds you of sakae sushi, even the design and the logo looks pretty similar. It has a conveyor system that serves sushi or you can order from the menu.Sushi variety is very limited and does not look appealing. Food does not look fresh and even if you order from the menu, the waiter or waitress might just take it from the conveyor belt, defeating the purpose of getting fresh dish. The soft shell crab tastes awful, there is a stale smell. Price is similar to sakae sushi but the quality of food simply does not justify the price that you will have to pay. Even during peak hours, you might find the shop pretty empty. Service level is below average, waiter and waitress are not responsive and you might need to nudge them a bit.

address: 604 Sembawang Road #01-22/23, Sembawang Shopping Centre Singapore 758459 Singapore
comment: As dinnertime drew near, I decided to try eating at a halal eatery called 'Hei Sushi'. The food joint reflects an ambience depicting the Japanese culture with green as its signature colour. Since green signifies the colour of nature and freshness, it's not surprising that the shop provides fresh sushi for consumer consumption. I queued up at the waiting line before being led to a table. I was offered a menu and made some quick orders concerning rolls of seaweed over sticky rice stuffed with tuna, crab meat, roe and other seafood delicacies. As I waited for my meal to come, I saw other customers made somewhat similar orders. The place is littered with white tables and brown chairs where customers sat comfortably while eating the sushi dish of their choice. There was an unmistakable aroma of seaweed and seafood lingering in the air that made my empty tummy rumbled with anticipation. As time progressed, my mouth watered until my food was served before me. The sushi lot on my plate looked enticing enough to be eaten, which I made my first bite on one of them.
