My eyes rolled up with ecstasy as the sushi freshness engulfed me starting from my mouth outwards. The superb taste simply overwhelmed me till I had to pause in collecting myself. As the last trail of sushi slid down my throat deep within me, I looked on at the rest of the sushi lot and devoured like a crazed lion. A series of blissful feeling surrounded me after every bite till I shuddered at the end of my meal. As the food experience subsided, I found myself full to the brim and decided to get takeaways for my family. I knew for certain they were going to get a real kick from eating sushi from Hei Sushi! Hei Sushi's (Halal) opening hours: 11:30am - 9:30pm.

The restaurant was located in the new wing, open concept style, offering taiwanese dishes.Feng Food Fried Duo (S$11.80)Hakka style Deep-fried Chicken and Deep-Fried TempuraThe deep fried chicken was in spiced salted style, topped with crispy tempura battered basil leaves. The leaves was light and crispy without the usual strong herbal taste.The deep fried tempura was actually battered pieces of dough which were slightly chewy inside.Dao Xiao Miao Noodles with Specially Marinated Pork Chop Soup 招牌猪排湯刀削麵 (S$11.80)I usually avoid knife shaved noodles as I felt it was usually quite thick but the version here was super thin and very smooth in texture, similar to mee poh but in a broader way, making one wondering if it's machine made.Hakka Style Braised Meat (S$5.80)The meat was well braised without feeling jetal from the fatty meat.Fried Rice with Shrimps & Eggs (S$11.80)The simple dish was quite tasty and similar to DTF style.Washed with Taiwanese Roselle Tea (S$2.80) and Lime Juice with Sour Plum (S$2.80)

This is probably one of the better Food Republic outlets in Singapore. My favourites are the Indian Shami Banana, Beef noodles stall and Lixin Fishball noodles, prices are higher than the coffee shops but they are value for money. The quality of these stalls are quite decent so do give them a try. Seating area is massive and you won't have much difficulty finding a place even if its crowded. There are some private seating areas, so you can find the seat quickly if you are eating at one of those allocated stalls, do take note that food from other stalls are not allowed.

The Food Republic at Causeway Point hosts around 20 stalls selling a good variety of food that, as is usual with Singaporean food culture, encompasses the traditional cuisines of several Asian countries. Seating is always abundant whenever I patronise the place, perhaps because I always do so after normal office lunch hours are over. The interior decoration evokes a homely vibe, with shelves along the walls upon which normal household trinkets are placed. Hygiene is excellent since I fail to detect a single stain on the tables and chairs.Prices are slightly higher than what you would get in other food courts, but the ambience of the place and the general quality of the food on offer go some way toward justifying it. It is, for now, the only food court operating at Causeway Point, since the Banquet food court is closed for renovation.

This is a great food court, all the basics stalls are there. Breakfast combos, Ban Mian, porridge, chicken and duck rice. There's nothing special about this food court but again there's nothing wrong with this food court. The decorations are well done though.

The outlet was the latest outlet of the chain. It was well known for its Volcano Ramen, where the shop used a cone-shaped lip with a cylinder top to cover their noodles, and steam came out during the cooking process just like an erupting volcano. The seats were quite limited, there's only 1 table which seat 4 persons with other seats around the counter and the common table. On the table, there was condiments such as (self crushed) garlic, dried chillies, chilli paste, vinegar, soyu, (self grated) sesame seeds and oil, as well as, free flow of hard boiled eggs to help yourself to. Water was served after ordering. No alcohol at the moment the license was not yet approved.Kazan Kaisen-Shio (S$18.80++)KAZAN-Style ramen original tonkotsu broth enhanced with special blended salt paste with seafood Served in a stone bowl, it kept the dish warm. The noodles was flat broad type which reminded one of ee mee. The soup was milky and flavourful, packed with cabbage, shredded carrot, prawn, mussel, calamari and scallop. For a serving, it was just nice for 2 to share.Ramen + Gyoza (6 pieces)  Set (S$17.60++)Selected Karamiso Ramen (S$12.80++ ala carte)Original tonkotsu broth enhanced with special blended spicy miso pasteThe paste was quite salty so beware about mixing all the paste into the broth. The ramen came with a slice of cha shu (simmered pork), 1 half of Nitamago (flavoured egg), Menma (bamboo shoots), Negi (chopped spring onion), and Nori (seaweed). The noodle used here was the commonly found thin version. Yaki Gyoza (S$5.80++ ala carte)The fried dumplings looked not bad but lacking of juice when bite.
Tried shoyu ramen & gyoza set...noodles was nice but not fantastic. Gyoza was extremely salty. Mentioned to staff but nothing was done. Disappointed..

The restaurant was a fast food type, offering korean fried chicken and other korean dishes. The place was decorated in funky colours. After plaing order at the counter, one would be given a buzzer which would light up when the food is ready for collection. While collecting the food, did not forget to collect the tiny tin bin for the bones, the condiments and disposable gloves by the side.Jinjja Drumsticks (S$8.90/ 3pieces)The chicken was available in 3 different flavours but we selected the non spicy soy garlic which was slightly sweet and salty.Topup $2 for soft drink & fries to make it a set.Selected Sesame Seaweed flavour for the fries. The fries was light and crispy.Chicken Luncheon Kimbap (S$7.90)Seaweed rice roll filled with generous chunks of chicken luncheon, Korean pickles, egg, cucumber and carrots.It was a maki roll stuffed with luncheon meat, cucumber, carrot and egg roll. The roll was not firm and broke easily. The flavour was not bad.Chicken BibimSalad (S$7.90)Beautiful and naturally vibrant salad, topped with Korean glass noodle and chicken chunks for a healthy and filling meal.The dish was very colorful itself. Lots of crispy crumbs which added texture. The light soyu dressing was refreshing.

Recently the restaurant has started offering breakfast menu during weekends and public holidays from 8am to 12pm. We arrived at the restaurant at about 11am. The place was not crowded. Instead of the usual indoor dining area, the staffs showed us to the outdoor dining area. The indoor dining area was empty except for a couple who were waiting for the lunch menu to start. Seem that everyone who were having breakfast, were given outdoor tables.Interestingly the tables were decorated with a sunflower each. We waited at least 30 minutes for our orders to arrive. We almost finished the first item, when the second one finally arrived. Quite a long wait for the food. It seems that it happened to all other customers too.Eggs Benedict ($12.95++)Start your day right with a hearty platter for 2, with prefectly poached eggs on top of crispy turkey bacon, melted cheddar cheese and oregano buns, grilled snail sausage, mini cheesy hash browns and fluffy pancakes with maple syrup.Could not taste any cheese in the hash brown and it was lacking of crispy crust. The pancake was not fluffy, even the little one gave after a couple of mouthfuls.Salmon 'N Mushroom Sandwich ($8.95++)Smoked salmon and sauteed mushrooms sandwiched between oregano buns makes for a light and healthy breakfast, complete with a poached egg in a crunchy tortilla bowl. The tortilla bowl was quite hard.Big Brekkie Delight ($9.95++)Banish hunger pangs with this delectable breakfast of Cherry Snapper fillets (fried or grilled - your choice!), scrambled eggs, mini cheesy hash browns, sauteed button mushrooms in a torilla bowl and thick toasts!It was quite hard to slice the not crispy toast with fish knife. Berry Happy Pancake ($7.95++)Put a smile on your face with layers of thick pancakes oozing with the goodness of Nutella! Complemented with strawberry, banana, oreo crumbles and served with maple syrup on the side.Just for Nutella lovers.Nutella & Banana French Toast ($4.95++)French toast is layered with Nutella and banana slices to satisfy your sweet tooth and give you an energy boost in the morningIt more like pressed sandwich than french toast. Not what I was expecting.Glory Fish Tower ($7.95++)Built with signature hand-battered fish fillet, crispy Onion Glory, lettuce and topped with thick toasts, it is a glorious feast that awaits your conquest.Waited the longest for this to be served. As same as other dish, it was difficult to cut through the toast with just fish knife. The ring slice was light and crispy. The fish was a tab mushy inside.Chamomile tea ($2++)Served with maple syrupYes I was surprised.Overall disappointed that the food had taken quite long to be served. Not the correct cutlery being served.

A personal preference that I continue to practice whenever in Singapore is to stick to "consolidated street vendors" (hawkers centres or food courts; my equivalent of tiny mom & pop shops in the US) instead of the larger food establishments UNLESS *specifically* requested otherwise. I have walked past enough Manhattan Fish Markets to smell the wafts of singed shrimp or fried goodies in their typical open layout...BUT never heard the luring call of mythical sirens in the distance trying to seduce me in.That changed when I visited a friend in Yishun who insisted that we eat some place in Northpoint to catch up. We found that most establishments were packed like sardines in olive oil with lines longer than a crazy 2 year old can ever draw. So as we walked around, I kept insisting on hitting up the famous chicken rice spot nearby...but was repeatedly turned down. ("Chicken rice? Come on, you can have that any other given day...")So we pranced around the tiled floors until we landed at the first establishment without a line. MFM with no lines and two vacant tables was more than glad to pull us in for a meal. Our friendly server sat us down and handed us menus to peruse until we both arrived at a decision to what our hungry selves would gorge upon while we initiate protocol "heavy data synchronization via conversation". (Btw, sure enough, a few minutes later, there was a line of more than 8 people outside; talk about perfect TIMING).Moi - Salade et Poisson (crispy whole barramundi); & Citrus Mint drinkCollègue - Soupe et Poisson (grilled cod); & Rootbeer float*******We can't say we love this place; however, we can admit to having paid a decent amount for seating space to have a conversation in an atmosphere better than Starbucks. As for the food, 1. Grilled cod was such a tiny but well-presented dish. The flavors were intact - albeit nothing mind blowing - and fun to look at. I was even betting that it took significantly more work on the line cook's part to get the presentation right compared to my dish.2. Grilled barramundi is definitely great for those who want to achieve the maximum bang for the little buck in establishments such as this. There was so much fish to consume over plain boring slightly seasoned rice that just trumped my friend's dish...but flavorwise...boring, lacking, and needing more "spice" to it. (If I had brought my little secret spice box, I could have fixed it in an instant and made it immaculate on the spot...)3. Salad - it is what it is....but was given the weirdest question when they brought our main dishes to us before anything else - including drinks. "Oh, you want your salad now?" (I'm sorry madame, when was I supposed to get the salade? Tomorrow?)4. Citrus Mint - perfect base for a couple shots of rum or vodka or tequila. Okay, I shouldn't think along those lines...but I was just seeing...potential.An interesting place...but not one I'd recommend to anyone looking for great food. But my friend did enjoy the place and the dishes - as well as the atmosphere and the fact that we could catch up after a significantly LONG time apart. I guess...that's what matters when you end up visiting the McDonald's equivalent of seafood joints.Au'revoir. Bon appétit.Yelp 100: 3/100

The food was terrible and the Service was AWFUL!  Do not go with a large party!  We had 13 people in our group and the staff was completely OVERWHELMED! The manager seemed upset when serving our food.  I don't know if she was upset with our party or her staff but she was very rude!  We had to ask for our drinks 3 times .  Kids meals were the last to come out....it was just awful!  I will not recommend to anyone!

I have just left the restaurant and felt a need to comment on the 'marvellous' customer service I was given. We went into the restaurant and server wasn't so pleased to serve. 3 of us went but we were given a small table by the side where your elbow hits the wall just sitting there. And after our meal, I was charged for what I had paid (a coupon from the deal website). Server took very long to void our receipt and no apologies was said. The two malay girls were fine but the big malay boy.. he really shouldn't be working if he don't feel like it. I might just avoid this outlet though. The prawns on the platter was delicious.

address: 604 Sembawang Road #03-14 Sembawang Shopping Centre Singapore 758459 Singapore
comment: Aston was definitely a lot better when it first started. I remember visiting their first restaurant when they first started out. They had a long queue outside the small place. I went back 2 more times because I was impressed. I visited a few different Astons these 2 years, but not the original. The price is still the same, but the quality has drop significantly. The taste is no longer there.

address: 51 Yishun Central 1 #01-04, Cinema Cineplex Singapore 768794 Singapore
comment: Probably the best chicken in Singapore, no doubt. The outlet here is relatively clean when compared to other fast food chains in Singapore, and although there's the smell of chicken in the air most of the time - I rather quite like it.I ordered the 2 person chicken meal (to share with another friend), and it arrived rather quickly. The chicken was crisp and hot when I bit into them, and the meat beneath the skin was as juicy as ever. The fries were tasty as hell too, and the condiments were pretty good too.The only negative that Arnold's has is the price of the meals. KFC has meals that are cheaper and they offer way more food then some of the meals offered here. But if you don't mind paying a bit more for really good chicken, I recommend that you get Arnold's instead.

address: 51 Yishun Central 1 #01-04, Cinema Cineplex Singapore 768794 Singapore
comment: Before you even step into the restaurant, you'd have smelt the uncomfortable stench of oil-probably due to the fact that the place is poorly ventilated. The place itself is quite clean and empty on a weekday afternoon, and sinks are provided as with most fried chicken outlets. Had the whole spring chicken set (which does not come with soda or water of any sort) which cost about 12 bucks. Once you've tasted the chicken, the smell you endure is worth it. (I probably got used to it after sitting there for a while) the chicken is fried to perfection with a thin coating of batter-not too much, so you'd enjoy more meat than crumbs of batter unlike some fried chicken restaurants. Would recommend this to be shared between two hungry people. The spring chicken also comes with a tiny portion of coleslaw and some fries. The chicken is probably the reason I'd visit again. Would be wise to skip the sides imo if you're ordering a la carte. 5 stars for the chicken, minus half for the sides & the fact that their set does not come with drinks, and -1.5 stars for the stench.

address: 51 Yishun Central 1 #01-04, Cinema Cineplex Singapore 768794 Singapore
comment: Chicken taste good. Coleslaw and mashed potato were superb... Please it with your bare hand...

The Japanese restaurant was newly opened, taking over the space formerly occupied by Popular bookshop. There was quite a list of items on the menu but there was no kid's meal for the little one. The wet tissue on the table was chargeable. Order was taken through ipad on the table. One had to walk to the cashier to make payment. Green tea was chargeable at $1.20++ and refillable, although it was a tab difficult to get the staff to refill during the peak dinner hour.Truffle Chasyu & Hijiki Soba ($12.80++)Chasyu & Hijiki seaweed salad with cold soba & truffle sesame sauceSmelt strongly of truffle oil when served. The sauce was a tab watery. The noodle was cold and refreshing. The dish was served with 3 pieces of chashu (braised pork belly).Tara & Salmon Nabe ($14.80++)Japanese Cod Fish & Salmon Hot PotThe hotpot did not come with rice. The pot was way too small and the soup got overflowed easily when cooking over the hot stove. There was choice between miso, shoyu, and spicy miso. Selected miso which tasted not bad.Shirasu & Kani Tappuri Kaiso Salad ($12.80++)Steamed Baby Sardine, Crab Flake, Japanese Seaweed, Onsen Tamago & Fresh VegetablesServed with 2 choices of dressing which I selected Sushi Tei and sesame dressing. The sushi tei dressing was mustard in color and tasted slightly spicy. The salad itself was quite refreshing.Truffle Kani Roll ($12.80++)Fried Crabmeat & Shiitake Sushi Roll with Tanuki & Truffle OilSmelt nice of the truffle oil. The combination was not bad with crunchy crispy crust but felt a tab too oil after a few more mouthfuls.

address: 678A, Woodlands Ave 6 #02-01, Admiralty MRT Station Singapore 731678 Singapore
comment: NTUC Foodfare offers a reasonable selection of cuisine catering to the heartlands of Singapore. The Admiralty branch hosts about 20 stalls. The hygiene standards are adequate enough. Malay and Indian cuisine are also available. As for the food, a few stalls are alright, the rest are mediocre. The fishball noodle stall demonstrates some pretty inconsistent standards. Different people handle the cooking, depending on their shifts, so look for the one who is male; he whips up the most satisfactory bowl of noodles. The beef noodle stall cannot compare to "The Hong House" when it comes to the all-important gravy, but it is at least cheaper by a dollar or so. The Yong Tau Foo stall offers healthier choices for the discerning diner, but the food is average at best, though noodle servings are generous.As the only eatery serving the surrounding estate, it can still get pretty crowded on the weekends.

A newly opened mini food court called Malaysia 马来西亚 Chiak!, offering authentic Malaysian street hawker fare. From Penang 7th Street Nonya Kueh stall, tried the Sweet Potato Huat Kueh ($2) which was served pipping hot from the bamboo steamer. The cake was soft and fluffy with bits of sweet potato.From 辣椒板面 Damansara Chilly Pan Mee stall, tried the Chilly pan mee ($4), which was noodles served in dry style, topped with dried anchovies and spicy chilli paste, with a bowl of a clear soup by the side. It looked plain but it was delicious.From Penang Jalan Cheong Fatt Tze stall,tried the Penang Laksa ($5) which was rather small in serving and lacking of the fish meat which was commonly found in this dish. But the dish was appetizing and tasty.From Kuantan Nasi Lemak stall, tried the Nasi Lemak ($3.50), topped up with chicken wing ($1.50), was delicious especially for its sambal and fish cake, but the chicken wing was slightly too dry. Also tried its Lontong ($3.50) which also had delicious sweet and spicy chilli paste.From Penang Road Famous Teochew Chendol 檳城律馳名潮洲煎蕊 stall,tried the Chendol ($2), which was topped with chewy green jelly strips and slightly salty kidney beans. It was not too sweet and the jelly strips did not turn frozen as it was usually the case for the commerical made jelly strips.

address: 30 Sembawang Drive #03-15/16 Sun Plaza Singapore 757713 Singapore
comment: The outlet was opened at the third floor, just in front of the escalator. The outlet was dim in lighting, decorated tastefully with the ocean theme. Currently the restaurant was having a 1-for-1 promotion for selected main course on Monday to Thursday from 6pm to 10pm. This promotion would end on 28 October 2016.Grilled Peri-Peri Chicken with Scallops ($19.95++)It was served with Seafood Paella Rice and Chips.The tender chicken was topped with a spicy sauce which was a highlight of the dish. It went very well with the buttery rice, although one could not taste the seafood in the rice.White Fish with Ebiko Gratin ($17.95++)White fish gratinated with ebiko roe.It was served with Coleslaw and Baked Pumpkin. The coleslaw while crunchy, was lacking of the mayonnaise. The fish however was not as fresh as I had tasted before. It was quite salty too.Topped up $9.90++ to make it a meal with a Soup of the Day and a Root Beer Float.The soup of the day was mushroom soup which was thick and rich. The drink was served overflowing and one had to drink it quickly to stop the overflowing.Hot Fudge Chocolate Cake ($6.95++)Moist chocolate cake luxuriously topped with homemade chocolate sauce and served with a scoop of vanilla ice cream.The hot and moist texture of the cake was nicely balanced by the cold creamy ice cream.Overall food was not bad. The service was great too. The little one vomitted on the floor which was swiftly cleaned up by the senior staff, although the younger staff seemed to be at a lose on handling the situation.

The restaurant was recently opened, taking over the space formerly occupied by a bakery.The dining area was limited and tables were placed quite near to each other.Pork Galbi Wok with Sticky Lava Cheese (S$38.80++)Non spicy versionAlso available in spicy version.Pork belly stir fried with potato, carrot, onion and cabbage. The cheese made the dish quite creamy.Accompanied with expensive plain rice which cost S$2++ each.Ginseng Chicken (S$17.80++)The tiny chicken was stuffed with sticky rice. Could not find any ginseng in it. Just only the fine hair roots. The soup tasted more on the weak side.Yuzu Tea (S$3.50++/ cold)The layer of yuzu was quite thin. The glass was more than half filled with ice cubes.Red Dates Tea (S$3.20++/ hot)The drink was weak in taste.Orange Tea (S$3.50++/ cold)Another weak in taste drink.No water was served.

address: 30 Sembawang Dr #01-16/17, Sun Plaza Singapore 757713 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
user_location: South Bay Terraces, San Diego, CA
comment: Hi guys. Sorry to leave your first, only, bad review, but look on the bright side - no one in Singapore seems to use Yelp. Ordered from Grab and it got here very promptly. Happy about that. The sandwich was a hot and tasty, happy about that. The chicken cutlet was on the small side, but that's the nature of "real" chicken, I guess, so I can't be that upset. It was very good, if only a little bigger would have been great. But the fries. The fries I have come to learn are a phenomenon all around Asia for being the best of any McDonald's in the world (I tried seven different restaurants today before McDonald's was my fallback, but at least the fries will be good!) and yet what I received were greasier than usual (fine), hot enough, but...old. Just clearly... old fries. How can that be? I got them with no salt, just to be double sure they would be fresh. But somehow, I got old, soggy, limp ass fries. So I paid the grab driver and tipped him for the speedy service (not his fault, eh?) and called the restaurant. It'll be a quick fix. It's only some fries and it's half a mile away. As expected, the McDonald's worker showed up maybe... ten minutes later? Super happy. We exchanged pleasantries and he went back to his bike. I came inside and opened my hot, aromatic bag of... more old crappy fries. I literally ran outside barefoot to stop him and am wasting time writing this stupid review because of how irritated it makes me to have this problem at all, let alone twice on the same order. Guys .. be better.

The place was crowded during dinner time with long queue but the crowd turnover was fast. There was a time limit of 50 minutes for dine in. All the plates on the conveyor belt were priced $1.50++, ranging from sushi to maki roll to salad to mango pudding to miso soup. Help yourself to the tea bags for hot green tea, sushi ginger, wasabi, soyu. The speed of the conveyor belt was quite fast, so target your items carefully.

address: 930 Yishun Avenue 2, #03-47/50 Northpoint Shopping Centre Singapore 769098 Singapore
comment: I was walking around Northpoint with my friend, and for some reason we started to have a craving for Japanese food. We happened to walk past this area and decided to give it a try. The outside had a very nice Japanese touch to it and the overall place looked rather inviting, so we decided to give it a try.The prices here seem to be quite affordable; slightly below typical restaurant prices. I ordered an omu (omelette) rice with chicken cutlet, and I found that the rice was quite nice. The egg was particularly delicious as it was fluffy and tasted very fresh. However, I felt that the chicken cutlet was somewhat too thin and lacked bite to it. It was also rather tasteless and I have certainly had better ones elsewhere.The curry sauce was pretty good though. I also liked the fact that the serving size was enough for me, a really big eater.Overall, a decent place to get your Japanese food fix.

address: 930 Yishun Avenue 2, #03-47/50 Northpoint Shopping Centre Singapore 769098 Singapore
comment: Singapore is one of few countries where food (both in quality and variety) is woven into the very fabric of the culture. Yes, it is present everywhere...be it out of necessity, out of fun, out of random rendezvous, out of boredom...out of whatever you name it...it simply exists.So I'm sure it eventually causes some to stop and question how it is even possible for TERRIBLE food to exist (not to mention, continue to thrive/survive in some cases) in such a foodie nation?Perhaps, after this particular pit-stop on my way to getting rid of half the accumulated junk, I have two possible answers:1. "Out of comfort / convenience" - this place isn't cheap when you make a direct comparison with hawker centres, food court / Kopitiams, or even other "restaurants" nearby. In fact, it's a lot more than the former and still higher than the some of the latter. But from the sheer number of people there...probably it's either the intensity of the heat or the fact that tables are so readily available that "choping" isn't even necessary.2. "Out of indifference" - I guess there are some people just don't give a crap anymore after a lifetime spent within a foodie nation. Carbs? Check. Salt? Check. Rice? Check. $8.50? Check. Table? Check. Chair? Oh yes, check. Kids? What kids? Check. Fudge it...I'm hungry.NOTE:All three dishes that I spontaneously ordered that day...were salty beyond the "salty norms". Hey, you guys are using dead sea salt huh?/skip-beyond-skipYelp 100: 54/100/My-last-3-weeks-in-SG

Best Korean Food I have had in Singapore. Note that it's only hotplates and soups. I always get the Kimchi Ramien Soup that comes with dumplings in the soup. My fiancée always gets the Tom Yum soup and she says it's so yummy. I've been to a few Korean restaurants and the is all over priced and not nearly as yummy as the Korean stall at this Foodcourt. Plus, the meal is only $5 and the drinks are around $2.

address: 1001 Yishun Industrial Park A #01-1001 Yishun Industrial Park A Food Centre Singapore 768743 Singapore
comment: Important. Quite a number of parallel parking lots just outside of the canteen. Seems a lot of people come for the Thai food, Taste of Thailand and there are good verbal reviews from friends alike. Apart from the Thai food, there are a good fair share of local food stores like noodles, vegetarian and Indian Muslim food. Though it is right in the industrial park, the crowd here is still bearable and not unusally overcrowded during the lunch hour that I visited. The canteen is pretty airy too and that much I pretty love as I am afraid of the heat! I literally am a polar bear. Will come back and try the Thai food and give another review soon.

address: 930 Yishun Avenue 2 #B1-191 South Wing Singapore 769098 Singapore
comment: Although the outlet had opened for quite sometimes, I had not ate here until today. Ordering was taken through self service machines in front of the counter with payments through cash or cards. However I did not see the Fraser orange color machine and thought that there was no points for Fraser member (which was not true when I checked online in northpoint website). Wait for the order number to be flashed on the screen before collecting at the counter. Do take note that number may not be appear in sequence. One could not help but saw that the pair of orders before me was taken in mistake with the noodles eaten before realising the mistake.Help yourself to the drink dispenser machine but do take note no refill.Help yourself to the various sauces such as BBQ mayo, bibimbab, wasabi, teriyaki, Korean cho gochujang at the counter. Bird's Nest (S$10)Slightly poke that runny onsen egg to let it ooze and enjoy the creaminess of the yolk by mixing it with springy Korean glass noodles and well marinated spicy chicken.Topup S$5 with a side of Fried Dumpling and a drink.A bit upset that the onsen egg was already broken when served. The noodles was not bad but a bit too mushy.Grainy Salmon (S$10)Brighten up your day with the right kind of food and right kind of colors!Enjoy juicy pan-fried salmon topped on multigrain rice with onsen egg.Mix the tobikko thoroughly for that extra crunchiness. Topup S$5 with a side of Chicken Karaage and a drink.The rice was soft and smooth, with sweet corn in it. Wish the salmon was served slightly undercooked.

address: 369 Sembawang Road, #01-05 Sembawang Cottage Singapore 758382 Singapore
comment: I like the casual and airy design of the interior of this place, with cement floors and various neon colored placements. The white furniture gives this place a rather chic and cute look.We found the service here to be very prompt, possibly because we were one of the few customers there at the point in time. We ordered quite a few things to share, such as prawn cakes, curry sauce soft shell crabs, stuffed chicken wings and green mango salad. We found that the prawn cakes looked quite cute and tasted quite good as well. The stuffed chicken wings were satisfyingly large as well, but we thought that the fillings were somewhat too dry.For our mains, we had pineapple rice, seafood glass noodles, seafood pad thai. The seafood pad thai was good! The noodles were of the right texture and the overall taste of the dish was excellent. We also liked the green curry because it was rich and flavorful, yet not too spicy.Finally, we had the mango sticky rice for dessert; I'm not usually a dessert guy but I liked the mango sticky rice for its sweetness. Overall, a good place to have some nice Thai food.

The outlet at the shopping centre has recently gone through an upgrading. It has reopened with a cafe style look. Besides the usual menu, it also offers cakes and drinks, similar to McCafe from McDonald's. There is also self ordering machine available. Another order option is through mobile application and collect at counter to bypass the queue, which is quite new.Anyway there was no queue, so I just went by the traditional way ordering at the counter. Decided to try the new Parmesan Chicken by ordering its $7.90 combo set meal. It came with 2 pieces of Parmesan Chicken (1 wing and 1 thigh), 1 regular whipped potato and 1 SJORA Mango Peach. The outlet ran out of whipped potato, so it was replaced with coleslaw. The mango peach was quite watered down in taste. The Parmesan Chicken was quite crispy outside with a hint of spicy taste, while juicy inside. The yellowish sauce looked quite cheesy but really had the truffle taste in it, although could not smell any of it.Overall felt that it better than the usual fried chicken being not so oily and more crispy too.

Visited to try out as their menu looks good. I ordered their customized bento set to try which cost me $10.90 in total.Select one type of riceAdd One Main*Additional 1.00 for premium mainsChoose two types of vegetables All Bento comes with a bowl of soup. Overall, their food are not bad. Quite tasty and their service was good. Will definitely go back for more

address: 925 Yishun Central 1 #01-249, Yishun 81 Food Court Singapore 760925 Singapore
comment: One of the most well known chicken rice stalls in Yishun. It has been around for more than 20 years. It opens from lunch time (around 10.30am) and closes at 8pm or earlier when the chickens finish. The chicken is deboned before serving with the rice and achar (pickles). One also can add chicken feet, chicken liver and chicken kidney. The stall also used to offer rojak but to the overwhelming business, it was then stopped. Business was so good that it was expanded to another outlet in a coffee shop in Ang Mo Kio Central.

address: 3 Northpoint Dr #01-03 Yishun Town Square Singapore 768019 Singapore
comment: Burger King @ Yishun Town Square.Doable location on a smaller scale as compared to some of the BK I am used to.  At least when the last time I visit this location, it is quiet.  I guessed it all depends on the timing.  I know during the weekends this Burger King tends to be very busy or when the Yishun Town Square aka Event Hall runs a road show or an event comes about.This recent visit was when I opt for the Fanta Grape Float.  I forgot to ask the staff for less ice in my order of beverage.  My favorite snack or item is no longer available, maybe I can request the management to have this "elusive" item as their regular item.So as usual BK has those limited items to choose from.  Oh well...  May return to this location when needed.
Simply love the chef recommendation dry noodles with anchovies, bean sprouts and pickled mustard leaves.

rest_name: Big Fish Small Fish Northpoint City
comment: Time : 1830hrs ish.Big Fish Small Fish Northpoint City...My Bestie, she wants to have another round of Big Fish Small Fish as for her Dinner and since she does not want to travel far from her house and just came from work, hence to this location we went.YES you order at the counter, made your payment and the staff will show you where to be seated.  This location looks "bigger" than the Bugis Junction location aka have more seating areas.YES, another establishment in a MALL.  Another establishment that is situated at one corner of a passage way aka Mall, NOT a brick and mortar establishment.Since its the PEAK HOUR of Dinner, man.. once again another establishment packed to the brim!  THANK GOD when we arrived, we managed to get seats right away.  But it seems that they cramped so many chairs and tables as I have observed so many establishments are doing so lately.Big Fish Small Fish Northpoint City location, I want to like you, but for now you have 3 stars in my books coz, once again, another establishment that run out of food or items I want to order.Secondly, the sauces they offer differs from the Bugis Location.  While waiting for our food to be ready. One of the staffs, gave us complimentary crisps, or chips which are thinly shaved but comes out COLD.Standard, from both locations, I have experienced.  BOTH locations give Crisps that are COLD.  Thank GOD for the HOT items for the fish/seafood..This time around I opt for the Seared Dory with Rice ($8.80) with 1 order of 20oz Orange Minute Maid ($3.20).  My order of Seared Dory DOES NOT look seared at all.  Comes with Pilaf or Rice that is NOT cooked properly and steamed vegetables that looks so sad.  The steamed vegetables included were, asparagus, carrots and broccoli.  Standard items of Western vegetables.  Flavor of food was pretty bland.  Okay Big Fish Small Fish..  this time around you receive 3 stars in my books.  At least my friend is happy with her order of FRIED DORY..  aka  HOT Battered Fried Fish from the Fryer.Else you received like 2 stars, in my personal opinion.  3 stars also coz you are another Halal Certified establishment in town.  May return to this location, to make sure they have what the Bugis Location has to offer then perhaps my review might differ.Big Fish Small Fish Northpoint Location opens DAILY from 11:00hrs to 22:00hrs.  Last order is at 21:30hrs.  Hence plan accordingly.Q : 1124Check : 68453Order : 69005Big Fish Small Fish Northpoint City1 NorthPoint DriveSouth Wing of NorthPoint City#02-132/133Singapore 768019

rest_name: SMA - Super Makan Asia @ Northpoint City
address: 1 Northpoint Drive #B1-112, Northpoint City South Wing Singapore 769098 Singapore
comment: Fuss free local delights. I liked their seafood white noodles! Loads of Lala and very flavorful. Prices are nett so no GST or service charge. The staff are friendly, they serve teh and kopi here!! They also have a small western menu. The rendang here is tender and juicy, worth the $8!!
I've been wanting to try the steamed kaya toast for a while and I finally had a chance to on this most recent visit to Ya Kun.  Definitely worth the wait.

Ya Kun is a chain in Singapore well known for its kaya butter toasts. It has a outlet at Northpoint Shopping Centre which is near where I am staying. During mornings, the place is packed with people having a quick bite before going to work. The table turnover is quite fast.One orders and pays at the cashier. Remember to collect the number tag too. Although given number tag, one still have to wait at the counter for drink and half boiled eggs. Only the toasts will be served to you at your table.Value Set A ($4.80) - Kaya Toast with Butter SetThe set consists of 2 pieces of crispy toasts with kaya and butter spread on, 2 half boiled eggs and a choice of coffee or tea. It is one of the most popular sets commonly ordered by most. The toast although crispy and light, but tastewise still a far cry from how the founder used to make.Overall food is not bad and served quite fast. I would prefer that the staff would give the table a quick wipe as it is quite sticky.
Very slow service, disorganized even when the restaurant is filled with only 5 occupied tables

The restaurant was newly opened. Menu was limited, just a single page. No frills place. Pay for order at counter. Collect order at the back of counter when buzzer rings.Signature Beef La Mian 招牌牛肉拉面 (S$8.65/ small)Something soupy to keep warm during the rainy day. Selected mild spicy version. Very tender meat.Selected Leek Leaves version for noodles. Can't taste the leek in the noodles but it was quite soft and thin. There was 4 other choices for noodles.Topped S$3.65 to make it a meal with a choice of side and drink which selected Tofu Salad 豆腐丝 and Sour Plum Drink 秘制酸梅汤 .

address: 30 Sembawang Dr #01-02, Sun Plaza Singapore 757713 Singapore
comment: Generally quiet area with a good ambience. Coffee and tea average, as with most toast box outlets. Most would flock to the ya kun downstairs for better quality food and drinks, but I personally love the cafe-like ambience here :) it's a bread talk connected to a toast box, rather spacious and even has a small stairway by the door, giving a rather cute vintage feel :) generally a great place to chill!

The restaurant was recently opened. The dine in area was quite open. Proceed to the cashier to pay for your order with the order list. Remember to give the cashier your table number. Only cash and NETS was accepted here. Help yourself to the free flow of soup, condiments and cutlery at the side counter. The food arrived quite fast even before I reached the table with the soup.Beef Rendang ($7.50)Voted the number one dish of 'World's 50 Most Delicious Foods (Readers' Pick)' list in 2011, beef rendang is cooked for hours with rich spices for perfect taste and tenderness.Flavourful but would prefer it to be more tender. It was a dry for some pieces. Plain rice was not included and came at $0.90 per plate.Iced Chendol ($3.50)It came topped with jackfruit. The shaved ice was rough. The dessert was not too sweet and green jelly strips was not frozen hard.

address: 8A Admiralty St #06-07, Food Xchange @ Admiralty Singapore 757437 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: It has been a great disappointment with Ronnie kitchens where food arrived so late at 1215pm and today at 1245pm. The food is supposed to be consumed by 1pm on the sticker and if it arrives only at 1245pm, how can we expect the quality and hygiene level. Also for lunch to be arriving so late, this has led to me have a rush lunch as we have work schedule to follow esp in the teaching line. Sometimes in a rush, I have to throw most of the food away as I just simply have no time to eat. I hope that better lunch delivery time is meet and if not, I will never order from this caterer again

address: 1 Woodlands Square #B1-16, Causeway Point Singapore 738099 Singapore
comment: I went to The Chicken Rice Shop to celebrate my birthday with family last year. The outlet was new and had an opening promotion that we couldn't resist. A meal for four at just $39.90! It included rice, two types of chicken dishes, vegetables, pie tee, drinks and bubor chacha for dessert. In we went and though it was a busy day, the staff and food didn't disappoint.The cafe was full, so understandably , we had to wait a while for the chefs to prepare our order. We shared two plates of butter and roasted chicken with our rice and veggies among the four of us. The chicken was tender and juicy and the rice cooked just right. That itself was already filling. Then the pie tee came. They're like popiah served in fried dough cups. For some reason, they weren't as good as the ones we had at their branch in Vivocity. The veggies were soggy and weren't fresh. The bubor chacha hit the right level of sweetness and included plenty of yam and sweet potato chunks. It filled our bellies well enough. Though the standard of the pie tees has fallen, we were satisfied with the meal and will be back on other promotions!

A place to splurge if you have extra money to spend on nothing special-though credit has to be given for its handmade noodles and clean-tasting (read: bland) dishes. The "legendary" rainbow ramen was nothing to shout about, save for how empty it was (it was the most expensive but came with no dishes/meat). I finished the bowl of noodles feeling clean/healthy (since there was not much flavour) even when drizzled with the starchy (tasteless) sauce it was served with. The signature minced pork ramen tasted ordinary, it's minced pork reminding us of the canned minced pork in chilli oil one would eat with porridge at home. Didn't try the medium spicy noodles but they were not spicy at all according to my eating partner. The xiao long baos were also nothing to shout about. The only difference between their original xlbs and the ones with scallop were the few strips of dried scallop in the scallop xlb. If you have to eat here and crave xlbs, just stick with the original. Overall, a rather ordinary (home cooked feeling) meal which did not justify the amount spent here. More could be done to differentiate their dishes from what could be done at home and attract a better crowd.Would give it 2.5 stars at best

This KFC is at the Zoo's kidzworld. Although there are ample seating, there is usually no space available even on non-peak period. The tables are occupied by parents waiting for their kids playing at the water play facilities right in front of the restaurant. It might be better to walk outside to the other KFC at the zoo entrance if you are looking for food.

The restaurant was renamed UmiTeishoku, with menu similar to the latter. One was surprised that the restaurant was quite empty during sunday dinner time.Hot Udon & Mini Oyako Don Set ($12.50++)Japanese thick wheat noodles in dashi broth and mini chicken and rice bowl The set was accompanied with chawanmushi (steamed egg), seaweed pickles, and sliced orange.One was surprised that there was mayonnaise on top of oyako don. The egg was cooked too well and separated from the meat, none of the gooey texture which one was expecting. The dish fell down the expectation of an oyako don. The udon was served in a fish based broth, topped with some pieces of fishcake. Simple and warming.Tori Katsu Bento ($11.50++)Crispy chicken cutlet, served with Japanese rice, salmon sashimi slices (2pcs), miso soup, todu & seaweed picklesThe chicken cutlet was light and crispy. The cold tofu was served with sesame dressing and mayonnaise on top.Bara Chirashi Don ($13.50++)Assorted fresh sashimi chunks on Japanese riceThe set came with miso soup, chawanmushi & seaweed picklesThe assorted sashimi was served not marinated with sauce by the side, although I felt it was a tab bland for me after pouring in the whole cup. Needed to add a tab more of soyu. Wished that there was more seafood.Japanese Ebikko Eel Roll ($9.80++)Not bad although would wish that the sauce on top was more.

The restaurant was recently opened in the new wing of the shopping mall. I was attracted by its 1-for-1 pizza promotion but was told that the promotion was not available after sitting down as the promotion was not available during holiday. Water was not served.Soup of the day ($3.30)Served with garlic bread. It was broccoli soup. Light but flavourful.Caesar Salad ($6.80)Romaine, lettuce, egg, crotons, caesar dressingIt was light and crisp, dusted with parmesan powder on top.Salted Egg Prawn Pasta ($14.90)Linguine in salted egg yolk sauce, served with succulent prawns.The sauce was rich and creamy with curry leaves in it. It was also slightly spicy as there was chilli padi in it. The prawns were chunky and juicy.Vegetarian Aglio Olio ($8.30)Spaghetti with Thai asparagus, capsicum & button mushroom tossed in glaric & olive oilRequested to serve it without chilli padi. The dish was delicious and garlicky.Kids meal of Chicken Nugget ($5.50)It was served with complimentary orange juice and ice-cream.The meal consisted of 4 pieces of nuggets, with french fries and baked bean. It was well liked by the little one.Dark Chocolate Hazelnut Waffle ($9.90)Chocolate + Hazelnut ice cream, topped with crushed Kit Kat & chocolate sauceInstead of chocolate ice cream, it was served with vanilla ice cream, which the staff later served us an additional scoop of chocolate ice cream when we asked about it. Avocado Milkshake ($6.80)Refreshing blend of fresh avocado with vanilla ice cream and gula melakaThe drink came highly recommended by the staff. Felt the fruit taste was not distinct. It was more on the milky side.

It was one of the new restaurants in the Makan Town of the new wing of the mall.Banh Xeo (S$11.50++)Vietnamese Pancake with Minced Meat and Seafood Barely can tasted the seafood in it. Mostly tofu, bean sprouts and minced meat.Bun Cha Gio Ga Nuong (S$10.80++)Fresh Noodle with Grilled Lemongrass Chicken and Fried Spring RollsIt looked not bad but there was no fried spring rolls when served, which one did not realise after eating. Pho Xao (S$10.80++)Fried Pho Noodle (seafood)Felt like zhi char noodle. Slightly more salty than preferred.Xoi Che Voi Xoai (S$4.80++)Mango with Glutinuous RiceThe mango was more on the sour side. The rice was soft and moist.Accompanied with Soda Chanh (S$3.50++)Soda, Lime & Sugar Syrupwhich just tasted like plain soda water.

This vendor offer lots of fried food aka street food such as Vadai, Pakoras, Indian Masala Chicken Parts such as Liver/Gizzard Chicken or Chicken wings to name a few.  But they specialize more of the Vadai variety aka in Malay its called as Wadeh.  YES, when its HOT from the Fryer its good to eat, though I cannot deny its a little smaller aka smaller portion than I am used to etc.  I got to know this vendor during the Ramadan Bazaar month May/June 2018 @ Geylang Serai and now they are back for the Deepavali Bazaar or Diwali @ Woodlands MRT thru their social media platform.  They also take orders items such as Murukku, a savoury crunchy snacks. All in all, their Vadai or Wadeh that we have tried, ate or order was just OK.  I will stick my Vadai AKA Wadeh cravings at Tekka Market instead.  Oh well at least I have tried their Vadai from this vendor.

The restaurant was opened recently in Northpoint. Although there was a number of promotion available, the restaurant was not packed even during peak meal hours. So the five of us came for late dinner, we had our choice of table with circular seat. Do take note that wet tissue, braised peanut, crispy fish skin, you tiao were chargeable. Dried Scallop Porridge with Century Egg, Minced Meat & Cuttlefish 干贝皮蛋鱿鱼肉碎粥 (S$11.90++)The serving looked much smaller than the picture in the menu, and there not much liao in it. The porridge was very fine and well flavoured.Claypot Frog's Meat with Scallion Ginger Sauce 瓦煲姜葱田鸡 (S$18.90++)It looked like barely 1 frog in this dish and there was barely any meat with mostly bones. Quite disappointing.Premium Porridge 极品泡饭 (S$16.90++)Clam, Sea Cucumber & Fish MawLike Teochew porridge, it was soup over rice here. Similar to other dishes there was not as much liao as showed on menu. It was light in taste with lots of vegetables such as carrot, and tomatoes.Deep Fried Homemade Prawn Balls 手工虾枣 (S$14.90++)Not too bad, although one would prefer more crunchy texture. It would be better to have it served with sweet flour sauce instead of sweet dark sauce.Stir-fried Scallops and Royal Chives 带子青龙菜  (S$19.90++)A bit too overcooked making the vegetables lacking of crunchiness.

Went there at 1.40pm and the crowd is over. Overall, terrible service. They don't explained that you have to do the ordering yourself, on the given paper. When I was done with write down my order, I got to hunt the server down to give them your order. The server prioritized cleaning up the table over whether the customer is ready to order. I attribute this to poor management training. The server should keep an eye on the customers that that arrived and are ready to order while going about their other lower priority tasks. The only other time I see the server is when they bring the food. If I have a choice, I would not give the 10% service charge as I don't see services at all, other than they obligation.

This stall is actually a franchise that's little well known on Yelp. They have 5-6 stalls in Singapore, mainly in s-11 hawker centres in the heartlands such as Ang Mo Kio and Yishun. They also have stalls in Orchard road, after hearing it from one of the stall helpers. In this stall, you will immediately notice the loud commanding voice of the helper taking orders. It's stern and firm but he's quite nice la. There may be a stream of customers but the helper is ready to bring the food to you. To the main highlight. As usual, I will taste the drumstick rice first. This stall's drumstick is tender and softer than most hawker stalls already and the rice is fragrant too. Once I add the chilli and dark sauce to the rice, the 'burst' is definitely there! What makes this stall stand out? It's the peanut chicken soup or some other soup of the day that comes with your chicken rice! The soup is tasty and filled with ingredients, unlike most stalls which serves plain soup. Being set in a super convenient location, just a minute's walk from Khatib MRT, with a good flavorful soup as a chicken rice proposition, yay I'm a fan!

The outlet was the first vegetarian outlet for Dough Culture. On top of its usual fried dough fritter, and other deep fried snack, it also offers rojak, porridge and laksa.Vegetarian Laksa (S$3.80)The broth was packed separately from the rice vermicelli, mock prawn, mock fish cake, and straw mushroom. The broth was topped with finely chopped laksa leaves and dried beancurd puffs. The usual laksa flavour was fainter than preferred and it was way too creamy. One would wish for more vegetables instead mock meat.Tau Suan (S$2) The dessert was made of mung beans. Slightly more watery than perferred. Could be due to the fact it was on the counter for quite sometime. It was served with crispy you tiao (deep fried dough fritter), which was packed separately to maintain its crispiness.

address: 33 Allanbrooke Rd Sentosa Leisure Group Singapore 099981 Singapore
comment: This place made my beach day even better.  The ambience and the views of the ocean was the topping on a already great day in Sentosa.  It's the cutest place I ever seen.   I could sit here for hours ordering every item on the menu.  The staff is so welcoming! I order the Crab Meat with spaghetti!  I'm still raving about my dish.  The helping was huge with more than enough crab meat.  Every bite was better then the next bite.  I'm a pasta girl, I know good pasta.  I order a side order of onion rings.  I enjoyed the crisp on the outside.  Of course, my husband order the Avocado Salad with the Singapore Sling.  He was very pleased with his meal.  He cleaned his bowl too!  I can testify the Singapore Sling was good too.

address: 33 Allanbrooke Rd Sentosa Leisure Group Singapore 099981 Singapore
comment: I don't know how you can mess up a salad, but apparently it's possible. The chicken was super greasy so the oil and dripping everywhere so that might as well be the dressing, and I've never seen tomatoes in a ceasar salad before. All the food was terrible and overpriced. My drink was pretty, but it wasn't good, but hey, it looks good to take a photo off. We only decided to eat here because you need to be a customer to use the lawn chairs and there were no where to sit on the beach. Wish we would have been to the other side to the beach first, there's plenty of other options to eat there and it's way prettier. There's a time limit for how much time you can relax on the lawn chair and there's a minimum of how much you need to spend on your ticket to sit.Tell me about your experience if you've been here or is going to after reading this review:)

address: 33 Allanbrooke Rd Sentosa Leisure Group Singapore 099981 Singapore
comment: Got here quarter to 7pm on a Friday. We were seated rudely by someone, who told us to sit anywhere. When we asked her for the wifi she barked she will give it to us. Super rude. Came and said kitchen is closing in 10 if you want food. No smile, nothing the whole time. Calamari was rock hard. Mee goreng had too much chilli sauce. There were ants all over the place and flies. Drinks are too weak...costs an extra $12 to make them into doubles. They also had no strawberry flavour for their frozen drinks so it ruled out half the drinks I wanted on the menu. Nice view and chill vibes. Food and drinks came fast too.

address: 33 Allanbrooke Rd Sentosa Leisure Group Singapore 099981 Singapore
comment: I decided chilling here after soaking up all the vitamin D rays my skin could tolerate at Sentosa Island Beach but, I think I kinda overdid the sunning just a tad too much-I look like mahogany furniture!  So, let's go sit in the shade; enough sun for today . . . (Rubbing my hands together watching people gulping those tasty cocktails-WAP~Down the hatch ever so quickly!) Now, let's get some tasty libations drinking myself silly!At Raffles, they had the audacity charging about  $25.00 U.S. Dollars for ONE Singapore Sling-I'm not spending THAT much money on a small drink so, for the same $25.00, I bought at least-if I remember correctly (I had quite a few drinks so, I totally zoned out unable remembering how many drinks I consumed-HAH!) BUT, it must have been at least-Uh~I think three, maybe it was five well-drinks?  Geez-My memory escapes me~HAH!Anyway, feeling higher than a kite flying in the clouds . . .I was floating into la-la-land, finally realizing I must ride the Metro returning to 98 SG . . . TOTALLY SOUSED!  Ooops!  You know, I don't remember how I returned to 98 SG . . . BUT, the next day, I woke up believe it or not . . . NO HANGOVER=20-Million STARS to the awesome bartender who made my well-drinks!!!  **\(^ ___ ^)/**~Weeeeeee-----Cheers!

address: 33 Allanbrooke Rd Sentosa Leisure Group Singapore 099981 Singapore
comment: Free WiFi, great drinks, friendly staff, beach chairs - nice place to relax in a Sunday afternoon

address: 33 Allanbrooke Rd Sentosa Leisure Group Singapore 099981 Singapore
comment: After a long day in the sun at Sentosa, we ended up at this bar close to the southernmost point in Continental Asia. It should have been a more enjoyable experience than it was but unfortunately we will be unlikely to return. We ordered some beer and some cocktails to sit back and watch the sunset. The bar was not very busy. Most of the beers on the menu were not available at that time. The cocktails were OK but pricy. The pool table was $10 to play for 1 hour although there was only blackboard chalk for the cues. Our last game on the pool table went over the hour. Despite the fact that there was no one else waiting to play the staff wasted no time in letting us know that the game had to finish. Then they repeated this a couple of minutes later. Yes, I know it was $10 for one hour, but was it really good customer service to kick your customers off the table when there was no one else waiting to play. We only wanted to finish the game that we started. Keep your stock of drinks in line with the menu, learn to improve the level of customer service and you have the makings of a great bar in a great location.

address: 33 Allanbrooke Rd Sentosa Leisure Group Singapore 099981 Singapore
comment: Great location, friendly service, and reasonable drink prices, but the food is horrible. Remember the stuff you would throw in the microwave from the freezer to eat as a teenager? Yes, that's pretty much what they serve here. Almost forgot, the Pina Colada was wretched as well. Recommend coming for beers only.

address: 33 Allanbrooke Rd Sentosa Leisure Group Singapore 099981 Singapore
comment: Had the ceasar salad and nachos, never were very good and both were overpriced. You're paying to just have a place to sit on the beach. I would recommend trying somewhere to eat on the other side of the beach instead.

address: 60 Siloso Beach Walk Southern Islands 098997 Singapore
comment: Chicken was decent as three different sauces were available.  The rice had the requisite flavoring while the vegetables were small in quantity.  The soup was okay.

Attended Chef Ian Kittichai X Chef Thitid Tassanakajohn of Le Du from Bangkok, Thailand , 4 Hands CollaborationAt Tangerine @ Espa In Resorts World Sentosa in Resorts World Sentosa from 11 April 2019, 7pmChapter IISavour's 100Gourmet April Edition6 Course Dinner (S$180++/ public, S$110++/ Singtel & Maybank customers)Although we arrived early, there was a hiccup as the staff could not my reservation. But soon we were showed to a table.Spring onion & coriander breadThe bread was served top of a flower pot with pesto sauce in it. The bread was buttery soft.Seared ScallopChef Ian KittichaiTangerine's garden herbs, cashew nut milk-pepper dressingInspired by the herbs grown in Tangerine's garden with a lightly seared diver scallop, house-made Thai cashew nut milk and a touch of Thai chiliServed in a shell, decorated with colorful flowers, it was simply to pretty to be eaten. The scallop was so juicy.Cured FlukeAvocado, green mango & gingerChef Thitid TassanakajohnThis dish is inspired by the Thai people's favourite green sauce , affectionately called "nam jim seafood ". However, he wanted to do it differently, in a modern and artisanal way incorporating avocado, a fruit many people don't know can grow in large quantities back in Thailand. The flavour is rich and intense but not overpowering the delicate fluke.First time having cured fish in thai style. The cured fish looked more sashimi then cured.Sustainable Sea Bass SoupChef Ian KittichaiTurmeric, Coconut - galangal brothAs humble as it sounds, this dish incorporates delicious local sustainable sea bass with local herbs in a Southern Thai-style dish.Milky soup which was more on the sour side. Interesting serving it from a teapot packed with lemongrass.Lobster in Signature Southern Style CurryChef Thitid TassanakajohSmoked pumpkin & signature Chu-Chee curryPaying homage to his favourite Southern Thai curry! It is traditionally a very spicy dish. He gave it his own twist with smoked pumpkin puree added for an additional layer of flavour and to balance out the heat of the curry.The sweetness from the pumpkin and the spiciness of the curry striked a balance in between."Hunglay" Iberico PorkChef Ian KittichaiTamarind, pickled garlicThis dish is an interpretation of Chef's love affair with the classic Northern Thai curryCooked 3 hours. The sauce was spicy but grew with a lingering aftertaste.Served with eggplant , pumpkin purée and pickled ginger. The curry was very rich. Yummy with just rice. The meat was flavourful although would prefer it to be more tender.Mango Panna CottaChef Thitid TassanakajohnSmoked coconut ice creamWhen speaking about Thai food, who can leave out the popular Thai dessert, Mango Sticky rice! This dessert follows a similar concept, but without the sticky rice. A lighter version, but still possessing the essence of the perennial favourite in every bite.Interestingly the crispy rice provided a kind of savoury kick to the sweet and slightly tart mango  pudding. The smoky ice cream was quite unique in taste. Overall the food was totally different from the usual Thai food. Only that the serving portion was kind of small. The first 3 dishes were served pretty fast and smooth but the wait for the last 3 dishes were quite long. Maybe it was the first night and the kitchen staffs were not familiar with the place.

I have read many reviews about Chef Forest's Sous Vide Salmon Fillet with Red Capsicum Coulis and Tamarind Sauce, and many of them did rave about this particular dish. However, I was sorely disappointed by it - the salmon fillet lacked any punch in its taste. While admittedly it does look fresh, the sous vide method of cooking it (according to my waitress, Yuko, they boil it at 40 degrees Celsius) means that it may be neither warm nor cold. Perhaps the sauce was used to give the salmon some form of flavour - but alas, this was done unsatisfactorily and left my friend and I wanting. Mind you, this dish isn't cheap - it costs S$22.For more, see my blog entry at travellah.wordpress.com/….

address: 1 Larkhill Road Amara Sanctuary Resort Sentosa Singapore 099394 Singapore
comment: Decided to be a smart-ass and turned up at the restaurant without making a reservation only to be let down gently by the head waiter who apologetically told us they were fully booked for the evening. In between my dismayed sputtering, he decided to take pity on me and said he would give me a call if a table let up.And it (thankfully) did. Had a fantastic meal consisting of tasty fish cakes, crispy fish doused in spicy Thai sauce, alarmingly spicy Tom Yum Goong and rich green curry - all well-accompanied by fluffy jasmine rice. The only qualm I had with the food was that it was not quite warm enough. Food that isn't of the right temperature always makes me unfoundedly suspicious.Service definitely also deserves a mention - the staff were extremely attentive and took us very seriously when we asked for suggestions on our choice of dishes. They gave great recommendations based on just a couple of preferences highlighted.Will definitely be turning up at their door again - with a reservation made this time.

I have been nostalgic of the NY style bagels that I feel in love with. Just plain good old bagel with a cream cheese spread. And Schmears delivered on all points! When I first bite into my toasted bagel, I was home in NYC again. Love the chilled out vibe in this place and also love that the owners hail from NY, so they defo knew their stuff! Highly recommend!

address: 31 Ocean Way #01-09  Sentosa Cove Southern Islands 098375 Singapore
comment: Best coffee in Sentosa . I'm sure there are people who prefer their Kopi-O's and hawker Center hot drinks, but as far as frothy milk coffees go, this places smashes them. If you're in Sentosa Cove regularly It's totally worth getting one of the pay in advance loyalty cards, which they have various versions of depending on your tipple of choice.

address: 31 Ocean Way #01-09  Sentosa Cove Southern Islands 098375 Singapore
comment: This branch of Joe the Juice is absolutely shocking. Their equipment is constantly broken, which means you either get sour milk or no coffee at all. The staff here also open and close the store when it suits them. This morning, an hour late. Whoever owns this franchise needs to wake up.

address: 31 Ocean Way #01-09  Sentosa Cove Southern Islands 098375 Singapore
comment: A relaxing place to rest and enjoy the atmosphere at Quayside Isle. They have a selection of juices (think Boost Juice), coffee and sandwiches. Definitely coming back next time I'm in thr neighborhood.

I went a few months ago and only remember to write this review now as a friend was asking me about this place. The local food was surprisingly good. Huge portions and priced around $10+. The laksa was highly recommended by my host (who was the member and boat owner in our group). I tried some and it was very rich and lemak! Some of our party had the champagne buffet..I must say it's the most affordable champagne buffet at 78+ (add another + if you're not a member as you have to pay 10% service charge). I had a taste of the gazpacho and loved it. My friends seemed to enjoy the seafood and desserts. The menu is western fusion, some touches of asian but not overtly so. And the buffet champers served freeflow was...Piper Heidsieck, so it was a reliable brand. Reliable and way better than cheap stuff. Generous when you factor in the price.I had a healthy fish bee hoon (huge portion), it was ok with clams. My friend let me try her fried kway teow with a raw egg yolk (I think it's called moon river?) and it was yummy.Another nice thing is they still allow ordering from the ala carte menu. In fact they let us order from the full ala carte menu (we were a big group of 15 or so) and not the shortlist that they had separately for Sunday. So you know how sometimes you have some in the group who insists to go for champagne brunch but you are not keen on eating a log and a house or want to save some money..you will do ok here.There was one difficulty, there was a live band playing on Sunday. It's not that they were bad but they played a mix of some old music at a very loud volume and it was really spoiling the relaxing summertime sunday mood rather than helping to create the chillax mood. So I suggest if the band is on, sit outside by the water. It will mean you have to walk further to the buffet line but that's a good thing. I love dining by the water so I give this 4 stars (although I couldn't that day as it was raining quite heavily).I asked and the staff was very certain when she said you can get a member friend to book for you and the member friend doesn't have to be present when you eat or pay. I haven't taken advantage of this yet but I think it's doable as I realise I know 3 members just off the cuff already. Plus...I have the Islander Pass. Otherwise entrance to the island is $7 per car on Sundays and $6 per cab!

This restaurant gone from bad to worse. Servers are most unfriendly. Have no ideas about serving. Prefer to argue with customers rather than pleasing the customer. Such a pity. The food is boring. Same buffet everyday !

address: Serangoon Nex Shopping Centre # B1-73 Singapore Singapore
comment: Simply love the porridge here, especially the minced meat porridge! The taste is subtle yet without the addition of seasonings as you can really taste the flavours of the pork, Ikan billis etc. I would say that it is not cheap dining here, hence the 4*, but I'd rather favour quality over quantity. Verdict:- Porridge (fish and minced meat on two occasions) : Porridge is not just for when one is ill but can be a light meal any time of the day. Love the subtle taste of each ingredients and the subtle taste of sliced ginger. - Chinese cabbage with milk broth : Very well done cabbage; blanched without losing its crunchiness and coupled with the broth mixed with salted egg, it is simply divine!- Tofu : They offer a variety of tofu with different toppings. Try anyone. They are just as good!Tip: Good to go early to beat the dinner crowd which starts trickling in at around 6pm.

Interesting menu for coffee shop fare, but seriously let down by lack lustre food. Order a Cajun chicken burger, this was bun, lots of raw onion, slice of processed cheese, half a chicken thigh, BBQ sauce and another bun. No Cajun anywhere to be found only an overpowering taste of raw onions. Of course it came with dry and cold fries without seasoning. Totally unappetising. My son ordered a Mac and cheese which came as cold macaroni in a brown sauce.This place doesn't even meet the standard coffee shop food.... stick with the many other local food for offer on this coffee shop.

How to give anything less then 5 stars? Very thankful to have this outlet so near my house, each time I want to have a vegetarian meal.I've been eating vegetarian meals at home and outside for a week since I've been back from Europe (no, not because I'm sick of meat, or anything weird!), but more because my mindset has changed due to conversations with some people and seeing things from a healthier perspective.I've visited this outlet 4 times in a week and each time I've ordered something different.Here's what I ordered:- Laksa - The soup is da bomb! Laksa is generally a vegetarian dish as there is no meat in there and what makes the dish is the flavourful and creamy soup! Add Greendot's famous sambal in, and the soup has a fantastic OOMPH flavour! This is always a favourite!- Herbal Noodle Soup - This is also another favourite of mine as the soup has an insanely good herbal taste with lots of goji berries floating (depending on which outlet you visit). If you want something extra nourishing and healthy but also want some soup noodle-y thing, try this!- Soya Noodles - This is my first time trying it only because I overheard the couple in front raving about it between themselves. I'm always a fan of soup noodles, however, this is a dry noodle dish. There is a big bowl of soup that comes with it though. What I love about this dish are the crunchy carrot/cucumber strips that blend in so well with every mouthful of flavourful noodles! Ask for more sauce for the noodles, if you like your noodle wetter.- The black pepper franks - I presume is a substitute for sausages but it is actually tofu made to look like a sausage. Eating it on its own is abit bland but dip it in a mix of chilli and tomato sauce (given by the waitress and a small dish to pour it in) is heavenly.What's more, each time I visit, I notice that the wait staff are always very cheerful and crack jokes with regulars and newbies alike, making the whole dining atmosphere very pleasant. Also noticed that they are mostly seniors, save for the cashier? Hmmmm.TIP:  The cashier won't actively ask you if you have their membership but they do! Go to Greendot's website to sign up and collect points by providing your number before you pay. Worth it if you eat here regularly or are a vegetarian.

there's always a friendly host to welcome you at the entrance of this joint.i decided to give its angelica herbal noodle set at $6.90 (lunch promotion) a try since i had never eaten here before. to my delight i was presented with a bowl of lovely greens on one side and some interesting looking assorted meat balls on the other side. maybe because I didn't know what to expect so i was quite delighted by the chewy noodles in the soup and the refreshing herbal broth. i did go back a 2nd time but i do have to say that the experience wasn't as great as the first.the standard wasn't consistent and in my 2nd bowl, there weren't as much greens and the noodles weren't as chewy. perhaps the chef had his day off...none the less, a nice place to visit for something "healthy" even when you're in a hurry.

This Chinese restaurant serves a great boneless steam chicken dish called Samsui Chicken. The chicken is eaten together with a splash of ground ginger  all wrapped in a leave of lettuce.The restaurant theme makes you feel like eating in a courtyard with Chinese styled pavilion. Service is quick. Orders were taken quickly and the food came in within 15 minutes. Empty glasses were filled in without prompting.

The restaurant was located at the second level of the shopping mall, and offered Putian cuisine, which originated from a coastal suburb in Fujian, China, also known as Xing Hwa 兴化 cuisine. The family decided to celebrate grandma's birthday here, and she was given a soft toy by the staff. Looking through the various menus, we decided on the OCBC Exclusive Set for 8 people which cost $248++. Do take note that plain water is chargeable at $0.50++ per glass. The wet tissue and the preserved vegetable on the table are chargeable too.Starters Platter : Seaweed with Mini Shrimps, Braised Bamboo Shoot, Pork Belly with Garlic, Braised Homemade Bean CurdSeaweed with Mini Shrimps (ala carte $7.50++)To retain the best texture and nutrition of the seaweed, we use only 15cm-long top-grade seaweed that is harvested within 30 days after cultivation. Tossed with quality mini shrimps imported from the South China Sea region, every mouthful of this starter is a delightful and refreshing experience.The seaweed was very thin, with texture similar to black moss.Braised Bamboo Shoot (ala carte $7.50++)Bamboo shoots smoked in slow fire, then braised for a savoury finish.The bamboo shoots was well braised and juicy.Pork Belly with Garlic (ala carte $8.90++)Tender pork belly slices topped with rich garlic sauce over a bed of cucumbers.The pork belly was cold and refreshing.Braised Homemade Bean Curd (ala carte $5.90++)PUTIEN's specialty bean curd braised for savoury bursts of flavour every bite.Somehow this dish reminded me of mock abalone, but it taste quite savoury.Braised Bean Curd with Chinese Cabbage (ala carte $25.90++ (M))Homemade bean curd and chinese cabbage, flavoured with Putian seasonal clams, dried shrimps and dried scallops in a light, tasty broth.It was a simple soup but the soup was full of flavours especially from the seafood. The bean curd soaked up the soup easily.Steamed Live Seabass (ala carte $4.90++/100g (Seabass)Fresh fish steamed with garlic, black bean in soy sauce and chilli oil, then topped with a generous serving of chopped chillies for a savoury-spicy complement to the fish's natural sweetness.The fish was fresh and juicy.Steamed Prawns with Minced Garlic (ala carte $32.00++ (M))Succulent prawns lightly steamed and topped with savoury minced garlic.It was helpful that the prawns had been sliced into two, so that it would be easier to remove the meat from the shells.PUTIEN Sweet & Sour Pork with Lychees (ala carte $18.90++ (M))Deep fried to light golden brown, the meat is tender and moist on the inside. The lychee is a perfect complement with its added burst of sweetness to the sauce.Looked not bad, but the crust encasing the meat was lacking of crispiness. Stir-fried Green Dragon Vegetable with Garlic (ala carte $14.90++ (M))A healthy dose of emerald green vegetables infused with fragrance of garlic slices.I like that the dish was fried with lots of garlic slices, but the vegetable was lacking of crunchiness. Choice of 1 Main Course : Mazu Mee Sua (ala carte $26.80++ (L))Mee Sua, or literally, "Long Noodles", symbolizes longevity. PUTIEN Mee Sua is handmade using traditional methods and a recipe unique to Putian. Using premium quality flour, the pristine, white, thread-thin vermicelli doesn't turn soggy when cooked.The noodle was smooth and well braised with a strong alcoholic taste in the flavourful broth.Dessert of the Day : White Fungus with Gingko Nut and Red DateThe dessert was served hot and light in taste.Complimentary Fruit PlatterThe fruit served were fresh and juicy.Overall the food delicious and filling. The service was not bad with the staff helping to serve the noodle and soup in small bowls.

Love their famous Xin Hua Bee Hoon so we decided to head here to celebrate my mum's birthday. However, the Bee Hoon was drier then usual and we were quite disappointed with it. The Lor Mee looked way better.However, the family love the vibe of the place with awesome service from the staff so this place warrants a 5* rating.P.s Putien is giving away free Monkey toy if you celebrate your birthday there because this is the year of the Monkey in the Chinese zodiac.

[ 3.5 star instead of 3, the dishes make up for the sluggish service)Putien "", the pioneer of Heng Hwa () cuisine in Singapore has been serving simple and purity meals for the past decade. Since its opening in the millennium year, it has never fail to draw eager diners to the restaurants. Putien being the name, is a city in Fujian province in China. The Putianese also referred to Xinghua, speaks a min language and this group of dialect is not common in Singapore. However, its cuisine has been well-liked by many. I am intrigued.Stepping into the restaurant at Nex shopping mall, it was 70% filled with heartlanders. Despite the after lunch hours at 2.15pm, the flow of diners didn't stop yet I was able to get a table effortlessly. I was attracted to the clean and spacious setting, something which helps to ease my tension from the enormous afternoon heat. The table-to-table arrangement has been quite roomy and not elbow-knocking. I truly enjoyed the soothing therapeutic melody playing in the background while waiting for the dishes, it definitely cools you down even having to wait long, if need be.  I am no novice to Putien dishes, I snapped at my comfort food. The wait staff who took orders was prompt and attentive while another who managed the beverage, had been a little sluggish. Hence, I attribute the "lag" to individual working attitude than putting them down as a whole. I had premium Iron Goddess of Mercy, "Tie Guan Yin" for a refreshing taste buds to accompany my meals. The tea leaves comes in whole and the oolong fragrance was very strong. Every sip sparks me up and seems to get me ready for the dishes behind the kitchen. Truly stands above the rest and I get heartened every time the tea cup was refilled with hot boiling water.I did not opt for any starter and zoom right into the mains. I ordered the Fried Homemade Beancurd, Deep Fried Tenggiri Fish and the notorious Fried Heng Hwa Bee Hoon.   The fried homemade beancurd was delightful. It has a pronounced soybean aroma which enlivened by the sprinkled salt (resembled french fries but replacing the carbo-rich ingredient with a healthier version) . Each thinly sliced bean curd has been fried to crisp and the accompanied sweet-sour garlic dip flavors it further (it was as good on its own).   I'd always like my tenggiri fish to be fried thoroughly till golden brown. Yes, Putien's very home-cooked way which reminds me of my granny's version. The fish was fresh with the meat being moist. No traces of awful fishy taste in them which made me adored even more. No greasy after-taste was a plus factor.The most anticipated dish; Fried Heng Hwa Bee Hoon was the star of the meal.
